Text: It’s so important for businesses to come together and take a stand for refugees. Virgin is committed to improving the lives of refugees and as part of the Business Refugee Action Network we’re calling on governments to do more: https://lnkd.in/dgxGEEY International Rescue Committee Ben & Jerry's The B Team

Name: Richard Branson
Text: Interesting read on purpose and perspective from Virgin Galactic’s new CEO Michael Colglazier #VirginFamily

Name: Richard Branson
Text: Great to see Virgin StartUp exploring the future of business and the rise of purpose-driven business in their most recent MeetUp. Here’s more from Holly Branson: https://virg.in/bst

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Growing up is never easy—especially during a pandemic. Even before COVID emerged, around one in five young people experienced a mental health disorder like depression or anxiety. And millions of young people don't get the help they need—especially young people of color and LGBTQ+ youth.The Upswing Fund for Adolescent Mental Health, a new project seeded by Pivotal Ventures, will provide resources to organizations that directly serve young people’s mental health needs. The fund will also support innovative efforts to address the systemic barriers that keep too many young people from accessing care.During this difficult time, young people everywhere should know that they are not alone. https://m-gat.es/3dMfHXg

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: “While a small fraction of U.S. companies (9%) offer paid paternity leave,” Reddit co-founder Alexis Ohanian Sr. writes, “the stark reality is that many men don’t take advantage of the opportunity, due to a looming stigma and fear of losing their standing—or, even worse, their job.”His solution: Normalize paid leave for all employees—and empower men to actually take it.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Powerful words from Malala Yousafzai in light of this year's International Day of the Girl:“We need economic systems that work for girls and women–not against them. We need to reshape the outdated curriculum that still defines what girls and boys learn in the classroom and take into the world. We need more women in decision-making roles on education policies and budgets.”Read her full piece at https://lnkd.in/ghr4brx.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: COVID has highlighted longstanding inequities in access to mental health care—especially for young people.Our partner United for Global Mental Health has joined forces with the World Health Organization and World Federation for Mental Health to inspire action this #WorldMentalHealthDay, urging people around the world to "move for mental health" to increase awareness and funding for global mental health.Together, we can reduce stigma and create change. What will you do today to #MoveForMentalHealth?https://lnkd.in/gkvRqCV

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: The world’s economic recovery from COVID should start with making sure everyone can meet their basic needs and pursue opportunities. I spoke with The World Bank about why it’s so important for countries to invest in their people.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: I’m looking forward to speaking with the International Monetary Fund’s Kristalina Georgieva and CNN’s Becky Anderson about how the world can address the disproportionate economic impacts of COVID on women’s livelihoods. We’ll discuss why governments need to put women and girls at the center of their response so they can emerge from this crisis stronger, more prepared, and more equal. Hope you’ll join us. https://m-gat.es/33TyVGW

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Malala Yousafzai wrote about the kind of world she’d like to see for women and girls following the COVID pandemic on Evoke.  “I often say that my goal is to see every girl in school in my lifetime,” she writes. “But imagine that COVID is a turning point, a time when we invest in education like never before in human history, a time when we finally make good on so many years of promises.”Let’s recommit to centering girls and women in our response to COVID.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: I’m so impressed by the girls I meet around the world who turn challenges into opportunities for change.Marley Dias is one of them. To mark International #DayoftheGirl, we spoke about her love of reading, #1000BlackGirlBooks, and how trailblazing Black women inspired her to become an advocate.Don’t miss Marley’s excellent book recommendations!

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: “Can we afford to allow our children to grow up in a society that limits or devalues their potential?” writes Alfiee (Dr. Alfiee) Breland-Noble for World Mental Health Day. No, we certainly can’t.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: I think a lot about the societal expectations of women. What can be worse? The cost — for all of us — of society’s expectations of men. We’re paying a steep price for it today.   In this week’s What the Elle newsletter, from Ellevest.#whattheelle #leadership #diversityequityandinclusion

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: I always find the annual Lean In "Women in the Workplace" report to be an important read, and this year’s is essential.Due to the disproportionate impacts of the pandemic, more than 1 in 4 women are considering downshifting their careers or leaving the workforce altogether, Lean In’s research found. It’s crucial that leaders act now to make sure COVID doesn’t unwind years of progress for women in the workplace.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As a young woman, math changed my life. But I was lucky. Math classrooms currently aren’t designed to help all students succeed—especially girls, students affected by poverty, and Black and Latinx students.Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation’s new Grand Challenge for Algebra 1 seeks to change that—with your help.Submit your bold ideas for how to make math accessible to all young people. https://m-gat.es/30ILpzg

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: The stories I’ve heard from women around the world have called me to action. I’m honored to be among the voices calling for progress for women in the new book, “Vital Voices: 100 Women Using their Power to Empower." Vital Voices mentors and invests in women leaders around the world. Leader by leader, it’s proving that the world gets better when women gain the power to make decisions, control resources, and shape perspectives. I hope you’ll take a look at the organization and the words of so many of my heroes in this book.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: So love this tribute to RBG from Esther Wojcicki, celebrating her legacy as a trailblazer and her wisdom as a mother.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Today in Wake-Up Call, wellness coach and best-selling author Kristin Meekhof shares eight things we all can do to help elevate our mood and decrease our stress related to these trying times.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: In all of the swirl of news, let's not lose the thread that women are falling (even further) behind financially during this downturn. And it hurts all of us. I talk about it in this CBS This Morning segment. Ellevest #genderwealthgap #genderpaygap #personalfinance

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: When COVID reached Kenya, businesses closed, work became scarce, and mothers like Faith had to make impossible choices to keep their children safe and fed.Faith’s first-person account of adapting to life during the pandemic offers powerful testimony that women’s economic empowerment and equality must be central to global response and recovery efforts.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As COVID puts progress toward gender equality at risk around the world, simple tools like digital payment and ID systems can help women remain economically empowered.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: This year has become a more important time to advocate for gender equality than we ever could have imagined. Women must be at the center of the global response to COVID in order for the world to build back stronger, more prepared, and more equal than before.As we mark the 25th anniversary of the Fourth World Conference on Women and look ahead to the #GenerationEquality Forum in June, let’s keep making it clear: Equality can’t wait.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: "Some companies may think that worrying about employee burnout is a luxury they can’t afford right now. In fact, it’s mission-critical. If companies rise to the moment, they can head off the disaster of losing millions of women and setting gender diversity back years. They can also lay the groundwork for a better future beyond COVID."— Sheryl Sandberg and Rachel Thomas #WomenInTheWorkplace

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Pivotal Ventures Director Renee Wittemyer and Techstars Managing Director Jason Towns explain why we need more innovation for caregivers and their loved ones—and how the Techstars Future of Longevity Accelerator will help entrepreneurs grow their businesses and create greater health, safety, and dignity. https://lnkd.in/gtx-zPb

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Amazing things happen when women gather—even when it’s virtually. I’m proud to be a keynote speaker at today’s Texas Conference for Women to harness our collective wisdom and reaffirm our commitment to the work for gender equality. https://m-gat.es/2G694Tj

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: The global community needs to act now to prevent vaccine inequality—a situation in which high-income nations have the doses to immunize against COVID while other nations do not. This wouldn’t just be a moral failure. It would also be dangerous for the entire world. Projections show that if low-income countries can't stop the spread of COVID, high-income countries will continue to risk reinfection and economic pain because of the disease.The good news is that we can prevent vaccine inequality by distributing the necessary tools and drugs to nations that need them. Equitable distribution will save millions of lives and shorten the pandemic for everyone.Read more in this piece from Bill Gates.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Excited to be on today's season premiere of Red Table Talk with folks who know how to keep it very real! Watch the full episode at https://lnkd.in/ebrTdVJ

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As work parents continue to navigate the COVID crisis, they are demonstrating admirable grit and creativity to adjust to the fact that many schools and childcare services are not returning for in-person classes or care. I’m eager to learn more about how this change continues to impact you and your families. Working parents, how are you coping? What has worked and what needs to change?

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Shaylene and Dominique were thrilled to be expecting their first children. But once their babies were born, their paths diverged. One of the women had paid family leave and the other didn’t.New America l Vicki Shabohttps://lnkd.in/gWb5FMQ

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Even before the pandemic began, millions of Americans were caring for their aging relatives—often without adequate support. My company, Pivotal Ventures, has partnered with Techstars to help entrepreneurs advance new, innovative solutions for older Americans and the people who love and look after them. The head of this effort, Jason Towns, talked to Evoke about how entrepreneurs are rising to meet this urgent challenge.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Representation matters. Serena and Venus Williams blazed a path in tennis that helped young stars like Naomi Osaka follow in their footsteps and forge new inroads of their own. Together, they’re changing the game.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As Americans continue to mourn Ruth Bader Ginsburg, I highly recommend reading this essay she wrote in 2016. In it, she shared advice that served her well throughout her life, from balancing work and family as a young law student to becoming a trailblazer on our nation’s highest court. Through her work and her words here, Justice Ginsburg showed that all of society benefits when women are in leadership roles.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Please meet a group of extraordinary individuals: the winners of the Goalkeepers 2020 Global Goals Awards. From Nepal to Nigeria, this year’s honorees are taking action in their communities to make progress toward the Global Goals in the face of COVID. Bonita Sharma has received the Progress Award for her work to educate women and girls in Nepal. As co-founder of Social Changemakers and Innovators, she’s worked to improve nutritional health for nursing mothers and young children and to empower marginalized women economically. The Changemaker Award goes to Hauwa Ojeifo. A sexual and domestic abuse survivor, Ojeifo is the founder of She Writes Women, a women-led organization providing mental health support to survivors of gender-based violence and individuals living with mental health conditions.MASH Project Foundation based in India, has received the Campaign Award. Through work with more than 500 partners in more than 20 cities, they’re building a global community of change-makers to bridge gaps between government, civil society, youth and media.Dr. John Nkengasong has received the Global Goalkeeper Award. The director of the Africa Centres for Disease Control and Prevention, Dr. Nkengasong has championed global collaboration and evidence-based public health practices.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: I’m a big believer in the power of data to uncover problems and highlight solutions. The data behind this year’s Goalkeepers report sends a clear message: We need global collaboration to end the pandemic and move our world forward. Take a look at this stunning chart, which shows the number of lives that can be saved through equitable distribution of a future COVID vaccine. I encourage you to dig into the rest of the data, too. https://m-gat.es/2ErMsM4

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Women in low-income jobs are bearing the brunt of the economic downturn caused by the pandemic. Think of the garment worker whose factory has shut down because the global demand for new clothes has stalled. Or the woman who sells food in an outdoor market and has to close shop because no one is gathering anymore. Leaders around the world can—and must—step in. Emergency cash transfers—that are designed to reach women—are a good way to prevent this pandemic from locking these workers and their families into poverty.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As we mark International Equal Pay Day, here are some startling facts about gender pay inequity right here in the United States.-	Black women earn 38% less than white men.-	Native American women earn 43% less than white men.-	Latinas earn 45% less than white men.Read more about the gender pay gap from our friends at Lean In. #EqualityCantWait

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: At the core of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s extraordinary life was a simple conviction: “Women belong,” she said, “in all places where decisions are being made.” She was a brilliant jurist, an inimitable Supreme Court justice, a force for equality and integrity—and she was one of my heroes. There will never be another RBG, but we are a much better, fairer country for all that she gave us.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: My father’s death is a tremendous loss for our family and the many people whose lives he touched. Dad lived a long and enormously meaningful life. I never stopped learning from his wisdom, kindness, and humility. Melinda and I owe him a special debt because his commitment to serving the community and the world helped inspire our own philanthropy. Although he would be the last person to say it, my father’s compassion and generosity will live on in the foundation he helped build. As I’ve said many times before, my dad was the real Bill Gates. He was all the things I strive to be.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Did you know the typical Black family has 1/10th the wealth of a white family? I spoke to the President of Ally Invest Lule Demmissie about why this racial wealth gap exists — and what individuals and businesses can do to help close it.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: If you take away one message from this year’s Goalkeepers report, I’d like it to be this: The world can end the COVID pandemic and start to undo its damage if we commit to work together.  The Goalkeepers report is our annual assessment of the world’s progress toward the 17 Sustainable Development Goals—a set of goals that countries, gathered at the United Nations, agreed to achieve by 2030. Reaching these goals will help us realize a world where every person has an equal opportunity to lead a healthy, productive life. I won’t sugarcoat it: The 2020 report is not a comforting read. The pandemic is worsening inequalities everywhere and slowing down, and sometimes reversing, progress the world has made toward the goals.  But I hope the urgency and possibilities of our shared global mission will make this report inspiring, too.  Global cooperation can still fix this global crisis. Through innovation and an equitable distribution of solutions, we can still make up lost ground. So let’s get to work. You can read this year’s full Goalkeepers report here.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: This beautiful piece from Nigerian poet Titilope Sonuga—previewing themes from our foundation’s upcoming Goalkeepers report—is well worth your time.I love this line in particular: “We make our lives a cathedral of joy with room in it for all of us.”To learn more about why the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation launched Goalkeepers visit https://lnkd.in/dscuMAg.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: We’re proud to support SecondMuse’s #HeadstreamInnovationFestival and the young innovators building tools and solutions for mental wellbeing.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Members of our Thrive community shared their go-to strategies for bringing more mindful moments into their days. What works for you?

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: This mug reminds me of the importance of not caring what other people think. In order to be your most unique, creative self, you will need to let go of caring what others think about you. It’s one of the greatest gifts you can give yourself. It takes self-awareness, self-reflection, determination, and lots of courage.Not caring what others think about you doesn’t mean you don’t care about them... it just means you don’t need their validation to be you. It’s been my life’s practice to work on this... I hope it becomes yours too. Be you! #Entrepreneur #MondayMotivation #MondayMugShot

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: So excited to listen to the new season of Seneca Women's Conversations on Power and Purpose #podcast - which features fascinating conversations withleaders who are using their power for purpose to accelerate women while building a better world. The first episode is out now and features two-time gold medalist, author, and activist Abby Wambach! Listen here 👇

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: A survey of people in 18 countries finds women are more likely than men to agree that their household workload has increased during the pandemic.As part of the response to COVID, countries must recognize and address women’s disproportionate share of unpaid work.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: In 1995, Hillary Clinton declared in Beijing that “women’s rights are human rights.” Twenty-five years later, she reflects on that speech and gives a clear-eyed look at the progress the world still needs to make to achieve gender equality. “Rights are important,” she argues, “but they are nothing without the power to claim them.”

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: No conversation on COVID is complete without the voices of women.Women are at the center of the pandemic’s social and economic impacts and need to be at the center of the world’s response, too. That starts with listening to women. https://m-gat.es/390l4zn

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: In a world of interconnected markets, a canceled prom in New Jersey can contribute to garment workers in Ethiopia going hungry. This piece does a great job at breaking down why women can be more economically vulnerable in crises and how governments can address some of these structural issues.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Our country needs new solutions to help older Americans and the people who care for them. The pandemic has made that abundantly clear. Entrepreneurs are answering that call. My company, Pivotal Ventures, has teamed up with Techstars to support innovators who are taking on some of the biggest challenges in eldercare.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: To build back from COVID more prosperous and more equal than before, the world needs more—and better—data on women. https://m-gat.es/3gBZZ0v

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As the U.S. Open starts, I’m thinking about a tennis match from 47 years ago. I still remember sitting in front of the TV as a kid and watching Billie Jean King take on Bobby Riggs in “The Battle of the Sexes.”  I recently got to speak to Billie Jean about that experience and how it helped spur her to decades of activism for gender equality. “For me, playing Bobby had little to do with tennis,” she told me. “It may have been a tennis match, but it was all about social change.”

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As the U.S. Open starts, I’m thinking about a tennis match from 47 years ago. I still remember sitting in front of the TV as a kid and watching Billie Jean King take on Bobby Riggs in “The Battle of the Sexes.”  I recently got to speak to Billie Jean about that experience and how it helped spur her to decades of activism for gender equality. “For me, playing Bobby had little to do with tennis,” she told me. “It may have been a tennis match, but it was all about social change.”

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Warren Buffett is one of those people who always has a kind word for everyone. He likes to make sure everyone feels celebrated. Today, on his 90th, I'd love to do that for him. Happy birthday, my friend.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: I’m excited to share TIME'S UP’s new report, “Unsafe and Underpaid: How Sexual Harassment and Unfair Pay Hold Women Back,” demonstrating how sexual harassment and pay inequity reinforce each other — and offering recommendations for eradicating them. ➡️ times.upnow.us/2EDbKGG #TIMESUPPAYUP

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Many of us learned that the movement for American women’s right to vote started in Seneca Falls in 1848 and ended in 1920 with the ratification of the 19th Amendment. The reality isn’t so simple—but it’s a lot more interesting.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Lifelong civil rights activist Mary Church Terrell was a woman of firsts. She was elected the first president of the National Association of Colored Women. She was one of the first Black women to earn a bachelor’s degree. And she, along with her daughter, participated in the first-ever pickets of the White House in 1917.We can’t commemorate the 19th Amendment without recognizing her work—and the work of many other Black activists whose stories are often overlooked in history books.https://m-gat.es/34eIktl

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: For Women’s Equality Day, some light reading on the history of women, voting and equality, from Ellevest

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Today, on Women’s Equality Day, we commemorate the 100th anniversary of the 19th Amendment granting some women the right to vote.  It’s a day of celebration—but it’s also a call to action.Although we’ve made great progress as a nation, we still have a long way to go to achieve gender equality—especially for women of color.How will you honor women today and continue the fight for equality? Let us know in the comments. #EqualityCantWait #WomensEqualityDay

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: This Women’s Equality Day, I’m issuing a challenge: The #EqualityCantWait Challenge. Along with many others, I’m committed to driving faster progress for women and girls in the U.S., especially for women and girls of color.Join us by bringing your bold ideas to the table and spreading the word. https://m-gat.es/31r3LFC

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: If we’ve learned one thing in 2020, it’s that the pace of progress is anything but static.  On this Women’s Equality Day, we can choose to accept continued incremental gains for women and girls—or we can insist on something much better, much sooner. More women, especially more women of color, need to be in positions to make the decisions, control the resources, and shape the policies that affect their lives and communities. And it can’t happen soon enough. #EqualityCantWait

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Do what others say cannot be done, that's where it's most fun! I have spent the last 20 years doing things they said couldn't be done, to bring women better and more comfortable options. When the purpose of WHY you're doing something is greater than yourself, it's easier to find the courage you need to do it. #MondayMotivation

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Women leaders around the world have had success in slowing the spread of COVID. A fascinating new study has found that leadership styles may help explain why.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: We can't allow COVID to derail students’ dreams of going to college. That’s why the Bill & Melinda Gates Foundation will expand partnerships with three organizations that get students the support they need to stay on the path to college and complete their degrees.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: If the pandemic stalls progress toward gender equality, the cost will be in the trillions. But if policymakers use this emergency as an opportunity to replace old systems with new and better ones, the world can build back more prosperous, more prepared, and more equal. Learn more: https://m-gat.es/2PRa3YE

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As we commemorate the 100th anniversary of the 19th Amendment, I’ve been thinking a lot about why we know the names of some activists who fought for women’s voting rights and not others, and why the complicated history of the amendment’s passage can be a call to action for us now.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: This month marks 100 years since the 19th Amendment’s passage. For #seeherstory, we’re highlighting the life of Alice Paul — a famous suffragette. Born in 1885, Alice attended suffrage meetings with her mother from a young age. She organized the National Women’s Party — and held protests at the White House. When women finally received the right to vote, Paul dedicated her life to the Equal Rights Amendment, which has yet to be ratified by all states. #vote #votingrights #19thamendment #history #seeher

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Epidemics don’t just overwhelm immune systems. They also overwhelm health systems. And because the parts of those systems devoted to caring for women are often the most fragile and underfunded, they collapse first.There is still time to prevent tragic and needless deaths. The first step: In every country—and for every woman—sexual and reproductive health care must be classified as the essential services they are.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: To do better by women, employers must do better by Black women.For #BlackWomensEqualPay Day, Lean In has released a new report shining a light on the specific challenges Black women face at work—and sharing ideas for how companies can ensure Black women are given equal opportunities to learn, grow, and lead.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Today is #BlackWomensEqualPayDay. Black women work full-time in the U.S. typically earn 62 cents for every dollar a white man makes. Per a new analysis, this wage gap costs Black women more than $23,000 a year. There’s also research that shows that Black women are among the hardest hit by the coronavirus unemployment crisis.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: You may know that Sojourner Truth was a pioneering activist for racial and gender equality.But do you know the story behind the name she chose for herself after she escaped from slavery? Or that she sold self-portraits to challenge the images of Black people in widely circulated racist cartoons?As we commemorate the centennial of the 19th Amendment this month, let’s learn more about the Black activists who challenged both sexism and racism in their fight for the vote—and let’s recommit to continuing their work to advance equality. https://m-gat.es/2DGwKwi

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: 2020 is a historic year for women running for political office in the U.S. Kamala Harris is the first Black woman and the first person of Indian descent to be selected as the vice-presidential candidate of a major party ticket. And our partner the Center for American Women and Politics reports that a record number of women have filed to run for Congress this year.A century after the 19th Amendment was ratified, our country has made important progress to expand women’s role in public life. But we still have A LOT more work to do. Even though a record number of women are running for Congress, seven out of every ten House and Senate candidates this year is a man. If we want to reach gender equality in America, our government needs to look more like the people it represents. When women are at the table where decisions are made, we all win. Dig into the Center for American Women and Politics’ data to learn more about women who are running for office in 2020: https://lnkd.in/g8cJ74i

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: It’s a historic year for women in politics—from Kamala Harris, the first Black woman and the first person of Indian descent to serve as the VP candidate of a major party, to the record number of women running for Congress.But women are still massively underrepresented in public office and make up less than 30% of House and Senate candidates in 2020. We need to change that. #EqualityCantWait

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: "What we choose to do now will echo throughout the lives of these girls, their communities, their countries, and our entire world. We owe it to them -- to all of us -- to support them in this critical moment." — Michelle Obama and Melinda Gates

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: As we commemorate the centennial of the 19th Amendment, we have to stay committed to advancing systemic change for women of all backgrounds.  I’m joining The 19th News–a new nonprofit newsroom focused on the intersection of gender, politics, and policy–for the #19thRepresents virtual summit this week. Take a look at the outstanding lineup and register: https://m-gat.es/31CVkWI

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Representation matters, especially when it makes history. Today’s announcement of Kamala Harris as the first Black woman and person of Indian descent to be a major party’s vice presidential candidate is a momentous step forward for our country and for all of us.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: School may look a little different this fall, but that’s only more reason to support teachers as they get ready for the new year. In partnership with DonorsChoose and PowerOf, we’re boosting donations to the classroom project of your choice today. 🍎

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: We need to speed up the progress of women becoming decision-makers in the United States. And you can help change this ratio.Step one: Use our assessment tool to see if your idea to increase women’s power and influence is a good fit for the Equality Can’t Wait Challenge and its $40 million in grants. 👉 https://lnkd.in/gk_ZZCE

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: “According to Paid Leave for All, when the pandemic hit the U.S., more than 33 million workers—many of them low-wage workers of color—didn’t have a single guaranteed paid sick day.”As this piece highlights, the need for paid leave in America has grown even more urgent.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Michelle Obama and I joined forces to share a message we feel strongly about: As the world works to solve the challenges of COVID, we must take decisive action to make sure girls everywhere have a chance to learn, to stay healthy, and to stay safe—not just for their sake, but for all of ours.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Embrace when things are broken. When I started Spanx I was selling fax machines door to door and getting kicked out of buildings, dating the wrong guys and feeling very broken. When things feel the most broken is when we feel the most inspired to create change... don't give up! #Entrepreneur

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: In 1968, Shirley Chisholm became the first Black woman to be elected to Congress. Today, more than 20 Black women serve in the House and Senate—progress, but not nearly enough.Throughout history, Black women have helped make America’s government more open and inclusive—even while facing racism and sexism. As we approach the centennial of the 19th Amendment, learn more about Black women who led the fight for women’s voting rights in “Truth Be Told,” a special edition of Evoke.https://m-gat.es/2PnIZzM

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: “As I laid there in my driveway, incapacitated by the intersectional and multilayered trauma of Black death and dying, I started to think about what it means to survive white supremacy and anti-Black violence.” Postdoctoral researcher Tiera Tanksley works with our partner Connected Learning Lab, which helps spread positive and pro-social behaviors between youth in support of mental wellbeing. She writes about leveraging social media for healing and joy during this time. #MentalHealth https://lnkd.in/g_DD7Gm

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Big news: Thanks to support from the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation, the Equality Can't Wait Challenge is now awarding $40 million in funding.  Registration for the Challenge is open until September 1. Interested in applying? Click to learn five tips for your application process.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Huge news! The Equality Can’t Wait Challenge just got bigger. With support from the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation, the challenge will now award a total of $40 million to the organizations with the biggest and boldest ideas to increase women’s power and influence by 2030. https://lnkd.in/eHWCEhr

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: “We should always be able to put our families first—not just during global health threats. But right now, paid leave is absolutely crucial for ending the COVID pandemic and this economic crisis.” Read more from PL+US: Paid Leave for the United States founder Katie Bethell and U.S. Rep. Jimmy Gomez about supporting all workers with a national paid leave policy. https://lnkd.in/grsX23F

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: In this week’s What the Elle newsletter, from Ellevest, I share what finally — after all these months — brought me to tears, as the lessons from the pandemic crystallize for women. #whattheelle #personalfinance #essentialworkers

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: #SeeHer Story: Hattie McDaniel made history as the first Black Academy Award winner for her role in "Gone With The Wind", but she wasn’t allowed to attend the ceremony due to the color of her skin. SEEHER

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Access to contraceptives should be considered an essential service during the pandemic. Here’s why it matters so much:

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: Some exciting news about the Equality Can’t Wait Challenge: It just got bigger.   I’m grateful to the Charles and Lynn Schusterman Family Foundation for joining the Challenge, so we can increase its impact.   Now is the time to invest real resources in the advocates and solutions that will drive progress for women across the country. Learn more, and consider applying, at https://lnkd.in/gYnKXRu.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: You know that moment just before a rocket takes off? The course is set, the engines are firing, and it’s about to get the boost it needs to get on its way to the moon.  That’s the moment of lift. I spoke with The New York Times editor, Francesca Donner for the Women's Forum for the Economy & Society about why we may be on the cusp of many such moments thanks to young people calling for change.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: World leaders from South Korea’s Moon Jae-in to New Zealand’s Jacinda Ardern and South Africa’s Cyril Ramaphosa agree: “None of us is safe until all of us are safe.”Once a safe and effective COVID vaccine is successfully developed, access to it must be equitable.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: What we read in our history books isn’t always the complete story. As we approach the centennial of the 19th Amendment, it’s important to learn about the lesser-known stories of the women and men who played crucial roles in the fight for women’s suffrage. Get started by reading about the Seneca Falls Convention, a seminal moment in the movement, told from eight different perspectives.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: The TIME'S UP national survey on the #paygap adds urgency to our work: 6 in 10 women say they’ve faced gender or racial discrimination or obstacles to higher-paying jobs. Learn more here:https://lnkd.in/ewd6Vit

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: How many women have died of COVID?  How many women have lost their jobs in the adjacent economic crisis?  And how many have had to stop work because schools and daycares have closed?  I don’t know the full answer to any of these questions. No one does. When it comes to the pandemic, and its effect on women, too often we just don’t have the numbers.  I write in STAT about why countries need more and better gender data to effectively respond to this pandemic.

Name: Melinda Gates
Text: I learned some of these names in school: Sojourner Truth, Ida B. Wells-Barnett, Harriet Tubman.But others I didn’t: Frances E.W. Harper, Nannie Helen Burroughs, Mary Church Terrell. Join me in learning more about the women who fought both sexism and racism in the long struggle for women’s voting rights. https://m-gat.es/3052Iuu

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: To all our small and medium-sized business owners and entrepreneurs: thank you. You help shape our communities and keep our country strong. Now I know this year hasn’t been easy, but we’re going to be here for you - this week and every week - until the end of this crisis. https://bit.ly/2IEaFAp

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Applications for the Canada Recovery Benefit are now open. If you’re directly affected by COVID but are self-employed or can’t access Employment Insurance, this benefit is here to help you. If you’re eligible, you’ll get $500 each week for up to 26 weeks. You can apply for this support through Canada Revenue Agency’s My Account, or you can call 1-800-959-2019 or 1-800-959-2041. It’s a quick and simple process - and if you’ve applied for the Canada Emergency Response Benefit in the past, it’s very similar to that. To learn more about the Canada Recovery Benefit, to see if you’re eligible, and to submit an application, click here:  https://bit.ly/31058L2

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Even though we’ve been through a lot this year, there’s still so much to be grateful for - our family and friends, those work on the front lines, and everyone who’s come forward to lend a helping hand. Hope you all have a happy and healthy Thanksgiving! https://bit.ly/34R0q38

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: As we head into the long weekend, I hope everyone stays safe and connects with their loved ones virtually. And if you’re going to the store, make sure you have the COVID Alert app on your phone. To learn more about it, check out my conversation with Amber and Jean-François Gagné :

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: As our economic recovery from this pandemic continues, we need to be looking forward. A greener economy, a cleaner country, and a stronger future are what we all want - and we’re taking another step toward that today.  This morning, I joined Premier Ford virtually to announce our partnership with Ford Canada. Together, we’re investing in the transition of Ford’s Oakville Assembly Plant so they can make zero-emission electric vehicles. This investment secures more than 5,000 good jobs, opens up more opportunities for our auto sector, and positions our workers for success - whether they’re in Oakville, Windsor-Essex, or elsewhere in Canada. At the same time, by investing in technology that protects our environment, we’re also taking action on our plan to get to net-zero emissions by 2050. For more on today’s announcement and how we’re making building a country that’s cleaner and more competitive, click here: https://bit.ly/3jIAopd

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: As we continue to restart our economy and people head back to work, we know some may need more support - so we created new benefits to make sure people can get the help they need. For those who have to stay home from work because they’re sick or need to self-isolate due to COVID, there’s the Canada Recovery Sickness Benefit. And for those who need to stay home to take care of a child or parent, there’s the Canada Recovery Caregiving Benefit.Applications for both of these benefits are now open and can be submitted through Canada Revenue Agency’s My Account - or by calling 1-800-959-2019 or 1-800-959-2041. For more information on these benefits and the application process, click here: https://bit.ly/3nrfi0P

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Today, Minister McKenna and I announced an investment of $10 billion in infrastructure projects across the country through the Canada Infrastructure Bank. This funding will create approximately 60,000 good jobs, strengthen our communities, and help grow our economy. This funding will also help connect small businesses to high-speed internet so they can better participate in the digital economy. It’ll help farmers enhance production and expand export opportunities. And it’ll help build a low-carbon economy that ensures Canada remains competitive. For more on the investment we announced today, and the work we’re doing to create good jobs today and into the future, click here: https://bit.ly/30rJ9fH #infrastructure #economy #jobs

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: COVID cases are rising across the country, and we need to take this seriously. We need to get this second wave under control. And we need to keep following public health rules - which means wearing masks, staying two metres apart, limiting the number of people inside your business, and letting your employees stay home if they feel sick. You can also download the COVID Alert app onto your phone and encourage your employees to do the same. It’s another tool you can use to keep yourselves and your customers and clients safe. After all, the more people who use it, the more effective it will be and the better we’ll be able to limit the spread of the virus. To learn more about the app, and to add it to your phone, click here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: COVID remains a serious health threat. And with the number of cases rising, we need to double down on our efforts to limit the spread. Watch live as I speak about what you can do to stay safe - and how we’ll be there to help:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: At the beginning of the pandemic, we put in place a number of measures to help you keep your doors open and your workers on the payroll - measures like the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy and the Canada Emergency Business Account. The pandemic has changed the world as we know it, and so we need to update our approach to make sure you can keep getting the support you and your business need. In today’s Speech from the Throne, we shared our plan for moving forward together and building back better. Whether you’re a young person looking for paid work experience, a woman hoping to get back into the workforce, a parent seeking better care for your kids as you return to the office, or a business owner adapting for the future, we’ll continue to be there for you. We’re going to extend the wage subsidy through to next summer, launch a campaign to create more than one million jobs, scale up the Youth Employment Strategy, and much more. For details on our plan to get the economy back up and running and Canadians back to work safely, click here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: The mining sector creates good jobs for Canadians, and will help Canada as we safely restart our economy and chart a path toward a clean and more competitive future. This morning, we broke ground at the Côté Gold mine with Chief Boissoneau, Chief Ray, and Premier Ford. During construction, the mine will create more than 1,000 jobs. And once that’s completed, there will be 450 full-time positions available. This is good news for members of the local First Nations, for people across Northern Ontario, and for our country’s economy. This project also reminds investors that Canada is still a great place to do business - and as we take this opportunity to build a more resilient country, we will continue to work with our partners to make sure Canada remains competitive in the global economy of the future.

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: From the outset of the pandemic, we’ve been work closely with the provinces and territories to protect your health and to make sure you have the support you need. We’ve been in regular contact with the premiers - and this afternoon, Minister @LeBlancDominic and I had another phone call with them. We covered a lot of ground during our conversation, talking about the steps we're taking together to support workers and business owners across the country, as well as the work we’re doing to help keep our kids safe at school. For more on today’s call, click here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Black business owners and entrepreneurs face unique challenges accessing the right financial tools and mentorship they need to succeed - and we’re taking action to change that. To support thousands of Black business owners and entrepreneurs across the country, today we announced the launch of Canada’s first-ever Black Entrepreneurship Program. This program will include a new National Ecosystem Fund to help them access financial planning services and business training, as well as the Black Entrepreneurship Loan Fund to help them get loans of up to $250,000. The program will also include funding to create a new Black Entrepreneurship Knowledge Hub. Run by Black-led community and business organizations, the Hub will help identify the barriers to success that Black entrepreneurs face and the opportunities they have to grow. We’ll keep work with Black business owners, entrepreneurs, and organizations so they can excel in the months and years to come. For more information on the Black Entrepreneurship Program, click here: https://bit.ly/3hjZSqB

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Small businesses are the backbone of our economy and key to our recovery. They’re rehiring workers, creating good jobs, and retooling to keep us safe. Today, I sat down with some owners and workers from across Atlantic Canada to talk about that and hear about what more we can do to help.  I met with the team from Louisbourg Seafoods and heard about how the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy helped them hire 600 seasonal workers. And when I sat down with folks from Distillerie Fils du Roy, they spoke about how they used the Canada Emergency Business Account program to stay open through the pandemic - and how they then retooled and produced hand sanitizer for essential services. I also met the CEO and two program managers from Tronosjet Maintenance and heard about the thermometer covers, nasal swabs, and mask straps they’re making to help keep people safe. These businesses are not alone. Many of you have been work around the clock these past several months to be there for Canadians. Know that our government is committed to being there for you too. For more on the programs some of these business owners used and how they could help your company, click here: https://bit.ly/3gRPHJO

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: This morning in Montreal, we announced the steps we’re taking to make sure we have access to potential COVID vaccines. Because as more people head back to work and our kids step back into the classroom, we’re staying focused on keeping everyone safe and healthy. That’s why we’ve signed two new agreements - one with Novavax, one with Johnson and Johnson - to reserve millions of doses of the vaccines they’re developing. Thanks to these agreements and our previous agreements with Pfizer and Moderna, we have reserved at least 88 million doses of potential vaccines, with options to obtain tens of millions more.And because we’ll also need to produce and distribute an eventual vaccine here at home, we're investing in the expansion of this National Research Council facility in Montreal. By next year, the bio-manufacturing facility here at Royalmount will be able to produce up to two million doses per month to help keep us safe.To learn more about the work we’re doing with researchers and scientists, and for all the details on the steps we’re taking to keep you safe, click here: https://bit.ly/3lED2h8

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: As we continue to restart our economy, you should be able to return to work knowing that your kids can safely head back to class. On that front, today our government announced an investment of up to $2 billion in school safety for the coming year - with an additional $112 million in funding for First Nation schools on reserves. We are work with the provinces and territories to make sure schools across the country have the support and resources they need. From personal protective equipment, to adapted learning spaces, to remote learning, schools can use this funding for whatever they need most. For more information on what we announced today, and to learn more about the steps we are taking to keep your kids safe when you head back to work, click here: https://bit.ly/2Ey1hMJ

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Since the beginning of this pandemic, our government has been focused on making sure workers across the country have the support they need. That was why, among other programs and subsidies, we introduced the Canada Emergency Response Benefit that helped more than 8.5 million people get through some difficult months - and we are extending the benefit by four more weeks. And as we restart our economy, making sure workers feel safe and supported remains a top priority. Today, Deputy Prime Minister Freeland and Minister Qualtrough announced changes to Employment Insurance, which will make the program more flexible, more generous, and available to more people. For more on the changes and three new benefits that were announced today, click here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Update on Parliament: Throughout the pandemic, we’ve supported Canadians with a huge emergency response. We’ve carefully – and successfully – reopened many parts of the economy. And in the coming weeks, we’ll present our plan to rebuild a stronger, more resilient Canada.  Earlier today, I asked the Governor General to prorogue Parliament. We will then present a Speech from the Throne on September 23rd to lay out, in detail, our approach going forward. It will also allow Parliament to hold a confidence vote on this new plan.  Whether you’re counting on the CERB or the wage subsidy, these programs will not be affected by the prorogation. And as we start a new session, our focus will continue to be on getting you the support you need. For more on existing programs, visit:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Today, we announced changes to the Cabinet to make sure we can continue to get you the support you need, and so we can keep work with the provinces and territories to protect your health and safety.  Deputy Prime Minister Chrystia Freeland will take on the role of Minister of Finance. She will be the first woman to assume that role, and I know she will continue to serve Canadians well as she leads the restart and recovery of our economy. She will also remain Deputy Prime Minister.  Dominic LeBlanc becomes Minister of Intergovernmental Affairs. He is already familiar with this portfolio, having previously served as the Minister from 2018-2019. In this role, he will work closely with the premiers on issues that matter most to you. He will also remain the President of the Queen’s Privy Council of Canada.

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Earlier today, I spoke with and accepted Minister Bill Morneau’s resignation. Since he was first elected and became Canada’s Finance Minister, Bill has worked tirelessly to support all Canadians and create an economy that benefits everyone. And thanks to his unwavering leadership and commitment to service throughout the pandemic, our government has laid the groundwork for a strong economic recovery. I have counted on his leadership, advice, and close friendship over the years and I look forward to that continuing. Bill, you have my deepest gratitude and I want to thank you for everything you have done to improve the quality of life of Canadians. I know you will continue making great contributions to our country in the years to come. My full statement on Minister Morneau’s resignation:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: As we continue to restart our economy, more businesses across the country are reopening their doors and rehiring their workers. We recognize that some business owners may need extra support though, and we extended and expanded the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy to make sure they have what they need to bridge to better times. If you own a business and are looking to use this program to get things back up and running, you can apply today. To learn more about the wage subsidy, to calculate how much support you can expect to receive, and to submit your application, click here: https://bit.ly/34cQ3If

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Across the country, more and more businesses are opening back up - but we know that owners and workers still need support. To make sure you have the help you need and your business can reopen its doors and rehire its workers, we’ve extended the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy until December 19th. We’ve also made it more accessible to support more businesses, and created a top-up for employers who were hit the hardest.Applications for the next period of the wage subsidy open up on Monday, and today we launched an updated and improved calculator that can help you get prepared. To learn more about the support that is available to you and your business, and to find out how much support you can expect to receive, click here: https://bit.ly/2XQZ45E

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Update on the Canada Emergency Response Benefit: Our goal is to transition everyone on the CERB to Employment Insurance. In the coming weeks, we will create a transitional, parallel benefit that is similar to Employment Insurance. This benefit will include access to training, and allow you to work more hours and earn more money. There will also be a sickness and caregivers benefit if you’re not covered at work if you get COVID, or if your kids or parents get it and you have to take care of them.  We’ll have more details to share in the coming weeks, but here’s the bottom line: we intend to cover every Canadian who is looking for work with a better, 21st century EI system. And there will be no increase to EI premiums during this challenging time.

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: As we continue to gradually restart our economy and more people head back to work, innovative technologies will help us keep our families and communities safe and healthy. Because even though we’ve made good progress over the past few months, COVID still remains a serious threat to our health. So today, we announced a new national mobile app – the COVID Alert app – which will help us limit the spread of the virus. The app, which is free to download and available now, will notify users if they may have been exposed to someone who has tested positive. Watch this video to learn how the app works, and for more info and to download the app click here: https://bit.ly/3feUaWg

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Across the country, businesses are reopening their doors and rehiring their workers. We’ve been there every step of the way so far - and today, we’re proposing changes to the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy so that even more business owners and workers can get the help they need.We propose extending the wage subsidy until December 19th. We also propose making it accessible to more employers, introducing a top-up for those who were hit the hardest, and more. Get all the details:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: We’re focused on getting you the support you need and keeping you safe. That’s why we’ve been work with the provinces and territories, and that’s why we’re investing more than $19 billion through our Safe Restart Agreement. Here’s what this investment will do:It will help increase testing and contact tracing. It will protect your loved ones who are most vulnerable. And it will support the capacity of our health care systems, and the procurement of personal protective equipment, so you can stay safe as we restart our economy.It will make sure your community - and all communities who have been at the forefront of this pandemic - can keep running and help our economy come back strong. And it will help them deliver the services that you rely on, like public transit.It will give you ten days of paid sick leave if you don’t already have access to that, so you can stay home if you contract the virus. And it will help make sure there are child care spaces available for your kids, so they have a safe place to go when you head back to work.For more on the work we’re doing with the provinces and territories to support you and keep you safe, click here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Months ago, we introduced the largest economic measures our country has seen since the Second World War to make sure you have the support you need to get through these tough times. We introduced the Canada Emergency Response Benefit to help millions of people make ends meet, and we created the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy to help business owners reopen their doors and rehire millions of workers. Our government also introduced special support for seniors to help them with the higher cost of living associated with this pandemic. And to help young people across the country pull through, we established the Canada Emergency Student Benefit. These are just some of the steps we have taken over the past few months, but there are other supports - including the Canada Emergency Business Account and Canada Emergency Commercial Rent Assistance - available for you. We will continue to invest in you - and in all Canadians - so we can come back stronger after this pandemic.

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Canada is an amazing place to call home, and its people make it even better. We’re always there for each other - in good times and bad - and we always will be. And that’s worth celebrating. Happy Canada Day, everyone! https://bit.ly/2BXzofA

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Hate has no place in our country and will not be tolerated. Working together with Canadians, the premiers and I are determined to fight racism and discrimination in all its forms - and achieve lasting change. Read our joint statement:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Whether you’re currently studying or you’ve recently graduated, we know the COVID has had an impact on your internships, placements, and job searches. So here’s what we’re doing to make sure you can gain the experience you need and contribute to your community: We’re launching the Canada Student Service Grant. If you’re a student or recent graduate and you volunteer to serve in your community’s COVID response, you could get a one-time payment of between $1,000 and $5,000 with this grant - depending on the number of hours you serve. We’re supporting new job placements and internships, including: 20,000 job placements through the Student Work Placement Program, 10,000 job placements through the Canada Summer Jobs program, 5,000 internships through Mitacs Canada, 3,500 job placements and internships through the Youth Employment and Skills Strategy, and between 5,000 and 10,000 work-integrated learning opportunities through the Business + Higher Education Roundtable. We’re increasing funding for the Digital Skills for Youth program to help college and university graduates gain professional work experience. And we’re supporting the Computers for Schools Plus program so they can keep helping young people across the country. Get all the details here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Small business owners create good jobs and make our communities stronger, but this pandemic has been hard on them. This morning, I met with Manuela - who owns three small businesses in Chelsea, Quebec - to talk about the challenges she’s faced and the programs that’ve helped.Manuela’s one of the many small business owners who are stepping up and hiring back their workers using the the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy - in fact, she’s been able to rehire nearly 75 of them. She’s also using the commercial rent assistance to help with her monthly expenses.If you’re a small business owner and, like Manuela, you just need some extra help to reopen your doors and rehire your workers, use the programs we’ve put in place. Learn more about all the support that’s available and see how you can apply today: https://bit.ly/3fxfZki

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: To help people put food on the table and make ends meet during this pandemic, we introduced the Canada Emergency Response Benefit. And now, as we safely restart our economy, we know far too many are still struggling - and it won’t be easy for everyone to head back to work right away. If you’re having trouble getting back on the job, you shouldn’t have to worry about buying groceries or paying the bills.So to make sure you can still get the help you need, we’re extending the Canada Emergency Response Benefit by 8 weeks. The benefit will now be available for up to 24 weeks.For more information on this extension and what that means for you, click here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Like so many small businesses across the country, Ottawa’s Régimbal Awards and Promotions was hit hard by this pandemic - they went down to 3 employees and were worried about making ends meet. But thanks to the wage subsidy, they’re back up and running with 17 employees.In addition to the wage subsidy, they’ve used the Canada Emergency Business Account and the rent subsidy too. If your business is also looking to open its doors again and pay its staff, click here to learn more about all the supports that are available: https://bit.ly/3fhj73G

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: We’ve launched a hotline service for entrepreneurs and small business owners - including not-for-profit organizations and charities. If you need help navigating these uncertain times, call 1-866-989-1080 to speak with an accountant or business advisor. They’re ready to help.

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: To the class of 2020: Congratulations! I know this isn’t how you expected your last semester to end, and the world you’re graduating into faces unprecedented challenges. But you have everything you need to succeed, and your hard work deserves to be celebrated. To do that and to mark this momentous occasion in your life, I had a few words for you this morning. Read my message to the class of 2020 here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: We’re doing everything we can to help people get back to work and give businesses the confidence to re-open and re-hire. After all, the way our economy will restart is by getting workers back on the job when it’s safe to do so. So if you own a business and you’re looking to start up again, the Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy is available to help you re-hire your workers. And we’ve extended it by three months (to the end of August) so you can re-hire even more of your staff. To learn more and apply for the wage subsidy, click here: https://bit.ly/3heqQBx

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: COVID has had an impact on everyone - and for people with disabilities, there have been many extra expenses to deal with. That’s why we’re announcing support for people with disabilities today, including a one-time $600 payment for those who get the Disability Tax Credit. We’re also creating a National Workplace Accessibility Stream to help people with disabilities find - and keep - a good job. And across the country, we’re funding five new projects to help people get the supportive devices they need to overcome barriers in the workplace. For more on the special payment we just announced and how we’re supporting people with disabilities, click here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: I’m announcing support for people with disabilities, giving an update on the work we’re doing with provinces and territories to safely restart our economy, and more. Tune in now for all the details:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Across the country, cities and towns are providing essential services - and it’s important that they have the resources they need. So as a first step, we’re speeding things up and making more than $2 billion available to them in the coming weeks. This funding will help get infrastructure projects underway, give businesses the confidence to reopen, and make sure you - and all hardwork Canadians - can get back on the job.Get more details on today’s announcement here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: I’m giving an update on the work we’re doing with the provinces and territories - and small towns and big cities across the country - as we look at restarting our economies. Watch live for more info:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: All countries are being tested by the COVID pandemic. Lives and livelihoods everywhere are being threatened by the virus and its impacts. In order to successfully rebuild our economies, we need to work together - and we need to think outside the box. That’s why Secretary-General António Guterres, Prime Minister Andrew Holness, and I cohosted a virtual meeting with leaders and organizations from around the world. We heard about current economic challenges, ideas for moving forward, and what more we can all do to help those who need it most. There’s no doubt this work is necessary for small island states and developing countries - but it’s important for Canada too. Because across our country, jobs and businesses depend on the health and stability of economies around the world.  The only way the global economy can recover, and the only way our own economy can bounce back, is by doing this work together. So that’s what we’ll do - and we’ll report back with concrete proposals to the world’s economic challenges by mid-July. There’s no time to lose.

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: COVID is a global health crisis that has claimed more than 344,000 lives. It’s also an economic and social crisis taking an enormous toll on the global economy. People are losing their jobs and many are being pushed into extreme poverty. This is a challenge that our world has not seen in generations, and it will require global solutions to address the impacts of this virus.The best way to help all our people and economies rebound is to work together as a global community. That’s why the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres, the Prime Minister of Jamaica, Andrew Holness, and I are co-hosting a meeting with leaders from around the world today. You can watch our discussion live here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: COVID is a global health crisis that has claimed more than 344,000 lives. It’s also an economic and social crisis taking an enormous toll on the global economy. People are losing their jobs and many are being pushed into extreme poverty. This is a challenge that our world has not seen in generations, and it will require global solutions to address the impacts of this virus.The best way to help all our people and economies rebound is to work together as a global community. That’s why the Secretary-General of the United Nations, António Guterres, the Prime Minister of Jamaica, Andrew Holness, and I are co-hosting a meeting with leaders from around the world today. You can watch our discussion live here:

Name: Justin Trudeau
Text: Applications are now open for the Canada Emergency Commercial Rent Assistance program. If you’re a property owner who’s eligible for the program, you can now apply for support to help you reduce rent for your small business tenants by 75% for the months of April, May, and June. Applying for this funding makes sense - because your success depends on the success of your tenants. And with this program, we’re making sure small business owners can get the help you need to recover and come back after this pandemic. For more on what we’re doing to help property owners and small business owners with commercial rent relief, click here:

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: HUMBLED: Esusu is delighted to be selected amongst the MetLife & Visa's Global Inclusive 50 Fintech Cohort. Special thanks to our team, investors, and the village that continues to support us. Learn more here --> https://lnkd.in/d2d5APNcc: Samir Goel

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I have just started Jeff Weiner's "On Leadership" course on LinkedIn Learning, packed with incredible teachings. Amazed by his strength & ingenuity in borrowing teachings from others, e.g. Jeff Bezos' silent reading of prepared memos before meetings. ...Our egos often don't allow us to borrow outside thinking, somehow it's seen as incompetent. But just as in the scientific process, borrowing & building on the works of others is how big progress gets made. #leadership #personalleadership

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I have just started Jeff Weiner's "On Leadership" course on LinkedIn Learning, packed with incredible teachings. Amazed by his strength & ingenuity in borrowing teachings from others, e.g. Jeff Bezos' silent reading of prepared memos before meetings. ...Our egos often don't allow us to borrow outside thinking, somehow it's seen as incompetent. But just as in the scientific process, borrowing & building on the works of others is how big progress gets made. #leadership #personalleadership

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Mentorship - over or underrated? 🤔  Hot takes welcome!Personally, I believe it's incredibly underrated. I could easily attribute any professional breakthrough to advice I've received from a mentor.One piece of feedback I'll never forget was from my last day at Stripe... After work under her leadership for 4 years, I asked Jeanne DeWitt Grosser what 1 thing she thought could help me on my next adventure.She personalized the classic "your greatest strength is often your greatest weakness" in a way that resonated so strongly that it's come up nearly every week since (both professionally, and personally). For me, my passion and sense of urgency was why I was successful – pushing the realm of possibilities for winning deals/providing value for customers, but also exactly why I struggled in important other areas... 🤯What advice has stayed with you from a mentor?

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: My amazing sister Yael Garten is an inspiration for tech lovers and women. This week she introduced Apple's new  #homepod mini, an amazing product enabling you to communicate via #siri to get things done. Keep inspiring us Yael! You’re setting a good role model for your kids and the next generation!#appleevent2020https://lnkd.in/dNYHzxF

Name: Jeff Weiner

This week she introduced Apple's new  #homepod mini, an amazing product enabling you to communicate via #siri to get things done. Keep inspiring us Yael! You’re setting a good role model for your kids and the next generation!#appleevent2020https://lnkd.in/dNYHzxF

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: No more typos! Editing and deleting a sent message is now available on LinkedIn Messenger.  See video below to see it in action (more fun with sound).On desktop, simply mouse over a specific message you recently sent and select Edit or Delete from the menu.  On mobile, look for these options in the menu by long pressing a specific message. Send with confidence knowing that you can fix your mistakes.This is one of a number of new features that are rolling out now to help you have more productive conversations.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: From #opentowork to #getthisworkTwo weeks ago, LinkedIn & Emmanuel Acho went out of their way to help me find employment after I lost my job due to COVID. So many people reposted his message to help, even the CEO of LinkedIn Ryan Roslansky reposted. From all this, I was introduced to a guy name Shelton Banks who runs a non-profit called re:work training that has a mission of getting people of color, overlooked talent they call it, jobs in tech in 8 weeks. They didn't lie! I got plugged into the network and 3 weeks later I am now grateful to be removing #OpentoWork I am appreciative and thankful to everyone who has been rooting for me. Big thanks to guys like Emmanuel Acho and Shelton Banks who lookout for people like me.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: From #opentowork to #getthisworkTwo weeks ago, LinkedIn & Emmanuel Acho went out of their way to help me find employment after I lost my job due to COVID. So many people reposted his message to help, even the CEO of LinkedIn Ryan Roslansky reposted. From all this, I was introduced to a guy name Shelton Banks who runs a non-profit called re:work training that has a mission of getting people of color, overlooked talent they call it, jobs in tech in 8 weeks. They didn't lie! I got plugged into the network and 3 weeks later I am now grateful to be removing #OpentoWork I am appreciative and thankful to everyone who has been rooting for me. Big thanks to guys like Emmanuel Acho and Shelton Banks who lookout for people like me.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: September 28 marked the end of my proverbial “First 90 Days” as The Wharton School dean – a Zoom-filled first 90 days like no other. I took time to reflect on what’s transpired since my appointment and the #leadership lessons I’ve learned thus far: 1. Embrace the concept of “swift trust”2. Ask questions to inform your priorities3. Find people who energize you & seek out time with them4. "Wag the tail" i.e. lead the leaders

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: September 28 marked the end of my proverbial “First 90 Days” as The Wharton School dean – a Zoom-filled first 90 days like no other. I took time to reflect on what’s transpired since my appointment and the #leadership lessons I’ve learned thus far: 1. Embrace the concept of “swift trust”2. Ask questions to inform your priorities3. Find people who energize you & seek out time with them4. "Wag the tail" i.e. lead the leaders

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: This is our LinkedIn Learning Challenge week. So far I attended our first ever virtual Global Talent Organization Symposium with 650 of my best friends where I learned some great dance moves from Rouble Singh and Nawal Fakhoury, I listened to two fabulous and insightful speakers, Sumun L. Pendakur, Ed.D. on our individual ability to advance diversity and inclusion and AJ Sarcione on how we must find our own shine before we can help others shine. I did a refresh on Jeff Weiner's On Leadership course and completed our own Rob Garrott's course on Video Production and Editing, while also finishing a Screenwriting Course, all in pursuit of learning more about film making. And lastly, I learned a new recipe from my friend Michael Susi, who shared his delicious Lemon Caper Chicken. And it is only Wednesday. Whew! #alwaybelearning #LinkedInGTO #lilChallenge

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I had a pretty fun chat with Bill Gates last week. Think he'd land the job? 😂 #StateOfInspiration

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: 2020 has undoubtedly stressed us out at home and in the workplace — whether virtual or in-person. Next week, Ginger CEO, Russell Glass will host a discussion with Peter Majeranowski of Tyton BioSciences, Pat Wadors of ServiceNow, Jane van Dis, MD of Maven Clinic and Seth Blackley of Evolent Health to explore how leaders are managing election-related stress in the workplace, how they're encouraging civic engagement, and their plans to provide support long after election day. Register today to join us: https://lnkd.in/dHVWx8D #mentalhealth #election2020 #electionstress #behavioralhealth #workplacewellbeing #workplacementalhealth

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Learning > Education.  We are at an important inflection point. This won’t just be a lost school year, but a lost school decade.  While the “K economy” widens the gap between rich and poor, we are also seeing a “K education” where families with means can ensure their kids keep learning while those families less fortunate are seeing their kids fall behind. Now is the time for us to ensure kids learn 21st century skills.  Now is the time to expand learning from the classroom into the living room.  We must help our kids become lifelong learners. Thank you Stephanie Mehta, Jill Bernstein & team Fast Company for the opportunity to represent Encantos and serve on Fast Company’s Impact Council and share my perspective on the future of education.  #Edtech #21stcenturyskills #learnfromhome

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: After a year-long journey of self-discovery, I'm so excited to announce the rebrand of Brex, and how we plan on helping every growing company realize their full potential. Thanks to our amazing team that made this happen!https://lnkd.in/dKcXW5z

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: After a year-long journey of self-discovery, I'm so excited to announce the rebrand of Brex, and how we plan on helping every growing company realize their full potential. Thanks to our amazing team that made this happen!https://lnkd.in/dKcXW5z

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: This is one of best leadership courses I have ever attended, Thanks! Jeff Weiner. It’s a complete package of real life scenarios, proven principles, and most importantly enchanting executive presence. I highly recommend this course.Here are a few things that stood out to me.  1) Be mindful, a spectator of your own thoughts.2) Listen with an intent to understand, speak with an intent to be understood.3) Loved the “opinion, suggestion, mandate” framework.4) Strategy - Don’t play the game by somebody else’s rules, beat the competition by being yourself.5) Inspire excellence (demanding is easy but difficult to achieve in the long run).6) More is harder when it comes to focusing and scaling organizations.7) Strongly establish the bull’s eye before venturing into other growth areas.8) Strike the right balance between overcommunication and communication overload.9) Understand and use the power of ‘d’ in RAPIDs to empower your teams not to micromanage.10) Buffer to Brainstorm — use unscheduled times to think and connect the dots.11) Start with what inspires you.12) It’s all about your energy — this course was a perfect example of high passion delivered.#leadership https://lnkd.in/g2reVmK

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I am excited to lead the Headspace Inc. organization at such an important time in its history. It is a dream to wake up each day and work with such an amazing team that persists in delivering health and happiness to the world!#headspace #mindfulliving #curiousminds #courageousheart #selflessdrive
