Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Two years ago today, I started at LinkedIn. My son was four days old, having arrived much earlier than anticipated. I left him with my wife to come in for orientation, and I will admit to being more than a little nervous. I was starting a new job in a new industry with colleagues I mostly didn't know well. 732 days later, I have discovered the most creatively and intellectually satisfying chapter of my career. It's an honor to work among entrepreneurial, visionary journalists deeply committed to bringing members the news and views that will drive their professional lives forward. And yes, I am still counting my time here in days because it still feels as though I've just arrived; as much as we've created in these past two years, the most interesting challenges are just ahead of us.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Today the team at Inventables launched a new product called the X-Carve Pro along with updates to our Easel Pro software and upgrades to our support.  This ~3 min video gives the highlights https://lnkd.in/gyZr_H4 #launchday #startups

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: It’s no surprise that a survey of 11,000 teenagers has found that 38% are more worried about their mental health now than they were before the pandemic. We must assume that every child has been affected in some way by COVID and teachers across the country are finding that they need to put in place a plan for all children and personalised plans for those who are most deeply affected.At EVERFI EdComs, we believe that those plans should include the teaching of compassion, which is why we have launched a 45-minute course free to all UK primary schools called The Compassion Project.It is designed for seven to 11-year-olds and was originally the brainchild of Jeff Weiner, LinkedIn’s Chairman, who says: “I’m not sure that I can think of anything more important than teaching compassion. The benefits are myriad in terms of … improving [children’s] sense of self, their self-esteem and the way they relate to others.”If you or your organisation is interested in supporting the teaching of compassion in primary schools across the UK, we’d love to hear from you. Please contact us here and we’ll be in touch.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I had never heard the definition of trust as consistency over time before work with Jeff Weiner, but saw it prove out time after time. And Rachel Botsman's post today was another helpful reminder.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Overdue Life Update: I became a first-generation Latino college graduate! For those of you that don’t know, I have a low-income Mexican immigrant background. Only 13% of Chicago Public Schools Latino high school males are projected to obtain a bachelor’s degree within 10 years. I beat the odds and graduated from a top ten university. 🎓I’m grateful for my familia that supported my dreams and for always being there when I needed a ride from school or a home cooked meal. I’m thankful for professors that encouraged my ambitions and even those that didn’t; both helped build my resilience and aptitude to learn. Thank you to my previous supervisors that granted me opportunities to grow. Thank you to my team at McDonald's for seeing my potential. You all believed in me, let me work while in school and have continued to open doors for me to prosper. Gracias to the Latinx community at Northwestern University, MSA, SES, and my peers for fostering inclusive spaces for me the past four years. I’m 2 months into my full time role as an HR Specialist on the US People Alignment team at McD. Looking forward to growing as a servant leader, continuing to champion DEI, and giving back to my community. Si se pudo, y todavía falta!  #newrole #grateful #FGLI #Latinx

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Excited for my new position on the BAWSI team.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: My Alladapt co-founder, Dr Kari Nadeau, is not only a leader in food allergy and the inventor of our lead compound, but she is using her expertise in immune function to lead very impactful CV19 research at Stanford. So inspired to work so closely with her.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Helping those impacted by COVID get the skills they need to land their next job has been a big focus for us in 2020. Across LinkedIn so many folks on our teams have worked to give our members and customers the resources and support they need to navigate and emerge from the pandemic -- through our COVID Resource hub, Recruiting for good, and coverage by our editorial team. And just this week our CEO Ryan Roslansky shared how we've reached 10 million learners through our global skilling initiative with Microsoft. Having LinkedIn's efforts recognized is a great way to end the week and I’m excited to share that the 2020 Stevie Awards did just that with a Gold Stevie for “Most Valuable Corporate Response to COVID.”  Big congratulations and thank yous to our amazing team of dedicated pros who've done the work, including Meg Garlinghouse Monica Lewis Daniel Roth Melissa Selcher and so many more.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: This global crisis has taken most of us out of our element, so it’s important to take time to care for your mind and incorporate mindful moments throughout the day. As we allow more fluidity between work and our personal life, we can’t ignore that we have to prioritize mental health both at home and at work. That's why I'm thrilled that Microsoft is helping to bring Headspace Inc. experiences into Microsoft Teams. #mindfulnessatwork #employees #headspace #microsoftteams #futureofwork

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: This global crisis has taken most of us out of our element, so it’s important to take time to care for your mind and incorporate mindful moments throughout the day. Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: For almost a year, I looked for employment; I am beyond words glad I found it. While the emotions are still fresh, I want to highlight how deeply wonderful LinkedIn was during this time. When COVID began, I would daily tune in to LinkedIn LIVE to learn and connect with people. I cannot more highly recommend Andrew Seaman's videos. The guests he has on do an amazing job of being engaging and navigating best practices in resumes, interviewing, and hiring. What stands out the most though is the incomparable community, I found online. I am so deeply grateful for everyone I have connected with this past year. Sometimes it led to interviews, other times it was just lament or encouragement. Special thanks to all the people, I sent messages to, to learn more about your work and the connections I made on LinkedIn LIVES. LinkedIn is a wonderful professional platform, and I just want to encourage people to use it for all it is worth. Alright have a great Friday and thank you for coming to my Ted Talk.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I'm proud to share an update on our efforts to help those impacted by COVID get the skills they need to land their next job.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: After 25 years of interviewing candidates, I’ve come to appreciate one quality above most others—a talent for understanding how one is perceived by others. Call it self-awareness, detachment, having a clue, whatever— it’s so underrated a requirement for getting things done.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I’m excited to recognize an integral member of our team at PayPal, Sabrina Flores. Sabrina directly supports me as an Executive Support Technician, and I can say firsthand from work with her that she is fantastic. Sabrina originally joined us through our partnership with Year Up, a nonprofit that empowers young people with professional skills and is a recent recipient of one of PayPal’s grants to nonprofits that are supporting underserved youth in San Jose. After her one-year program with Year Up ended, she stayed with us permanently, now helping to keep our executive team running smoothly and ensure we’re set up for success. She’s said that this is her favorite part of the job: “Being equipped at the forefront of technology to help the senior leadership team continue their workflow without feeling the tug and pull of technological changes.”  Sabrina is also a member of Aliados, our Employee Resource Group for Latinx employees and allies that is leading the kick-off of PayPal’s Latinx Heritage Month celebrations. I’m also happy to say that outside of work, Sabrina purposely detaches from the technology of her day job and enjoys hiking, painting, and photography. Thanks to Sabrina for her years of work at PayPal, and to Year Up for helping us find such great talent.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Excited about Ginger's first TV commercial airing this week on the major business networks! Full version here: https://lnkd.in/dAkub6s

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I haven’t reinvented myself yet during this pandemic LOL... but I’ve certainly reflected on the power of compassion and vulnerability as key leadership treat. I hope this sticks after all this passes as powerful learning for business.I took a great LinkedIn leadership course by Jeff Weiner where he discussed how culture cannot be demanded and values have to be inspired. I listened to a podcast where Brené Brown talked about how being vulnerable is crucial for innovation. People must have permission to fail without losing their trust.And, as said in this article, ”Creating an environment where there is fear, anxiety, and lack of trust makes people shut down”. ”Compassion and curiosity increase loyalty and trust”.I’ve failed some times in the past on this. I've let my negative emotions about work get in the way of team relationships. I truly apologize!I promise to take these learnings in my pocket from now on.  #leadership #executiveleadership #culture #innovation

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: On the morning of our first presidential debate here in the U.S., many of us are feeling a range of emotions: fear, hope, angst, curiosity. Not related, today at LinkedIn, we started the day with Darren Walker in our latest Speaker Series. Darren shared a message of optimism, action and understanding our privilege. There were so many gems of wisdom in the conversation, but one feels quite timely: "Out of all of our identities we hold, our number one identity is American. 'We the people' applies to us all." I hope that we see some of that thinking tonight from both candidates so we can heal and move forward. Thankful for LinkedIn's commitment to bringing in amazing speakers who touch your heart and allow you to bring what's happening outside in the world to your desk because let's face it: the world doesn't stop once you open your work laptop and sit down to work for the day. We carry the burdens of the world with us. I left this conversation feeling a true sense of hope and inspiration. Will I feel like that at 8:30 PM? Who knows, but in this moment, I'm grateful and starting the work day with that mindset. Thanks, Rachelle Diamond, for making this happen and thank you, Karin Kimbrough for an excellent conversation on so many important topics. #LinkedInSpeakerSeries

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Interacting with social media and online communities is a daily occurrence for me (spoiler: if you're reading this, it's prob you, too). Ideally, it should always be safe and respectful. And if it's not, the platform should take steps to protect you and give you tools to create the best possible experience. Big shout out to Liz who shares more on how we're doing that here at LinkedIn.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: How would you feel when your talent would have a direct impact on millions of lives' livelihood, building a product that will empower them with trade skills to support their families and local communities worldwide? We are hiring Nana's first Product Manager, who will work directly with Oliver Nicholas, Callie Bladow, and me.You will be mentored by some of the best product people in the world. Among your mentors: Josh Elman, Curtis Chambers, Bob Lee, Allen Penn, Ryan McKillen, Adam Sah, Matt Sweeney, Stephen Chau, Kevin Novak, Shaan Puri, and other word-class product builders who are joining the Nana journey. We are building a company that cares for:- Education - equipping people who have lost their jobs with trade skills.- Community - surrounding them with people who have gone down the same career path.- Mentorship - providing access to ongoing education and data-driven feedback for continual growth.- Sustainable income opportunity - a marketplace to connect tradespeople with jobs to put their new skills to work!We are looking for self-driven individuals that are passionate about the impact of workforce development. #productmanager https://lnkd.in/ggiM47Rhttps://lnkd.in/gi2DgRM

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: A very big thank you to every LinkedIn employee for helping secure this recognition from Business Insider Intelligence as the most trusted social platform for the fourth year running. To every LinkedIn member: Our work continues every day to remain worthy of your trust.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Thank you, Jeff Weiner and LinkedIn  for making the #OnLeadership course freely available for your members. This is the best 3 hour 9 minute investment on my personal and professional growth that I have put in this year. My 3 key takeaways [the power of three!] are: - It's not just the what; it’s also the *how*- Find the balance between: presentation & discussion, patience & tension, strategy & tactics, problem solving & coaching - Repeat, repeat, repeat!My favourite part of the course is that it highlights the importance of Authenticity and Belonging, and shines a light on Covering at all levels Make time to watch the course - https://lnkd.in/gjxujzr and read the book: Covering by Kenji Yoshino - https://lnkd.in/gwHDuyz#organizationalleadership #covering #onlinelearning #alwaysbelearning

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I remember seeing an ad once with an impactful tagline “Trust is a one time gift”.  And Jeff Weiner encourages us to remember that consistency over time builds trust. There’s no better way to walk-the-talk than to be the most trusted platform for the 4th consecutive year, in today’s rather cluttered social media space.https://lnkd.in/g-XSEWg #trust #socialmedia LinkedIn Business Insider

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Last week, I was honored to receive the Global Leadership award at LinkedIn's annual Sales Kickoff. If you know me, you know I generally like to fly under the radar, but I wanted to express my deep gratitude for this incredible honor. Navigating this past year has been challenging for all of us, but these people have been instrumental in my growth and development. Catherine, this is as much your award as it is mine. When I grow up, I want to be just like you. Alyssa, Julie, Jonathan, Mike, Jeff, LaRon, Peter, Steve, David, and Ryan, you've shown me that true leaders are both courageous and kind. You set the bar and continue to raise it.  My team: Alejandra, Sandy, Veronica, Janesh, Ryan, August, and Nelson -- you bring out the best in me everyday. Cali-Alliance for life. Right now, the fight for justice in our country may feel like trying to boil the ocean, but I encourage everyone to be open-minded, brave, and like my late Father Paul Graves, thoughtful. Let's take it one day at a time. Peace and blessings to all of you. KG

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Eight months ago, I met a fellow passenger on a flight. We chatted and I learned about their professional interests. I subsequently made an introduction to another person in my network who was hiring, and eventually this person got the job.Today I received the following thank you and follow up:“I just had my 90 day review and I am in love with this company and the people I have the pleasure to work with..I knew I wanted to make a different impact in people’s lives..but never knew where I could fit in. I have found my perfect place..thank you for everything. Truly a life-changing experience.”This note made my day and reminded me of the power of sharing with your network, helping connect people for mutual benefit, and expressing your gratitude and thanks.#feedyournetwork #gratitude #followupwhensomeonehelpsyou

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Have you noticed a rise in friends or colleagues who are abruptly moving out of big cities?Dealing with the COVID pandemic is changing a lot of our habits -- and for some people, that includes a big-time change of address. Fresh data from LinkedIn's Economic Graph team shows that San Francisco and New York, in particular, are seeing a lot more outflows than inflows this year.Where's everyone going? A lot of the movement is toward suburbs and smaller cities, where the cost of living is lower, and the amount of available space is larger. That's especially helpful for people whose homes have also become their offices and their children's makeshift schools.If you've made such a move -- or are considering one -- come join the conversation in our comments section#WorkforceReport #parentinginapandemic #relocation #movingtips

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: While the holidays may look different this year, many companies like Walmart, FedEx and Macy's are still ramping up seasonal hiring. Good Morning America dives more into who's hiring and what type of roles they're looking for. CC: Taylor Dunn Rebecca Jarvis Andrew Seaman #GetHired

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Very proud of the LinkedIn team as today we’re starting to roll out our first major redesign in five years. The redesign includes a more modern look & feel, Stories, a new search experience and new features in messaging.  But more importantly it gives us a strong foundation on which to continue building new features to help the community connect to opportunity. You can see more in the video below from our head of design, Sarah Alpern (she/her), or check out this post for more details: https://lnkd.in/d55PVkC

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I couldn’t be more excited to see our new LinkedIn experience start to roll out to members today. We've redesigned our desktop and mobile products from the ground up to make your LinkedIn experience more modern, intuitive, inclusive, and enjoyable -- with your valuable professional community in the front. In addition, we've rebuilt our search experience so now everything on LinkedIn (e.g. people, posts, jobs, pages, courses, events) is easier than ever to find. We’re also adding Stories and new messaging enhancements so that everyone can creatively express themselves and bring the casual office conversations we used to be able to have in-person back to life. A lot of goodness is packed in this launch and I am proud of all the work our team has done to bring it to life. I am excited for all of you to discover it!

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: At the start of the Sales Kickoff week my Manager and Rockstar Sneha Gupta asked us to take this week to focus & invest in ourselves - and I can say I did! I completed perhaps the most engaging piece of online learning I have ever attended - On Leadership by Jeff Weiner. Strongly recommend :).....#linkedin #LiL #learning

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: 2 years ago today, a 2-min chat with Jeff Weiner (Ex-CEO & Present Executive Chairman of LinkedIn) changed my life!In these last 2 years, I have:• Shared 600+ posts on LinkedIn• Received 1000s of leads and worked with 200+ clients across continents• Won funding for my startup• Released my first ebook #Anthology to rave reviews• Been a speaker for 30+ webinars and given 100+ live sessions/ interviews• Started providing high value content on Instagram, Twitter, YouTube and my website My point is...Every single opportunity can drastically change your life.Be tenacious and thankful for blessings you receive. Identify opportunities,Show up,And make the most of them.Magical things happen when we show up! ✨What one thing changed your life? #ShreyaWritesPS: Thanks to Jeff Weiner for the 2-min chat. Thanks to LinkedIn for the amazing community. Thanks to YOU for supporting my content ❤️#content #writer #contentwriter

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Nobody would hire me. Nobody would even give me a chance.I was frustrated. As a young husband and father of 2 daughters, I felt the weight of my responsibility. I wanted to give my kids experiences I never had. I wanted to go on family vacations. Take them to Disneyland. Hawaii. I wanted to give them the best life I could give them. Interview after interview. Nobody would hire me because I didn’t have a bachelor's degree. I was delivering newspapers in the morning, then going to my office assistant job, also trying to go to college part-time at night. Finally, I made a choice. If they wouldn't hire me, I would hire me. I started my own software consulting company, TrueDev Technologies. Running that company for almost 6 years taught me lessons no employer could ever teach me. It propelled my skill level and my value. Since then I've worked at senior levels at Microsoft, Expedia, and Salesforce. Now with 4 beautiful daughters and an amazing wife, things are good. My kids have been to Disneyland twice and Hawaii :) Don't let rejection stop you. Don't let rejection define you. Let it refine you.💡 Follow me for daily advice, real stories, and encouragement. #motivation #jobsearch #neverquit #grit #mentormesh #network #interviewing

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Even in a tough economy, all of the #LinkedInTopStartups are hiring and growing, LinkedIn News Senior Editor at Large Jessi Hempel tells Bloomberg News. Check out the segment for more on key trends we're seeing in this year's list, how companies are attracting talent and how they are approaching remote work during the pandemic.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Jeff Weiner says compassion is empathy plus action.This definition is one I love and use daily. It forces me to be a great listener while also being a great problem solver.However, it’s a completely different story when we try to be self-compassionate.That’s hard work.It’s something I’ve struggled with for a long time. I hold myself to a high standard, and when I feel as if that high standard isn’t met, I judge and ridicule myself. Once I get going, it’s hard to snap out of that line of thinking. I don’t do this all the time, but growing up this was my default response to failure.It takes a lot of work to be self-compassionate. I try to get better at it every day, but I still have a ways to go. Sometimes my fiancé catches me disparaging myself and she shouts out, “Hey! Stop that! That’s my fiancé you’re talking about!” It’s always a funny moment, but it helps snap me out of a downward and harmful spiral. She wouldn’t let someone else talk about me the way I was talking about me… so why should she tolerate it from me?Being self-compassionate means being forgiving and optimistic. It's about training yourself to see yourself as a friend.My full thoughts in this week's Gridology:

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: People all over the world are spending more time work and plugged in than ever before. That’s why it’s so important to incorporate #mindful routines throughout our days to keep ourselves healthy and well. I’m thrilled to announce that we’re work with Microsoft to bring #mindfulness experiences into Microsoft Teams. How do you practice staying present and mindful throughout your workday?#mentalhealth #headspace #microsoftteams

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Why I Changed my LinkedIn Profile PicRecently, I took a long hard look at my LinkedIn profile photo – the woman staring back at me had newly highlighted hair and a fresh cut, a pressed blazer, a hint of a smile that showed just the right amount of teeth to let you know she was serious but could be lighthearted when needed. I remember standing in my power pose as my husband snapped the photos. We poured through about 80 shots before we found the one that looked perfectly polished. But the person I was exuding then is not always who I am, and certainly, not who I am right now.  Today’s remote world has blurred the lines between my professional and personal selves, so I’ve chosen to represent that in my photo. Barely dried hair, comfy pullover, ripped jeans - slightly frazzled from having just gotten 3 kids ready for "school" - but smiling and ready for work.I’ve witnessed and read enough on authentic leadership to know that being genuine and vulnerable will get you a lot farther in your career than a glossy headshot.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: After 3 years and 2 months, today is my last day serving in student government at Yale University! I am extremely proud of the impact I have made as Yale’s first Black Student Body President, and I will do everything it takes to inspire and support our next generation of diverse leaders.You can read about all we accomplished here (https://lnkd.in/danqStD)

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Super interesting read on the differences between empathy and compassion. There’s a dark side to empathy?  Thanks @Rasmus#compassion

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: “Those that critized me, soon started to commend me”I’m stunned at the impact Students of LinkedIn has made. A hashtag that I started with the sole purpose of encouraging students to showcase their story, turned into an online community of almost 5,000 followers. The discouragement and questions in the first few months, almost stopped me from creating/sharing. It was a rough start; I felt out of place to be sharing my story with the professional world, but I'm grateful that I started while I was uncertain/unqualified/young/inexperienced. I have learned so much and I am still learning.If there's something that you really want to do: Trust yourself and deliver. To the leadership team I know here at LinkedIn: Jeff, Erica, Tyrona, Peter, Amy, Maya, Margaret, thank you, for all that you do. You are collectively and individually creating impact amongst the #studentsoflinkedin.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: It is a privilege.Exactly 10 years ago today, I made the best decision of my professional life, and joined LinkedIn.  In 2010, LinkedIn was often misunderstood as the “Lincoln” car dealership (by many people but esp my dad who has finally figured out the difference).  In other words, it was less of an obvious choice.  But what was obvious back then and still now, is the company is deeply rooted in a set of values that have guided the people it hires, the culture it nurtures and the millions of small and big business decisions we make every day. And while I did feel very privileged to join the company 10 years ago, every day since this feeling has become more pronounced for two reasons:My job.  I cannot imagine a job that more perfectly aligns with my personal values and what matters most in the world: ensuring that two people with equal talent have equal access to opportunity. My colleagues.  I cannot emphasize this enough. I have never worked with a group of people who have such clarity of conviction of why they wake up every day – and are driven to ensure that we live up to realizing our bold vision to create economic opportunity for every member of the globalworkforce.  Thanks @LinkedIn. It is truly a privilege. Big nod to @Blake Lawit also celebrating 10)

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Are you a leader? aspire to be a leader? or keen to understand leadership?"On Leadership" by Jeff Weiner from this weekend Structured, usefull and to the point course without extra jargon: 1) Awareness 2) Synthesis and 3) Inspiration.To learn about the incredible takeways from this  course, suggest spend 3 hours on it. Few of my takeaways: 1. Compassion is not conditional 2. Managers tell people what to do, leaders inspire 3. Know what you want to accomplish 4. Listen with intent to understand and speak with intent to be understood. 5. People do thier best when they know they are appreciated. 6. Objectives must be measurable 7. 'How' is also important as 'WHAT' 8. Tactics and strategy are not the same 9. Importance of clarity of vision and being authentic 10. Understand consequence of casual feedback. 11. Be spectator of your own thoughts 12. If your calendar is always busy, you are not doing the job.#Leadership #learning

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: 🚩 How To Improve Leadership 🚩FULL SLIDE SET NOW AVAILABLE:https://lnkd.in/dwn793JDuring Jeff Weiner tenure as the CEO at LinkedIn, the company grew its membership base from 33 million to more than 690 million members, increased its revenue from $78 million to more than $7.9 billion, and expanded its team from 338 to over 16,000 employees. Throughout this period of remarkable growth, Jeff developed the company's values and created an organization where compassion is as revered as a healthy bottom line. In this course, Jeff shares his advice on what it takes to be a great leader, using a three-part framework of awareness, synthesis, and inspiration.Learn about the importance of maintaining awareness of yourself, your team, your industry, and the world at large. Explore the topic of synthesis, which you achieve through developing your vision and values and by focusing on the most important priorities. Plus, learn about the role of inspiration in leadership, both in terms of being true to your own values and motivating others.#Leadership #awareness #inspiration

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: In 2017, this was my version of the #OpenToWork post. I did not see people make public posts about their job search. I wanted to try something different than slide into a recruiters DMs.Initially, it had 72 likes. Joy was one of them, she reached out to see where she could help. I’m so happy I met her & we are friends till this day. We did a #LinkedInLive earlier this year, link in comments.I recall wanting to delete the post. I started feeling out of place. No one was doing this publicly. People were posting successes & here I was.Then, Jeff engaged & the post went viral. This brought employers, recruiters, supporters, prayer warriors etc.Three months later I landed an internship.#Microsoft folks viewed the post most, my internship was w/ Microsoft & 3 years later I work at Microsoft full time.Why I post this?When you see an #OpenToWork or #jobsearch post, do not pass it by - engage. It really helps.Ryan told me, “#OpenToWork - to harness the power of the community to connect talent with opportunity. There has never been a more important time to help your community.” Joy, Jeff & thousand others engaged with my post & supported me & still do till this day. That’s why I do the same for others. I am, because we are.Lift as you climb. #theBOLDjourney #ubuntu

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I am a curious learner, carve a few hours every week to learn on #aiforeveryone #hyperautomation #rpaimplementation #emergingtechnologies & #leadershipexcellence. Today I had the privilege to experience Incredible, Inspiring, and Phenomenal leadership insights through “On Leadership By Jeff Weiner”. There were so many fantastic takeaways into my personal and professional leadership skills and approach. Want to share a few of them· Rules of 3’s – Awareness, Synthesis, Inspiration· Leadership – The ability to inspire others to achieve shared objectives· Compassion = Empathy + Action; Compassion is not conditional· Most valuable people - People that dream big, get it done and know how to care for one another· FoCuS – Fewer things are done better. Keep things simple. Communicate the right information to the right people at the right time. Speed and quality of decision making· Time management – Schedule buffer time to THINK/Reflect· Inspire – Clarity of your vision, the courage of your convictions and effectively communicate through authenticity, transparency, repetition· Effective speaking - Know your audience, know your material, and know your passion. Find your inner Rockstar. #leadershipdevelopment #inspiration #collectivewisdom #compassionateleadership #TheArtOfHappiness

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: In the past few days, I was able to carve a few hours to complete the phenomenal LinkedIn course “On Leadership by Jeff Weiner“. I simply loved it and couldn't recommend it more to anyone at any stage of your career. The 3 hours will fly, as you watch Jeff breaking effective leadership into 3 pillars:- Awareness: 	know yourself, your team, your company at a macro and micro level;- Synthesis: 	translate the vision into values, FoCuS (Fewer things done better, Communication, Speed) and tools for assertive execution;Inspiration:	how to inspire others to achieve shared objectives, effective communication and effective public-speaking;As we go back to basics, to lean management, Jeff’s discussion question “what are the key measures you track to evaluate your team’s performance and how do you track them?” is, to me, a great allusion to Daily Management Systems (DMS) and the power of data, since you can’t improve what you don’t measure.I’d say Jeff Weiner has indeed acted on his beliefs and is transforming the education system. “On Leadership” is one of the best leadership trainings I’ve had.Thanks for putting this together, Jeff. #leadership #inspiration

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: We lost a giant last night. Ruth Bader Ginsberg advanced women’s rights through both her legal decisions and her personal path. And she showed us how to live in these fractured times, able to bridge conflict in the workplace and forge relationships — without veering from your true north. This article she wrote in 2016 is short and illuminating about how she did, well, everything: “Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s Advice for Living” https://lnkd.in/eap9dwcAnd she practiced what she preached. The top comment on the story is from a woman who, as a young law school student, had her entire career launched thanks to the actions of RBG — a stranger to her. It’s the Jewish New Year today and I’m committing this year to live more like RBG: a little deaf (read the article) and a lot more giving.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I finished this insightful course but never-ending watch it. First time it was because  I wanted to see what can I learn there. After that time I started rewinding each chapter and I can tell you I have not heard this in that way.Many basic concepts we thought we know but we must remember and reflect. Those concepts we need both in our professional and personal life. I really enjoyed it and now sharing with you! I recommend you to do this course."If you're scheduling every minute of every day, you're not doing your job."' Jeff Weiner "Believe in your vision with every fiber of your being."' Jeff Weiner #Leadership #Learning Roméo Arsène BANZOUZI NSANA, Phina WANDO-SEMEDO, Eriel Chancy BAMOUANGA, Terence BERKIBARE,

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I just finished watching "On Leadership" by Jeff Weiner, and all I can say is WOW.There were so many incredible takeaways that I could write for days on the insights this has given me into my personal and professional leadership skills and tactics. Just a few:"Compassion is not conditional.""If you've scheduled every minute of every day, you're not doing your job.""Believe in your vision with every fiber of your being.""It's not just the what. It's the how.""Any time you have to cover who you are, it's going to impede your ability to effectively communicate."Like I said, WOW. Thanks for all of the knowledge and experience, Jeff. It is going to help me to become a rockstar leader. #leadership #success #motivation #leader #leadershipdevelopment #entrepreneur #smallbusiness

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: When you see someone’s “#jobsearch” or “#opentowork” post - please don’t just pass it by.Comment, like, share - do something to boost engagement. Help them out. Because if we could all do that for one another, it’d make the job search space a little less strenuous.You never know, their new employer could be in your connections/followers.PS: if you’re open to work/#jobsearching and have a post, drop the link in comments below so I, and others can like/comment on your posts to boost engagement.🌻💜 #theBOLDjourney

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: ONCE UPON A LINKEDIN GHOST VS. 500+ CONNECTIONSWhen I first joined LinkedIn in 2016, I easily morphed into a ghost. Like every greenhorn, I'd started to build a profile only to quit after a few unenlightened attempts, flat out dispirited by the "rigours" of clinching an all-star profile. I also committed the biggest visibility gaffe ever by setting my profile to private mode.I was so scared of being seen, hamstrung by the prospect of falling short upon exposure to scrutiny. In my own eyes, I was no professional, had achieved nothing and had no business being here, pretending to be somebody I clearly was not. . . LinkedIn was for high-achievers and I definitely didn't fit my own interpretation of a high-achiever. At the time, I was just a law student in her 2nd year of Uni who didn't even own a CV! As you can imagine, I felt about as phoney as Prince Ali of Ababwa in Disney's Aladdin.But real magic happened the instant I decided to OWN my #process, to silence self-doubt and be more intentional about putting myself out more this year. So thank you Jeff Weiner for the unique platform.And cheers to all my 500+ LinkedIn connections. You're each enough assurance that I've made some right decisions. THANK YOU!!!-Taiwo#network #connections #linkedin #thankyou

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: This is a thrill! The San Francisco Press Club announced its 2020 awards today, and among the winners is this feature published on LinkedIn last November. https://lnkd.in/gk4RMAq It won first place in the digital media category for feature writing/serious nature.Feature writing? On LinkedIn? Yes indeed. With editor-in-chief Daniel Roth leading the way, we've got a strong (and growing!) team of journalists here, bringing everything from podcasts to news summaries and data-driven reporting into the mix. We want our news feed to be as useful, timely and inspiring as possible when you're spending time with us. This particular story wouldn't have happened if LinkedIn managers (and veterans!) Melissa Boatwright (she/her) and Sarah Roberts hadn't welcomed me into a rich series of conversations about how we could do more to address veterans' issues. I got a big assist, too, from Dana Hagist, Mark Corey and other data specialists here at LinkedIn. They proved how severe an issue veterans' under-employment has become.Most of all, former Army sergeant Ritchie Thomas welcomed me into his world -- and let me see, up close, how grit beats adversity. #veterans #journalism #military

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: Some kids at work created a word of encouragement for the Bay Area, my former home and still in my heart ❤️ #bayarea #oakland #sanfrancisco #siliconvalley https://lnkd.in/dvAT9Dc

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: I love this simple definition of what makes great leadership in today’s world:- awareness- synthesis- inspirationSpecial attention for synthesis here which is seldom mentioned as such when talking about leadership skills. Being continuously drowned in various information, having multiple triggers to handle and navigating in complex environments, it’s about the ability to separate the signals from the noise, to figure out what’s essential and to connect the dots rightly. Even if this isn’t about the chemical definition of synthesis, we can surely add emotional and relational chemistry as extra ingredients for good leadership! 🧪 Thanks for sharing such great (experience-based) insights Jeff Weiner 💡 #leadership #leadershipdevelopment #learning #futureofleadership #futureofwork #sharingiscaring

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: This leadership course by Jeff Weiner is so motivating that it is now required for our managers - for their own personal development, but also to hold us accountable. It is really cool that LinkedIn has shared access for free. If you're a manager, check it out.

Name: Jeff Weiner
Text: The unprecedented series of events in 2020 has the potential to do lasting harm to the social and emotional well-being of our young people if we don’t take proactive steps to equip them with the essential life skills they need, now and into adulthood. Primary schools provide a strong platform to teach these skills, and the private sector plays a vital role in supplying our educators with the resources to support them. In work with EVERFI to deliver The Compassion Project to classrooms throughout the country, we hope to teach students the meaning of compassion and develop a foundation for greater diversity, equity, and inclusion in the classroom and in life.Learn more about Everfi's $100M pledge to Answer the Call: https://lnkd.in/dAFze85Learn more about The Compassion Project: https://lnkd.in/dt2NJE7

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: No one is exempt from this process. Having it go well depends on people’s abilities to make frank assessments of strengths and weaknesses (most importantly weaknesses). While it’s generally as difficult for managers to give this feedback as it is for their subordinates to hear it, in the long run it makes people happier and the organization more successful. To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/ekEDGR4 #principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Being truthful with each other about our strengths and weaknesses so we can figure out how to deal with them well is the best way to get to where you want to go in life and to be comfortable with being who you are. You'll see in this week's Case of the Week a real case example of how such forthrightness can be tough at first, but makes people happier and more successful in the long run. Check it out in the free app, Principles In Action: https://lnkd.in/ekEDGR4#caseoftheweek

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: By knowing what is true, I mean knowing how reality works. People didn’t create the laws of nature that we have to live by in order to be successful, but if we can understand these laws we can use them to achieve our goals. This makes me a hyperrealist: someone who embraces reality and works with it well as it is—not someone who wishes it were different and complains that it is not to their liking.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/ekEDGR4#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: In the long run, it saves time by increasing efficiency, but it's important that you do it well. You will need to prioritize what you are going to get in sync about and who you are going to get in sync with because of time constraints. Your highest priority should be the most important issues with the most believable and most relevant parties. To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gpXzRwv #principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Having a hierarchy of merit is not only consistent with an idea meritocracy but essential for it. It’s simply not possible for everyone to debate everything all the time and still get their work done. Treating all people equally is more likely to lead away from truth than toward it. But at the same time, all views should be considered in an open-minded way, though placed in the proper context of the experiences and track records of the people expressing them. Imagine if a group of us were getting a lesson in how to play baseball from Babe Ruth, and someone who’d never played the game kept interrupting him to debate how to swing the bat. Would it be helpful or harmful to the group’s progress to ignore their different track records and experience? Of course it would be harmful and plain silly to treat their points of view equally, because they have different levels of believability. The most productive approach would be to allow Ruth to give his instructions uninterrupted and then take some time afterward to answer questions. To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gpXzRwv #principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: I know that my own life has been full of mistakes and lots of great feedback. It was only by looking down on this body of evidence from a higher level that I was able to get around my mistakes and go after what I wanted. For as long as I have been practicing this, I still know I can't see myself objectively, which is why I continue to rely so much on the input of others.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gpXzRwv#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: If you want to be followed, either for egotistical reasons or because you believe it more expedient to operate that way, you will pay a heavy price in the long run. When you are the only one thinking, the results will suﬀer. Authoritarian managers don’t develop their subordinates, which means those who report to them stay dependent. This hurts everyone in the long run. If you give too many orders, people will likely resent them, and when you aren’t looking, defy them. The greatest influence you can have over intelligent people—and the greatest influence they will have on you—comes from constantly getting in sync about what is true and what is best so that you all want the same things.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gpXzRwv #principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: As you know, both my own background and my study of history have led me to believe that the failure to provide equal opportunity is not only unjust but also a threat to our society's well-being. We each have our own values and approaches to this issue. To me, reducing disparities in education and healthcare are the most important steps to rectifying the equal opportunity gap and an important way for those who are blessed to help those who are suffering. It’s for this reason that my wife and I are so happy that Dalio Philanthropies is partnering with NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital to form a new Heath Justice Center, which will address health disparities and health justice through research, education, advocacy, and investment in communities.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: To partner with Ray Dalio and Dot Collector is a game changer! And this integration allows people to give and get real time feedback during a Zoom meeting.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: At Thrive Global, we use the Dot Collector from Ray Dalio's Principles to reinforce our top cultural value, Compassionate Directness, by offering transparent feedback in real-time. So I'm excited to see that Dot Collector will be joining Thrive Reset as a Zoom Zapp! As Thrive Global's Chief Training Officer Joe Hubbard often says: feedback is a data-point. And it's a crucial one that Dot Collector will help us give right from within a Zoom meeting. But if we find ourselves ruminating over some constructive feedback — we can course-correct before that stress becomes cumulative. #Zoomtopia

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: I did this research into the standings of great empires over time because I needed the understanding it gave me to navigate the current environment. You can read more about this in my series, The Changing World Order: https://lnkd.in/gGSd8sfIf you find this topic interesting, you can pre-order the book now on Amazon.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: If you've found yourself in back-to-back-to-back Zoom meetings, you know about virtual fatigue. That's why Thrive Global is teaming up with Zoom on the Thrive Reset Zapp. With personalized or pre-loaded guides, you can soon use the Thrive Reset Zapp at the beginning of a meeting to start out fresh, in the middle of a meeting to stay focused, or at the end to help you recenter before moving onto your next Zoom. And it only takes 60 seconds! Watch the video below to see how it will work and learn more here: https://lnkd.in/erHA7y3 #Zoomtopia#wfh #wfhtips #burnout #stressmanagement #mindfulness

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Excited to announce that Thrive Global has teamed up with Zoom to launch the Thrive Reset Zapp, the first app that helps us de-stress in real-time within Zoom meetings and prevent virtual fatigue in just 60 seconds using personalized or pre-loaded guides. #Zoomtopia https://lnkd.in/egwF6wm

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: In 2020, Zoom has become the new office. That's why we're bringing Reset, a key feature of Thrive Global's behavior change platform, to Zoom. The Thrive Reset Zapp helps us course-correct from stress before, during and after Zoom meetings — in only 60 seconds. My latest:  https://bit.ly/3753nQh #Zoomtopia

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: The Dot Collector is going to be made available for you to use on Zoom. For many years I relied on a tool called Dot Collector to allow everyone to hear from everyone in a meeting without interrupting each other, to have people give and get real time feedback, and to collect info to enhance people’s development plans, reviews, and job placements. Since I showed the Dot Collector in my TED Talk, people have been asking me to make it available to them and I have wanted to do that but I never had a good opportunity. Then the folks at Zoom asked me to make it available to enhance Zoom meetings. So today I'm happy to announce that the Dot Collector is going to be integrated with Zoom by year-end so everybody can use it in their Zoom meetings. We shared a picture of what it will be like at #Zoomtopia today along with great ideas from friends like Arianna Huffington and her company Thrive Global. You can learn more about the announcement here: https://lnkd.in/g__DCF7 and find the app here: https://zoom.us/zapps

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: If you hold opinions about people that are relevant to how they are measured and you don’t openly explore them it is both unethical and ineffective because everyone should have the right to confront their accuser, and you can’t be sure that you’re right so you need to stress test your view. Doing that will help you and them. Explore them openly with the goal of figuring out how you and your people are built so that the right people can be put in the right jobs.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gpXzRwv#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: In most organizations, evaluations run in only one direction, with the manager assessing the managee. The managee typically disagrees with the assessment, especially if it is worse than his or her self-assessment, because most people believe themselves to be better than they really are. Managees also have opinions about managers that they wouldn’t dare bring up in most companies, so misunderstandings and resentments fester. This perverse behavior undermines the effectiveness of the environment and the relationships between people. It can be avoided by getting in sync in a high-quality way. Your reports have to believe that you’re not their enemy—that your sole goal is to move toward the truth; that you are trying to help them and so will not enable their self-deception, perpetuate a lie, or let them off the hook. This has to be done in an honest and transparent way, because if someone believes they are being pigeonholed unfairly the process won’t work. As equal partners, it is up to both of you to get to the truth. When each party is an equal participant, no one can feel cornered.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gpXzRwv#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: I did this research into the standings of great empires over time because I needed the understanding it gave me to navigate the current environment. You can read more about this in my series, The Changing World Order: https://lnkd.in/gGSd8sfIf you find this topic interesting, you can pre-order the book now on Amazon.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Access to equal health care and equal education are fundamental requirements of a just society. I'm excited about this announcement from Dalio Philanthropies with NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital, which are equally committed to health justice.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: If you can work with great thinkers to get in synch about what you believe to be true and what to do about it in a way that most people agree is idea-meritocratic, you will have an optimally effective organization. This should be done non-hierarchically.  In this week's Case of the Week, you can see one of the many times that the team had critical feedback for me, which I shared with the whole company to encourage others to give and receive feedback without letting hierarchy get in the way. It is another example of one of the key principles in action that was part of my formula for creating a winning organization. You can find the case in the free app, Principles In Action: https://lnkd.in/gpXzRwv #caseoftheweek

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: For an organization to be effective, the people who make it up must be aligned on many levels—from what their shared mission is, to how they will treat each other, to a more practical picture of who will do what when to achieve their goals. Yet alignment can never be taken for granted because people are wired so differently. We all see ourselves and the world in our own unique ways, so deciding what’s true and what to do about it takes constant work.Alignment is especially important in an idea meritocracy, so at Bridgewater we try to attain alignment consciously, continually, and systematically. We call this process of finding alignment “getting in sync,” and there are two primary ways it can go wrong: cases resulting from simple misunderstandings and those stemming from fundamental disagreements. Getting in sync is the process of open-mindedly and assertively rectifying both types.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gpXzRwv#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: It helps to clarify whether the weakness or mistake under discussion is indicative of a trainee's total evaluation. One day I told one of our new research people what a good job I thought he was doing and how strong his thinking was. It was a very positive initial evaluation. A few days later I heard him chatting away at length about stuff that wasn't related to work, so I warned him about the cost to his and our development if he regularly wasted time. Afterward I learned that he thought he was on the brink of being fired. My comment about his need for focus had nothing to do with my overall evaluation. Had I explained myself better when we sat down that second time, he could have put my comment into perspective.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/g2uRih4#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Yet I see people doing it all the time, usually to avoid making others or themselves feel uncomfortable, which is not just backward but counterproductive. Putting comfort ahead of success produces worse results for everyone. I both loved the people I worked with and pushed them to be great, and I expected them to do the same with me. From the very beginning, I felt that the people I worked with at Bridgewater were a part of my extended family. When they or members of their families got sick, I put them in touch with my personal doctor to make sure that they were well taken care of. I invited all of them to stay at my house in Vermont on weekends and loved it when they took me up on it. I celebrated their marriages and the births of their children with them and mourned the losses of their loved ones. But to be clear, this was no lovefest. We were tough on each other too, so we could all be as great as we could be. I learned that the more caring we gave each other, the tougher we could be on each other, and the tougher we were on each other, the better we performed and the more rewards there were for us to share. This cycle was self-reinforcing.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/g2uRih4 #principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: What might seem kind but isn't accurate is harmful to the person and often to others in the organization as well.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/g2uRih4#principleoftheday

Text: I get many good questions that I answer on a daily basis on social media so I have been sharing the questions and answers in this format so you and others can see them all. Feel free to keep our conversation going about these and other principles here.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Because many people have had questions about my principles about managing a team during ambiguous times, I’m passing them along to you in one package. To get these principles and more check out the Coach tool in the free app, Principles in Action. If you search the type of situation you are facing in the tool, it will pull up the appropriate principles: https://lnkd.in/gC3ysym

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Nobody ever said radical honesty was easy. Sometimes, especially with new employees who have not yet gotten used to it, an honest assessment feels like an attack. Rise to a higher level and keep your eye on the bigger picture and counsel the person you are evaluating to do the same.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/g2uRih4#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Everyone has his or her own principles and values, so all relationships entail a certain amount of negotiation or debate over how people should be with each other. What you learn about each other will either draw you together or drive you apart. If your principles are aligned and you can work out your differences via a process of give-and-take, you will draw closer together. If not, you will move apart. Open discussion of differences ensures that there are no misunderstandings. If that doesn’t happen on an ongoing basis, gaps in perspective will widen until inevitably there is a major clash.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Everyone has his or her own principles and values, so all relationships entail a certain amount of negotiation or debate over how people should be with each other. What you learn about each other will either draw you together or drive you apart. If your principles are aligned and you can work out your differences via a process of give-and-take, you will draw closer together. If not, you will move apart. Open discussion of differences ensures that there are no misunderstandings. If that doesn’t happen on an ongoing basis, gaps in perspective will widen until inevitably there is a major clash.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: You've heard the expression “no pain no gain.” Psychologists have shown that the most powerful personal transformations come from experiencing the pain from mistakes that a person never wants to have again—known as “hitting bottom.” So don't be hesitant to give people those experiences or have them yourself. While it is important to be clear to people about what they are doing well, it is even more important to point out their weaknesses and have them reflect on them. Problems require more time than things that are going well. They must be identified and understood and addressed, while things that are running smoothly require less attention. Instead of celebrating how great we are, we focus on where we need to improve, which is how we got to be so great.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/g2uRih4#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Ray Dalio is very right on!

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: To give you an idea of what I mean by tough love, think of Vince Lombardi, who for me personiﬁed it. From when I was ten years old until I was eighteen, Lombardi was head coach of the Green Bay Packers. With limited resources, he led his team to ﬁve NFL championships. He won two NFL Coach of the Year awards and many still call him the best coach of all time. Lombardi loved his players and he pushed them to be great. I admired, and still admire, how uncompromising his standards were. His players, their fans, and he himself all beneﬁted from his approach. I wish Lombardi had written out his principles for me to read. To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Work is either 1) a job you do to earn the money to pay for the life you want to have or 2) what you do to achieve your mission, or some mix of the two. I urge you to make it as much 2) as possible, recognizing the value of 1). If you do that, most everything will go better than if you don’t.Which is most true for you? 1) or 2)? Or do you have a good mix of the two?To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Most training comes from doing and getting in sync about performance. Feedback should reflect what is succeeding and what is not in proportion to the actual situation, rather than in an attempt to balance compliments and criticisms. Remember that you are responsible for achieving your goals, and you want your machine to function as intended. For it to do so, the employees you supervise must meet expectations, and only you can help them understand whether they are stacking up. As their strengths and weaknesses become clearer, responsibilities can be more appropriately tailored to make the machine work better and to facilitate personal evolution.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/g2uRih4#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Accurate feedback, especially about mistakes and weaknesses, provided in a non-hierarchical way and openly shown is a powerful force for improvement and team building. It is also extremely rare, so it is a great path to gaining a big competitive advantage for those who can do it. I know that it was key to Bridgewater and I's success. This case will prompt you to reflect on whether you can provide it, receive it and show it, as well as to think about its consequences. Check it out in the free app Principles In Action: https://lnkd.in/g2uRih4#caseoftheweek

Text: You've heard the expression “no pain no gain.” Psychologists have shown that the most powerful personal transformations come from experiencing the pain from mistakes that a person never wants to have again—known as “hitting bottom.” So don't be hesitant to give people those experiences or have them yourself. Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Turnover is costly and inefficient because of the time it takes for people to get to know each other and the organization. Both the people you work with and the company itself will evolve in ways you can’t anticipate. So hire the kind of people you want to share a long-term mission with. You will always have uses for great people.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Everyone has his or her own principles and values, so all relationships entail a certain amount of negotiation or debate over how people should be with each other. What you learn about each other will either draw you together or drive you apart. If your principles are aligned and you can work out your differences via a process of give-and-take, you will draw closer together. If not, you will move apart. Open discussion of differences ensures that there are no misunderstandings. If that doesn’t happen on an ongoing basis, gaps in perspective will widen until inevitably there is a major clash.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: The most meaningful relationships are achieved when you and others can speak openly to each other about everything that's important, learn together, and understand the need to hold each other accountable to be as excellent as you can be. When you have such relationships with those you work with, you pull each other through challenging times; at the same time, sharing challenging work draws you closer and strengthens your relationships. This self-reinforcing cycle creates the success that allows you to pursue more and more ambitious goals.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Whatever success Bridgewater and I have had is because we have had an idea-meritocracy in which the goals have been meaningful work and meaningful relationships achieved through radical truthfulness and radical transparency. Don’t get me wrong - it’s not always easy to do this. In these cases of the week, you will see what it looks like in practice.⁣⁣Each year, we celebrate these relationships during a party for people who have been with the company for more than ten years. To get an inside look at this celebration, check out this week’s featured Case of the Week in the free Principles In Action app: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn#caseoftheweek

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Neuroscientists, psychologists, and evolutionists agree the human brain comes pre-programmed with the need for and enjoyment of social cooperation. Our brains want it and develop better when we have it. The meaningful relationships we get from social cooperation make us happier, healthier, and more productive; social cooperation is also integral to effective work. It is one of the defining characteristics of being human.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn#principleoftheday

Text: Work is either 1) a job you do to earn the money to pay for the life you want to have or 2) what you do to achieve your mission, or some mix of the two. Text: In case you missed it, the latest chapter of The Changing World Order series is about one of the most important issues at play in the world today: the ongoing conflicts between the US and China across a number of areas. How these conflicts are handled will have a huge effect on the future, not just for the two nations, but for the entire world order. You can read the latest installment here:

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Meaningful relationships are invaluable for building and sustaining a culture of excellence, because they create the trust and support that people need to push each other to do great things.To see this principle in action, check out this week’s Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gJpjJmn

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Most people ﬁght seeing what’s true when it’s not what they want it to be. That’s bad, because it is more important to understand and deal with the bad stuﬀ since the good stuﬀ will take care of itself.To see this principle in action, check out this week's Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gFAFE_F

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: You need to be clear in conveying your assessments to your reports and openminded in listening to their replies so you can work on setting their training and career paths together. Recognizing and communicating people's weaknesses is one of the most difficult things managers have to do. It's important for the party receiving feedback to be sympathetic to the person trying to give it, because it's not easy--it takes character on the part of both participants to get to the truth. #principleoftheday https://lnkd.in/gFAFE_F

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Worrying about “blame” and “credit” or “positive” and “negative” feedback impedes the iterative process that is essential to learning. Remember that what has already happened lies in the past and no longer matters except as a lesson for the future. The need for phony praise needs to be unlearned.To see this principle in action, check out the Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gFAFE_F

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Put your insecurities away and get on with achieving your goals. Reﬂect and remind yourself that an accurate criticism is the most valuable feedback you can receive. Imagine how silly and unproductive it would be to respond to your ski instructor as if he were blaming you when he told you that you fell because you didn’t shift your weight properly. It’s no different if a supervisor points out a ﬂaw in your work process. Fix it and move on. To see this principle in action, check out this week’s Case of the Week: https://lnkd.in/gFAFE_F #principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Ever since I released my free Principles In Action app last year in the US Apple App Store, I’ve gotten a lot of requests to bring it to Android and other countries. I’m happy to let you know that it is now officially available for Android and iOS in the US, UK, India, Spain and Germany.People love the app—it has received 4.9 stars in the App Store. It has everything I’ve done in an easy to use format that is always up to date. People especially like the video cases that show how these Principles operate in my company Bridgewater. It also has a Coach feature, which will direct you to the most appropriate principles for the situations you face and a feature where you can write down and use your own principles. It soon will include a newly developed personal values assessment that will help you understand yourself better. I hope you find it as helpful as most of its users do. https://lnkd.in/gnrU6gJ

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: The life that you will live is most simply the result of habits you develop. If you consistently use feelings of anger/frustration as cues to calm down, slow down, and approach the subject at hand thoughtfully, over time you’ll experience negative emotions much less frequently and go directly to the open-minded practices I just described. Of course, this can be very hard for people to do in the moment because your “lower-level you” emotions are so powerful. The good news is that these “amygdala hijackings” don’t last long so even if you’re having trouble controlling yourself in the moment, you can also allow a little time to pass to give your higher-level you space to reflect in a quality way. Have others whom you respect help you too.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: You only need to find one that works.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Now that my app Principles in Action is available on Android & iOS in the US, UK, Spain, India, and Germany, I want to highlight the real life cases that are available within the app. They will show you the principles in action at Bridgewater via a Case of the Week. If you were already using the app via iOS, you might have gone through these cases already. As we resurface this content for our new users, we'd love to hear your feedback and thoughts on the cases – I hope you'll share them here.While fear often leads people to hide their weaknesses, openly exploring them is an essential part of personal development. In this week's Case of the Week, you'll see how getting past the fear of giving and receiving direct feedback has helped others grow to their full potential. Check it out in the free app, Principles In Action: https://lnkd.in/gFAFE_F#caseoftheweek

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: I think most of us are in the rare moment of being able to agree that Ruth Bader Ginsburg was a hero which is a really big deal because we now live in a society in which there are no agreed upon heroes. That is because most people who stand out are torn down because people who are on the other side want to discredit them. Because we can agree that she was a hero, we should be able to look at the principles that made her a hero so that others can live by them and we can have more heroes.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: If you're like most people, the idea of facing the unvarnished truth makes you anxious. To get over that, you need to understand intellectually why untruths are scarier than truths and then, through practice, get accustomed to living with them.If you're sick, it’s natural to fear your doctor’s diagnosis—what if it’s cancer or some other deadly disease? As scary as the truth may turn out to be, you will be better off knowing it in the long run because it will allow you to seek the most appropriate treatment. The same holds for learning painful truths about your own strengths and weaknesses. Knowing and acting on the truth is what we call the “big deal” at Bridgewater. It’s important not to get hung up on all those emotion- and ego-laden “little deals” that can distract you from the overall mission.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: When I refer to your “ego barrier,” I'm referring to your subliminal defense mechanisms that make it hard for you to accept your mistakes and weaknesses. Your deepest-seated needs and fears—such as the need to be loved and the fear of losing love, the need to survive and the fear of not surviving, the need to be important and the fear of not mattering—reside in primitive parts of your brain such as the amygdala, which are structures in your temporal lobe that process emotions. Because these areas of your brain are not accessible to your conscious awareness, it is virtually impossible for you to understand what they want and how they control you. They oversimplify things and react instinctively. They crave praise and respond to criticism as an attack, even when the higher-level parts of the brain understand that constructive criticism is good for you. They make you defensive, especially when it comes to the subject of how good you are.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Though it won’t feel that way at first, each and every problem you encounter is an opportunity; for that reason, it is essential that you bring them to the surface. Most people don’t like to do this, especially if it exposes their own weaknesses or the weaknesses of someone they care about, but successful people know they have to.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: I’m extremely excited that OceanX is launching our new ship OceanXplorer. This lead story in today’s NYT Science section explains the background, what we are doing, and also photos of the ship. She is cutting-edge, cool and effective. If you want to follow us on our journey you can do that at OceanX.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Many of you have been asking and I’m happy to share that my free Principles In Action app is now officially available for Android and iOS in the US, UK, India, Spain and Germany. My team is hard at work to develop versions for more countries to follow. I'm excited to be able to make my app available to more of you. https://lnkd.in/gnrU6gJ

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: You must be willing to do things in the unique ways you think are best – and to open-mindedly reflect on the feedback that comes inevitably as a result of being that way.Learning to be radically transparent is like learning to speak in public: while it’s initially awkward, the more you do it, the more comfortable you will be with it. This has been true for me. For example, I still instinctively find being as radically transparent in the ways that I am in my book uncomfortable because I am exposing personal material to the public that will attract attention and criticism. Yet I am doing it because I’ve learned that it’s best, and I wouldn't feel good about myself if I let my fears stand in the way. In other words, I have experienced the positive effects of radical transparency for so long that it’s now uncomfortable for me not to be that way.Besides giving me the freedom to be me, it has allowed me to understand others and for them to understand me, which is much more efficient and much more enjoyable than not having this understanding. Imagine how many fewer misunderstandings we would have and how much more efficient the world would be—and how much closer we all would be to knowing what’s true—if instead of hiding what they think, people shared it openly.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: I often observe people making decisions if their odds of being right are greater than 50 percent. What they fail to see is how much better off they’d be if they raised their chances even more (you can almost always improve your odds of being right by doing things that will give you more information). The expected value gain from raising the probability of being right from 51 percent to 85 percent (i.e., by 34 percentage points) is seventeen times more than raising the odds of being right from 49 percent (which is probably wrong) to 51 percent (which is only a little more likely to be right). Think of the probability as a measure of how often you’re likely to be wrong. Raising the probability of being right by 34 percentage points means that a third of your bets will switch from losses to wins. That’s why it pays to stress-test your thinking, even when you’re pretty sure you’re right.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Though it won’t feel that way at first, each and every problem you encounter is an opportunity; for that reason, it is essential that you bring them to the surface. Most people don’t like to do this, especially if it exposes their own weaknesses or the weaknesses of someone they care about, but successful people know they have to.#principleoftheday

Text: You only need to find one that works.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Natural selection’s trial-and-error process allows improvement without anyone understanding or guiding it. The same can apply to how we learn. There are at least three kinds of learning that foster evolution: memory-based learning (storing the information that comes in through one’s conscious mind so that we can recall it later); subconscious learning (the knowledge we take away from our experiences that never enters our conscious minds, though it affects our decision making); and “learning” that occurs without thinking at all, such as the changes in DNA that encode a species’ adaptations. I used to think that memory-based, conscious learning was the most powerful, but I’ve since come to understand that it produces less rapid progress than experimentation and adaptation. #principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Intentional distortions to attract readers and viewers through sensationalism that harms others is one of the great diseases that is undermining the health of our country. This is a case that affected Bridgewater that I had a window into which I’d like to pass along to you as an example of what it looks like.

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: The life that you will live is most simply the result of habits you develop. If you consistently use feelings of anger/frustration as cues to calm down, slow down, and approach the subject at hand thoughtfully, over time you’ll experience negative emotions much less frequently and go directly to the open-minded practices I just described. Of course, this can be very hard for people to do in the moment because your “lower-level you” emotions are so powerful. The good news is that these “amygdala hijackings” don’t last long so even if you’re having trouble controlling yourself in the moment, you can also allow a little time to pass to give your higher-level you space to reflect in a quality way. Have others whom you respect help you too.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Teams should operate like those in professional sports, where different skills are required to play different positions. Excellence in each is mandatory, the success of the mission is uncompromisable, and members that don’t measure up may need to be cut. When teams operate with such high standards and shared values, extraordinary relationships are likely to develop.#principleoftheday

Name: Ray Dalio
Text: Teams should operate like those in professional sports, where different skills are required to play different positions.
