Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Only 8% of primary patent-holders are women... Come on ladies we need your ideas out in the world! Speak up, be willing to look ridiculous, you’ve got the ideas inside of you, write your own patent, and go for it. I had no idea what I was doing. When I got my idea I went to the Georgia Institute of Technology library everyday after work for a week and looked up every pantyhose patent since the 1800’s on their microfiche. I then went to Barnes & Noble, Inc. and bought a book on patents and trademarks. I wrote my own patent, my mom drew the sketch of the product idea (the original footless pantyhose) and I was the model in the sketch. I had a lawyer write just the “claims” for a discounted fee and bam 💥 I got the official patent number two years later and I was an inventor! Add it to your bucket list... invent something... even if you don’t do anything with it, become a patent holder. If nothing else, just so you can drop that bomb at a cocktail party! "Oh by the way... I’m an INVENTOR." 👊💡#Invent #BeBold #Entrepreneur #Inventor

Text: I’ve had the pleasure of chatting with best-selling author Simon Sinek Inc. on many occasions, usually when we’re cycling up a mountain for the Virgin Strive Challenge. He is an unshakeable optimist and I’m delighted that he will be taking centre stage at Virgin StartUp’s next digital MeetUp to share insights on how to build and lead effective teams, what drives consumer behaviour, and why we should all feel optimistic about the future of business. Tickets are free but space is limited: https://virg.in/bsW

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Tonight, we mourn the loss of an icon. A pioneer for women’s rights and equality, we are indebted to #RBG for her work in changing the world for women everywhere.

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: I dedicate this Monday Mugshot to the Notorious RBG. ❤️ Her legacy will live on in the achievements of all the women who, because of her work, were given the opportunity to fulfill their dreams and greatest potential. What Justice Ginsburg accomplished in her lifetime makes me feel such profound gratitude and inspiration. I think about the deep empathy and frustration that fueled her to challenge double standards, to make the world a better place for generations of women to come. She not only uplifted the feminine, but she changed history for women. “Women belong in all places where decisions are being made.” May we never forget it... #RBG #MondayMotivation

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: This mug reminds me of the importance of not caring what other people think. In order to be your most unique, creative self, you will need to let go of caring what others think about you. It’s one of the greatest gifts you can give yourself. It takes self-awareness, self-reflection, determination, and lots of courage.Not caring what others think about you doesn’t mean you don’t care about them... it just means you don’t need their validation to be you. It’s been my life’s practice to work on this... I hope it becomes yours too. Be you! #Entrepreneur #MondayMotivation #MondayMugShot

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Brilliant, authentic, and relatable! Sara Blakely partnered with Salesforce today for a phenomenal conversation on #resilience, and this was one of my favorite takeaways. You can find and be yourself in your industry and your business while still remaining valuable as a resource and a team player - you don’t have to act serious to be taken seriously! #salesforce #spanx #notseriousbutsmart

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Thanks Salesforce for Small Business for having me for your #StoriesOfResilience series! Here is my top tip for category creators and business owners… how to stay ahead of the curve? Innovation. Differentiate yourself. Build a moat around your business. Ask yourself… “what’s your superpower?” Check out the full interview here: https://lnkd.in/gknS-Dz #Entprereneur #Business Salesforce Marie Rosecrans

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Today was extra special getting to listen to a woman I have admired for many years, the inspiring Sara Blakely, founder of Spanx. She is driven by a greater purpose and passion, to elevate women, and she does it beautifully. Every time I hear her story, I learn something new.Today’s takeaways we can all learn from:- Resilience is like a muscle. The more you push through, the stronger you get.- Don’t “fake it until you make it.” Be your authentic self.- Stay in your lane and hire your weaknesses.- Manage daily your negative self talk.- Be Different. Create something that didn’t exist or improve it so much, your product speaks for itself. - Keep your humor. You don’t have to act serious to be taken seriously.Thank you Salesforce for another great #storiesofresilience! #sarablakely #salesforce #dowhatyoulove #business #empowerment #authenticity #innovation #redbackpackfund

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Join me tomorrow for a conversation with Salesforce for Small Business for their next #StoriesOfResilience. I'll be talking with small businesses from around the globe about my journey with Spanx and the creation of the Red Backpack Fund, which was made to support female entrepreneurs in the wake of the pandemic. Don't miss it! We will be talking about failure, oops moments and how to survive the ups and downs of building a business. Register here to tune in! https://sforce.co/31znmni #SalesForce #Business #Entrepreneurship

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: How did a pair of pantyhose give rise to the youngest ever self-made female billionaire? Just ask Sara Blakely, who built her Spanx empire by using humor, solving challenges, and evolving as she grew at our upcoming #StoriesOfResilience next week! Register now and don’t miss out:

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: The new books to read this fall are about building careers and companies, rebuilding our lives and institutions, including those who have been marginalized, thinking more clearly, entertaining others, and sustaining our energy, our workplaces, and our environment.

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: One of the things that has been minimized about my journey is how hard I’ve worked to achieve my dreams. For two decades I’ve barely gone out, you’ll rarely see me at events, I don’t have hobbies and I only just started work out. 😳 To reach great success takes a lot of sacrifice. I wouldn’t have it any other way, but it’s important to mention the degree of hard work that it will take to go after your dreams. It’s like a pact you will need to make with the Universe and yourself. The harder you work, the more the Universe will believe how serious you are about your goals and will then show up to help. Edison said success is 1% inspiration and 99% perspiration. So true! One thing is for sure... everyday I’m hustlin’... still. #Entrepreneur #Hustle

For those participating in today's #MarchOnWashington2020 in DC, stop by our soon-to-be HQ where we'll be providing water, snacks and hand sanitizer for those who need it from 11AM-3PM - and thank YOU for using your #powertoempower! | Art by Gayle Kabaker Illustration featuring Amanda Gorman

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: I’ll never forget where I was when I heard that Princess Diana was critically injured in a car accident in Paris. It was the end of August 1997, and I was at our home in Millbrook, New York. My husband, Jay, was in the middle of his battle with colon cancer, and it was an incredibly stressful time. When the news broke, I spent hours glued to the TV in our family room, waiting for any bit of information. I was so upset and holding my breath like the rest of the world. But eventually, Brian Williams announced she had died. I was devastated. I hopped on a plane to cover the funeral. Although I was reporting on what was going on, I too was mourning Princess Diana. Now, 23 years after that tragic car accident, Diana is preserved in our memories: young, vibrant, and still figuring out who she was as she entered a new, exciting and probably nerve-racking period in her life. So much lost potential, but so many indelible images of a woman — loving her boys and finding her purpose, as well as herself. And in death, as in life, inspiring all of us to do the same. #rememberingprincessdiana #princessdi

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Throwback to this tweet in 2017 by Malala who was shot in the head by the Taliban for going to school. Malala graduated from Oxford University this year!"I raise up my voice-not so I can shout but so that those without a voice can be heard...we cannot succeed when half of us are held back." Malala Yousafzai

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: My heart is so full! Last Wednesday, on Women’s Equality Day, I graduated from the Women’s Fellowship!  Many thanks to Center for Civic Innovation and Sara Blakely for recognizing and honoring the work of female entrepreneurs.  You not only believed in our visions, but provided educational and economic support to further our missions.  To my sisters in the cohort, thank you for your unconditional love and support! Name: Sara Blakely
Text: If we’ve learned one thing in 2020, it’s that the pace of progress is anything but static.  On this Women’s Equality Day, we can choose to accept continued incremental gains for women and girls—or we can insist on something much better, much sooner. More women, especially more women of color, need to be in positions to make the decisions, control the resources, and shape the policies that affect their lives and communities. And it can’t happen soon enough. #EqualityCantWait

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: It's Women's Equality Day, and I had no idea this existed (thank you Sara Blakely for bringing it to my attention). I grew up with strong women so the idea of needing a women's equality day was foreign to me growing up.  My grandmother was a powerful influence.  She was a single parent of two head strong boys, a journalist, and a true southern lady.  She never once allowed me to feel less than anyone.  I was told at a young age I could be anything- a chef, a veterinarian, a writer.  I was not given a limitation.  That is not to say I have not felt the double standards or seen inequality in the work place.  I think most of the women I know have stories about being treated differently simply based on gender.The good news is I have seen a shift in women supporting women!  And when we band together and shatter stereotypes and applaud our success, we all win.Happy Women's Equality day do all the amazing women that get up and make the world a better place!#womensequalityday # #equality #diversity

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Happy #WomensEqualityDay. Thank you to the women and men who came before me who fought for equal rights, and for the ones who made it possible for me and so many others to pursue our own dreams. The original Wonder Woman TV show came out in 1975 when I was 4 years old. I remember being in awe of Lynda Carter because she didn’t need to be saved… she was the one doing the saving. I thought... "Women can be superheroes?" In the 1970s, women still had very limited options – I watched my own Mother and Grandmothers never really get the chance to fulfill their full potential. It motivated me to do everything in my power to fulfill my own potential on behalf of those who weren’t given the chance. Thank you to my mom for making this Wonder Woman Halloween costume! I remember you cutting and sewing each star, sewing the Wonder Woman top to my turtle neck so I wouldn’t be cold, the tin foil arm cuffs that kept coming off, and the head band I was so excited to wear I didn’t wait for the glue to dry and it stuck in my hair. It meant everything to me and I was truly transformed. Women really are superheroes, especially moms. #WomensEqualityDay

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Most successful entrepreneurs start their business as a side hustle & keep their day job until the it can support them. That’s good logic. But sometimes it's smart to throw logic out the window. #BusinessUnusual

Name: Sara Blakely
Text: Do what others say cannot be done, that's where it's most fun! I have spent the last 20 years doing things they said couldn't be done, to bring women better and more comfortable options. When the purpose of WHY you're doing something is greater than yourself, it's easier to find the courage you need to do it. #MondayMotivation

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: Handling imbalanced datasets in #ML is a difficult challenge, and can include topics such as #fraud, diagnosing cancer or disease, and even info-sec attacks. In this post, we will boost accuracy on a popular #Kaggle dataset by training a generative synthetic data model to create additional fraudulent records. Uniquely, this model will incorporate features from both fraudulent records and their nearest neighbors.

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: Smart article by Adam Kovacevich. I remember from my Google days that we had zero chiefs of staff for many years, and in fact had an informal policy against them. One day we hired an executive from Microsoft who insisted on having one. 12 months later, there were 250 chiefs of staff at Google. Currently, a LNKD search (which I doubt is 100% accurate) reveals 1,800 chief of staffs at Google.

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: Smart article by Adam Kovacevich. I remember from my Google days that we had zero chiefs of staff for many years, and in fact had an informal policy against them. Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: 👏 Want to be more fit? New research by our co-founder Jessica Wisdom, Humu advisor Katy Milkman, and more in #ManagementScience shows that rewarding people to exercise at the same time every day produces less lasting habits than offering flexibility. Check it out. ➡️

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: "Thinking about work while trying to relax induces panic, because feelings of time poverty are caused by how well activities fit together in our mind. If we are trying to be a committed parent while our work email goes off, we can’t help thinking we should be work on our next deadline instead of being present with our child. This conflict makes us feel like a bad parent (“Why am I thinking about work while trying to hang out with my kid?”) and a bad employee (“Am I hanging out with my kids too much? Will that promotion go to someone else?”)." - Great article by Ashley Whillans

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: “We aren’t all set up to work from home successfully. A lot of these cracks are starting to show as the crisis continues.” Our Head of Content Liz Fosslien spoke to The Information's Nick Bastone about recent WFH productivity trends.

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: Reigan, we're so lucky to work with you! I've learned a ton already. Folks, come join Reigan's marketing team as a product marketing or demand gen manager! Links below.

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: A field experiment my collaborators and I ran to help Google employees form exercise habits is out today in #ManagementScience! Surprisingly, rewarding people to exercise on a consistent schedule produced less lasting habits than paying them for flexible exercise. Flexibility seemed to breed the most resilient habits because people learned to workout not only at their "usual" time but also to hit the gym on a less rigid time-frame: https://bit.ly/37aBhU4

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: If you're not familiar with "WEIRD" in social science research, read on! It's basically the observation that much research is done on people from Western Educated Industrialized Rich Democratic backgrounds, and therefore isn't necessarily universally applicable. It's why at Humu we took pains early on to make sure our study participants were from a global population, and continue to adapt our products for global customers. This book review is a great intro to the concept and where it may have originated.

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: The very first book I have ever read about management and how big companies work was “Work rules” by Laszlo Bock.In this book author  describes a variety of approaches used to engage with and encourage staff at Google. I liked it and discovered many things: ✅ Very good analysis of many HR processes, including detailed and important references✅ Powerful idea of using checklists ✅ Objectives and Key Results must be specific, measurable, achievable, relevant, and timed (SMART)✅ The important idea that full transparency is necessary in modern business ✅ Success at job depends on personal 'scope, impact, and leadership'And many more insides from Google. I recommend this book to everyone and I will definitely read it again.  #leadership #managementtips #leadershipprinciples #managementskills #businessandmanagement #greatness #selfimprovement #selfgrowth #google

Name: Laszlo Bock
Text: It is a difficult situation for everyone, but “for people to get upset enough to say that ‘I feel this is unfair’ demonstrates a lack of patience, a lack of empathy and a sense of entitlement,” said Laszlo Bock, Google’s former head of people operations, or human resources. He is now the chief executive of the start-up Humu, which aims to help companies manage employees more effectively.

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: Hey curious New Yorkers - join us Thursday!  What's it going to take to navigate a future of accelerating change and technology? How do you use your human advantage to thrive in the face of AI? We'll discuss this and more in a session I'm moderating on Thursday, December 5 (6-7:30 pm) at Columbia University. A Playlist for Our Future? Human Advantage in an Age of Technology is hosted by Columbia's Center for Science and Society. Join Lydia Chilton, Alison Lord, Mickey McManus and Matt Jones as we discuss the skills - human & machine - and mindsets needed for more creativity, better problem solving and enhanced ways to learn.It's free, but you need to register here:https://lnkd.in/d6h4YgT #futureofwork; #learninganddevelopment #creativity #future

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: Ecomagination was GE’s multi-billion dollar brand makeover. It was a bold initiative to move a company considered to be an environmental dinosaur from the industrial age into a new era.  At the time, my guest on Ecosystems' #VoiceofValue #podcast, Beth Comstock, was the Chief Marketing Officer (CMO) at GE. Beth was at the forefront of helping to create a new 21st Century value proposition.  In this clip, Beth talks about conducting “dreaming sessions with customers." A brave, collaborative effort to co-create value with customers. GE and their customers worked together to design the right ecological and economical solution.   Ecomagination was one of GE’s most successful business initiatives having generated over $160 billion in revenue for the company. #ValueMadeClear How are you dreaming forward with your customers?

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: Mark Fallows interviewing the brilliant Beth Comstock on the Impossible Network podcast. I can’t recommend Mark’s podcast enough. The most inspiring and innovative minds in the world sharing their wisdom.

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: It’s an ideal day in the north woods. Finally found some time to finish Beth Comstock's 'Imagine It Forward'​ .“We are in the business of building and innovating... We invest in whiteboard wallpaper. We invest in flat, highly talented teams. We invest in Costco Wholesale snack runs. We see it as all of our jobs to make it as easy as possible for builders to build and for innovators to innovate. In this, we serve each other.”Commitment to change leaves little room for bureaucracy. Thanks for the great read, Beth Comstock. #customerexperience #martech #digitalmarketing #marketingautomation

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: Beth Comstock has led the way for so many female executives over an illustrious 20-year career as the former Vice Chair and CMO at GE and the former President of Integrated Media, NBC Universal. She is always looking to write her next story and live it as a courageous human being. She learned along the way that ‘our jobs do not define us.’ Who we are, the networks we create, the people we meet along the way - that's what is important. With each new opportunity comes the next story we will create. What will you become?

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: Came across this section in Beth Comstock’s book “Imagine it Forward.” Creating a safe zone for debate is 100% what I model, as I observed from innovative leaders I met throughout my career. They were marketers, insights, business leaders and HR, but they all demonstrated this to facilitate collaborative creativity.Comstock’s prescription for introducing consumer-centric innovation and creativity in a legacy organization: “What’s needed are the skills of a social architect, someone who is committed to collaborating in a psychologically safe zone that knows for what I call agitated inquiry. Agitated inquiry is the practice of evolving an idea into action steps through heated exchanges and debate.” @Beth Comstock

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: I finished listening to Imagine It Forward by Beth Comstock, Tahl Raz, narrated by Beth Comstock on my Audible app.Beth Comstock highlights the reality that 'most emergent leaders will be challenged at every turn and often be marginalized, but they will be essential to the success of old and new organizations alike'... Keep pushing forward and imagining a better future for your organization/technology!!!

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: "At heart, innovation is a twelve tone symphony of conflict and resolution. Lose control of the notes and the music will descend into chaos. Learn to conduct it and you can create something transcendent"  Beth Comstock in Imagine It Forward. #imagine #innovation #chaos

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: How to get the entire organization aligned on building new growth? Hint: You need a "get to yes team" (yes!), relentless focus on problem solving and a lane for high failures.  A good how-to here from David Kidder and Christina Wallace in New to Big. "Fast eats big" says David.  In my experience, most companies mistake money for speed and get confused about when to go slow and when to be faster than fast.  What do you think?

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: A #mondaymotivation story to share:  Adele is an 11 year old girl who wanted to play basketball with some boys at the Nike NYC store courts. But her feet were under the size limits. So she wrote me a letter, which prompted the Nike leadership team, led by Heidi O'Neill, to quickly remove the restrictions. Now anyone can play in store. And more, they invited Adele and her basketball teammates to play with some pros. Michelle Peluso and I (as Nike Directors) + Michelle's son Cole got to cheer them on.  What a great lesson on moving fast and encouraging voices, no matter how small. Small feet, big steps.

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: What are your proprietary gifts? Too often we overlook our strengths, and focus instead on what we don't have or what a competitor is doing better.  I especially like this concept of "proprietary gifts" from David Kidder, discussed here with his co-author Christina Wallace in their book New to Big, about accelerating new growth in companies. A good reminder to spend time on strengths -- yours, your team's, your business's.  #growth #gifts

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: “Change — in your career, in your company, in your life — starts with YOU. You have to imagine a future that others can’t yet see, and take the initial steps to make it real. Give yourself permission — Then pass it on!” - Beth ComstockI’ve been a long-time fan of Beth Comstock — and having just finished her book, “Imagine It Forward,” it’s even clearer to me why. Beth describes her life as a continuous process of  DISCOVERY. She says: “Open yourself up to be an apprentice, finding a ‘master craftperson’ to study under. Seek out the best in the field; take a key element of wisdom from each one, and then find a way to make it your own.” This was the approach Beth took when she became a first time CMO at GE. She read text books, connected with experts  — and, only after learning the fundamentals from peers, did she decide to break the mold: Building GE’s first “innovation/incubation engine,” rather than a traditional marketing function. Instinctively, this is the approach I took in building WeWork’s Central Growth Team. I spoke with more than a dozen Heads of Growth at exponential peer companies and, only then, did we build our team — recasting the Growth OS to suit the world’s fastest growing physical, social network. Thanks for always inspiring, Beth. Onward!

Text: Had the privilege of sitting with Beth Comstock earlier this week. Hands down one of the most impressive marketers I've ever met. Beyond that, her perspective on creativity, change, and what it takes to both navigate and instigate change is SPOT on. Was a real pleasure to spend some time with her!#creativity #change #perspective #innovation #marketers #CMO #leadership

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: Women make great mentors - I must admit last three books I’ve read this winter were by 3 female authors Beth Comstock ‘Imagine it Forward’, mathematician Cathy O’Neil ‘Weapons of Math Destruction’ and Sheryl Sandberg ‘Option B’. Azerbaijan should embark upon female leadership. Studies find that it brings diversity of thought, better problem-solving.

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: 1 in 2 people are looking for their next job. 1 in 6 is actively disengaged.  Why?  "Because work isn't work."  That's the premise of Aaron Dignan's new book Brave New Work.  Here we take a look at the bad behaviors that often sabotage good work.  I bet you'll recognize them.  Do you have others to add? #workbetter

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: Why don't we trust more at work? Aaron Dignan says it starts with "giving up the idea that we're somehow broken and need to be fixed."  And focus on how we make decisions, not just who makes them. More here on changing how we work.#changethework

Name: Beth Comstock
Text: Most of us are trying to figure out how to make our way through change. That's why I wrote this book.  I wanted to chronicle the messiness that comes with fighting for a better way in organizations. There is no formula or process map.  It's messy and that's ok.   #imagineitforward

Name: Michael Moritz
Text: I came home from an east coast business trip to see that The New Yorker (a very good source for criticism and commentary on popular culture) and Nature (one of the world's preeminent journals for scientific scholarship and news) were both covering AI and the future of work in the same week.  Man oh man, do we have Artificial Intelligence on our minds right now.  How much time are you all thinking about AI, and are you concerned or hopeful?

Name: Eric Ries
Text: LTSE is hiring a Senior Corporate Governance Counsel to join the Customer Development team and support companies as they prepare to list on the Long-Term Stock Exchange. This is a great opportunity for someone to apply legal rigor and creativity to helping the General Counsel and broader executive teams at private and public companies. Learn more and apply at

Name: Eric Ries
Text: September 9,2020. The LTSE opens for business paving the way for a new chapter in the #history of #american #stockmarkets. One year ago, if someone would have told me that I could have had a chance to work for Eric Ries, it would have felt impossible but as they say #dreamsDoCometrue. I could not be a prouder individual sitting miles away from America, knowing the incredible hard work that has gone in to unfurl this new chapter in #stakeholdercapitalism . Proud to be LTSE's first exchange fellow and can't wait to see the magic this exchange will deliver. #USA #financialmarkets #longtermstockexchange #LTSE with Daniel Amar Michael Sherry Carolyn Dee Samantha DeVito Holly Grant Teagan Russell Rachelle Perez Pavitra Bhalla Ray Shan Zoran Perkov Gary Goldsholle Laura Clare Alicia Diamond

Name: Eric Ries
Text: A new series coming out in September. I'm excited to give it a listen: https://lnkd.in/g6Gf9EG

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Today I'm proud to reveal some of the work on food security Jeff Lawson and I have been doing with Brent Summers, @justinmares and Jeff Nobbs at Helpkitchen.org. In 4 months we've served 175k+ meals to hungry people with a very lean team. We wrote about it here: https://lnkd.in/ggcGGWq

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Brad's book is out tomorrow. It hits on a key issue right now--fostering entrepreneurial communities. We need to start thinking about this now more than ever.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Understanding the origins of short-termism in the capital markets is the first step toward finding a better way.   #LTSE #longterm

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Excited to announce my new original workshop with Audible for Business to help teams listen and learn, no matterwhere they are.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: @LTSE we’re building a more equitable and sustainable market designed to support #innovation and sustainable value creation far into the future. We have open roles in engineering, data analysis, marketing, customer development and others. #Listings at https://jobs.lever.co/ltse

Name: Eric Ries
Text: We’re looking for a Head of Marketing to help develop and manage the brand and voice of @LTSE. We have a lot to say about what the long-term health and growth of companies and our country can look like. Come help us say it.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: If analyzing and interpreting data sets and market trends and transforming them into comprehensible information is your skill set, #apply to do it as a Data Analyst @LTSE. Come join us as we work to build a better future for all.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: We’re looking for a System Reliability Engineer @LTSE. Run performance-critical applications, troubleshoot issues, identify/mitigate reliability risks. Work with people dedicated to ensuring the continuous success of companies and our country.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: We value our customers (and all people) @LTSE. Our new Market Operations Analyst will, too. #Apply here if you feel a sense of urgency about customers’ interests and resolving them, as well as keeping an eye on the markets for new opportunities.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: We value our customers (and all people) @LTSE. Our new Market Operations Analyst will, too. #Apply here if you feel a sense of urgency about customers’ interests and resolving them, as well as keeping an eye on the markets for new opportunities.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: IT Engineers interested in joining the team @LTSE, please #apply. Help establish the foundation of our #IT practices, make processes more efficient, and ensure compliance as we build a sustainable long-term future for all of our stakeholders.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: LinkedIn: Software #engineers, @LTSE Software is #hiring. If building tools for the next generation of companies and a more equitable world appeals to you, apply for our Senior Software Engineer position.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: LTSE Software is #hiring a Frontend Architect to own the process by which we build design systems for our tools. Every tool we invest in is being built to help to create eco-system reform.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Over the past few weeks, I have recorded a series of conversations with the people leading the way out of the current crisis. They range from prominent CEOs and investors to scientists and builders work directly on relief efforts. These are the people I have had the privilege of work directly with and their example is what has kept me going in dark times and inspired me to take action. I wanted to share the conversations with you, in the hopes that you will do the same.I’m work on a number of other interviews as we speak. I will do my best to release them weekly, although with the pandemic you never know. The next few conversations are with civic tech leaders, scientists work on a cure, and ordinary people who’ve been swept into positions of leadership unexpectedly. Each of them is a part of the solution.If you know anything about me you know I’m all about feedback. So as you’re listening, if you have further thoughts, and especially if you know heros or leaders who we should be profiling, please reach out. Let me know what you think.Many thanks to Mark Cuban, Sam Altman, and the team at U.S. Digital Response for being the first to share their stories.You can learn more about the project here:

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Did you know that nearly 20mm children are expected to follow a remote learning plan, but have NO COMPUTER IN THEIR HOME? Please help our national campaign to help every child keep learning by getting a computer into the hands of every family in the United States. #schoolclosures #givecomputers #gofundme #keeplearning

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Shining a light on invisible heroes is valuable work and Dan Heath is doing it with your help. Nominate the unsung heroes who make your life easier now--and always--by posting in the comments.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: We’re celebrating 10 years of the #LeanStartup Conference. What have been your highlights? Which lessons stayed with you? What about the people you met who changed the way you built your startup? Please share.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: The Lean Startup Co. team created a Core Concepts track for our October 23-25 conference and wrote up a guest post about it at startuplessonslearned.com. They designed sessions that walk you through discovery, experimentation, and MVPs.Read the post here: https://lnkd.in/dqjs5NC

Name: Eric Ries
Text: This year’s Lean Startup Conference is fast approaching. From October 23-25th, the Palace of Fine Arts in San Francisco will be packed with opportunities to learn from an amazing slate of speakers, attend hands-on workshops, and network with fellow practitioners. The full program is now up, so you can check out everyone who will be there, including Arlan Hamilton, Founder and Managing Partner of Backstage Capital; Twitch founder Justin Kan; Scott Kupor, managing partner at Andreessen Horowitz and Morgan DeBaun of Blavity Inc. to name just a few. I’ll also be talking with Andy Rachleff, CEO of Wealthfront and Co-Founder of Benchmark Capital, about his 35 years in Silicon Valley. Thanks to feedback from previous attendees, our 2019 sessions are organized in four tracks: Enterprise and Government; Startup; Nonprofits and Lean Impact; and a new Lean Startup Core Concepts track that includes topics like experiment design, conducting customer interviews, and story-telling. Workshops and case studies in all the tracks come from companies including Lyft, Amazon Web Services (AWS), Caterpillar Inc., Gumroad, Procter & Gamble, Mozilla, Microsoft Garage, and Molson Coors. Register before Friday, September 6th before ticket prices go up.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Once a year, I have the privilege of convening entrepreneurs from all over the world at the Lean Startup Conference.This year, we’ll meet in San Francisco for three days of talks and workshops designed to help you thrive in your work no matter what level of experience you have with Lean Startup. It’s been amazing to watch the Lean Startup community diversify more and more each year, and we welcome everyone from startups, large companies, government agencies, and non-profits.We already have an incredible lineup of speakers like Michael Seibel, Leah Busque, Tien Tzuo, Scott Kupor, and Katie Haun, and we’re adding more every week. Tickets are on sale now for those of you ready to make your plans to join us—and after tomorrow night, the price will go up. I hope you’ll take a look at the early program and sign up here. I look forward to seeing you!

Name: Eric Ries
Text: On the company culture of Panda Express and continuous learning.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: A great inside look at the creation and growth of Thumbtack, which is ten years old, broken out into lessons and takeaways for maximum readability and impact.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: "This is the most remarkable thing about 'The Road Not Taken'—not its immense popularity (which is remarkable enough), but the fact that it is popular for what seem to be the wrong reasons. It’s worth pausing here to underscore a truth so obvious that it is often taken for granted: Most widely celebrated artistic projects are known for being essentially what they purport to be."

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Thank you to Eric Ries for the great inspiration in the early days of CloudHealth! The Lean start up was a must read.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Voted early with my pals. 36 million of us. Sara Fenske Bahat and I, with many of you, have spent two years opening our doors to give. (Thank you!) Backing the brave, of whom we are proud. I'm home now with the kids while Sara is in El Paso, leaving it all on the field. Your move, America.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Diversity is a key priority for the Lean Startup Company. We fully support California for this bold and groundbreaking move. #diversity #womenleaders #leanstartup #startup

Name: Eric Ries
Text: A bracing look at two new books on poverty in America, Not A Crime to Be Poor and The Poverty of Privacy Rights. It concludes that, "Taken together, they make a persuasive case for the idea that securing the most basic of individual rights for all in our society in fact demands a complete overhaul of our existing institutions."

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Noam Wasserman, best-selling author of "The Founder's Dilemma" and "Life is a Startup" will be at the #LeanStartup Conference sharing his strategies for building the most effective teams.Register for the the 2018 Lean Startup Conference here: https://lnkd.in/eqMF_ur#startups #conference #lasvegas #global

Name: Eric Ries
Text: A good breakdown of the truth that "The optimistic change-agent believes there is always a way forward: a communication issue to unravel, low hanging fruit to tackle, and more opportunities to establish psychological safety. But it also gets people...into trouble."

Name: Eric Ries

Name: Eric Ries
Text: I'm happy to spread the word about how Lean methodologies can amplify social good. Here's more about Ann Mei Chang's new book, Lean Impact, coming out on Oct 30th.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: A small treatise on mathematics, by someone who "tweeted a thing about why 1/0 = 0 is mathematically sound. Some people agreed, some people agreed with caveats, and some people called it bunk. A few people said it’s clear I don’t know real mathematics, because a real mathematician would never make such a mistake."

Name: Eric Ries
Text: The Lean Startup Conference, the flagship event for all things #LeanStartup, is moving to Downtown Las Vegas. Join me, Zappos CEO Tony Hsieh and a global community of entrepreneurs and innovators this November. Early Bird prices end tonight. https://lnkd.in/g9JHipN

Name: Eric Ries
Text: "How did he do that?" "How did he not die?" -- these crucial questions about Super Mario Bros. and more, answered at last.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: "In the spirit of the Bechdel test, a metric that cartoonist and author Alison Bechdel created to measure gender bias in film," this writer proposes a new test for writing about women in science--and every other field, too. For starters, "Take the things that are said about a female subject and flip them around as if they were said about a male. If they sound ridiculous, then chances are good they have no business in the story."

Name: Eric Ries
Text: A look at how early the gender pay gap starts, and how we can work to close it by the author of The Cost of Being a Girl: Working Teens and the Origins of the Gender Wage Gap.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: “A particularly dangerous traffic intersection...community journalism and how to translate data into experience” are just a few of the projects innovation and local government are tackling together in Mexico City.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: “The idea that our era is somehow seeing the emergence of an intelligence in silicon that rivals our own entertains all of us — enthralling us and frightening us in equal measure. And, unfortunately, it distracts us.” On the history, present, and future of AI, Intelligence Augmentation, and Intelligent Infrastructure.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: How adventure climber Alex Honnold prepared for his free solo climb of Yosemite’s 3000-foot El Capitan wall--which he was the first person to ever complete--and how “his cognitive training provides a hint about a major transformation that might soon upend the world of knowledge work.”

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Steve’s thoughts on a new research paper that gets into the mindset of entrepreneurs and looks at the qualities that suggest they’ll succeed.

Name: Eric Ries
Text: Plan better, pay fairly and maximize cash and equity runway. Our new tool Hiringplan is live on @ProductHunt. https://lnkd.in/dtnh7we

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: "Having an algorithm write hundreds of dull poems or songs and “curating” a few that aren’t boring [is] just a recipe for greeting-card sentiment and elevator music.... When we think about what kinds of creativity we want, and how that creativity will be mediated by AI, we should demand more." Great piece by Mike Loukides about what artistic creativity really implies, how far we are from that in AI, and how human-AI creative collaboration might work. #AI #creativity #creativetechnology

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I'm thrilled to announce my new book #ThinkAgain. It's about developing the humility to know what we don't know and the mental flexibility to rethink our opinions: https://lnkd.in/eBDwEi5

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I've often said that one of the greatest challenges (and opportunities) of the 21st century will be how to turn refugees into settlers. This article is focused on movement within the US, rather than transnational migration, but it gives a strong sense of the driving factors. Migration on the scale we are likely to face will not only devastate many areas, it will create intense pressures on those locations whose climate becomes more temperate or is less badly affected. Integrating migrants into existing cities will in some cases revitalize those cities; in other places, they will severely tax infrastructure. At worst, there will be warfare as countries try to keep desperate migrants from entering. If we want to get ahead of this, we should think about how to shape "the market" so that there is equitable opportunity for those forced to move, rather than leaving them in "temporary" shantytowns for decades. #climatechange #migration

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Happy to see OATV portfolio company Riffyn in the news, managing workflows for new #Covid testing protocols.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Excited that Riffyn was able to help Imperial College London with this COVID project, and will continue to support them in the implementation of pooling to jump to 4000 samples a day.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: It’s about time that we stopped talking about the costs of fighting climate change and instead looked at the economic opportunity in addressing it. Rewiring America is a new nonprofit that has tackled this gap with its new report on the jobs created by electrifying the economy. It's an eye-opening read. As I've written elsewhere, Elon Musk is just the first of America's climate billionaires. The opportunities of the 21st century are in addressing the crises of the 21st century, not in finding ever more dodgy ways to get people to spend money for things they don't need or to consume media that harms them. #climatechange #opportunity #venturecapital #entrepeneurship #jobs #economicslowdown

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: How to decide whether your idea should become a project:1. Interest: do you think about it in your free time and bring it up in random conversations?2. Importance: will it benefit others?3. Contribution: do you have something novel to add?

Text: Software for science is one of the most important frontiers for #OpenSource. If you work in this area, here's a great opportunity to get financial support from CZI Science. There are only two weeks left to apply.

Text: New data on remote work, March thru May:(1) Work days are 10-20% longer(2) Best predictor of adaptation isn't introversion, but being agreeable and emotionally stable(3) Communication went up 40% with strong ties but down 10% with weak tiesInsightful analysis from Ethan Bernstein, Hayley Blunden, Andrew Brodsky, Wonbin Sohn, Ben Waber:

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: John, we will miss you so very much. You were heroic.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I love the great work being done by the International Anti-Poaching Foundation (IAPF), founded by former sniper Damien Mander they're protecting the land and its wildlife from trophy hunters and poachers in #Africa. It's an all #women anti-poaching team who de-escalate violence but are effective at reducing poaching, their kitchen is also 100% #vegan which I love too!#wildlife #conservation #plantbased #culture #environment

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Why were Zoom and Netflix able to scale to meet a surge in demand, but state unemployment systems were not? It has a lot to do with how government buys and operates software. That has to change, Jennifer Pahlka told the House Budget Committee yesterday. This is a quick summary of what she told them. #government #covid #innovation

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: This is possibly the scariest article I've read on climate change, because it suggests humans may never wake up to the threat, but just continue, like lemmings, to rush off the cliff. Research shows that “extremely hot summers” are 200 times more likely than they were 50 years ago. But unless you’re considerably older than 50, you probably don’t feel the change. David Roberts describes ‘“shifting baselines syndrome”—a sort of generational amnesia that allows us to forget what we lost and adjust to what we have. It’s a useful psychological trait, but when confronting vast, slow-moving disasters like #climatechange  or #pandemic, it can lead to inaction and complacency. We can counteract that tendency by shifting our culture from one focused on meeting our own materialist desires to one that values historical consciousness—a day-to-day awareness of the obligations that come with being a good ancestor, says Roberts. Journalism and the arts can “pull the lens back and try to recenter a richer historical perspective.” But, he says, there's no substitute for leadership and responsible governance.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: A recent interview with me by Diginomica, echoing the themes of my "Welcome to the 21st Century" article: "This is just the beginning of changes, not the end. A lot of people frame this up as 'What happens post pandemic?' I don't think that's the right way to think about it. This is the century of things that we can imagine could happen but never really took seriously and never prepared for actually happening. And that's a big deal....I think we in the developed world are facing our first serious period of change in a way that we have not seen for a very long time. And because everything is up for grabs, there is a real opportunity and a requirement to shape that. Instead of just taking whatever we get....We can have a positive 30/40/50 years, or we can have a really negative one before we wake up."

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: New book just came in as I prep for the Terraform exam. Have anyone read this book before and found it very useful? #python #devops #aws #alwayslearning

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: This article is very worth reading. Here's a key paragraph, but what's important to read is how the author gets there. I could feel it rearranging my mental furniture in a small but important way as I went along:"In these corrosive, shallow, interminable debates about science, what is most sorely missing is any talk of judgment. It is impossible to understand how experts arrive at their advice, or how leaders use it wisely, apart from the exercise of judgment. Though we might think this point is obvious, it is belied by the common image of science as a neutral, even godlike encounter with eternal, capital-T Truth. With the benefit of a true understanding of the role of judgment in expertise, we would not need the deferential language of “following the science,” the condescension of being told our disagreement with the experts is because of cognitive bias, or the feeling of earth-moving scandal when experts get things wrong."

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Last October, I was part of a workshop on AI governance convened by the Rockefeller Foundation. The report, with essays by participants (including me), is now available. Here's Zia Khan's blog post introducing the report.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: This gives an eye-opening perspective on how inequity plays out in scientific research around the world as part of the legacy of colonialism. “This sounds like an exciting discovery. Please apply for a research permit so we can bring our teams out to study it.”

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: What have I been up to? I’ve been full-time work for COVID for 14 weeks with states and cities across the U.S. & here are my lessons-learned for us to get ready for the next wave of #COVID

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: This past Friday marked my last day at Georgetown University’s Beeck Center for Social Impact + Innovation in a full-time capacity.  It has been my pleasure for 2 years to serve as a Fellow at Beeck, initially under the leadership of founding Executive Director Sonal Shah and most recently under Nate Wong's leadership.  As lead for the Fair Finance portfolio, I have reflected extensively on issues that matter to under-represented communities. Our work has examined both public policy and financing tools that  empower all people to participate fully in an equitable, inclusive, modern economy.  As the world now grapples with a global pandemic and a severe economic downturn,  there is more urgency than ever to implement frameworks that support inclusion and equity. I am thrilled to pass the reins for the leadership of the Fair Finance portfolio to Andrea E McGrath MBA I MPA who brings significant experience in impact investing, social enterprise and academia.  I was also delighted to co-author my last Beeck piece below with Sonal and Betsy Zeidman, two incredible experts in impact investing, whom I have known for more than 15 years.  Stay tuned for news this summer about my next endeavor and please be in touch with your thoughts on promoting greater equity for all communities.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I've published a new learning playlist on the O'Reilly Media platform about agile software development for government. The title, "moving at the speed of need" comes from Ross Dakin of the Pennsylvania Department of Innovation, who used that phrase to describe how government needs to step up in response to the crisis. The playlist starts with @Kipthinks’ wonderful talk and platform Q&A about how the city of San Jose used #agile techniques to create its #COVID action plan, and accompanies it with a set of pointers into videos, books, and reports that help explain the techniques he and his team used.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I just published a piece about scenario planning and the post-#COVID future. "By separating the receptive imagination from the quest for certainty, it is possible to prepare for a wide variety of unknown futures, to imagine how you might respond, and to make plans that hold up across a range of possible outcomes. So, while you may hope for a return to normal, and plan for that as one of your scenarios, it is worth taking the time to think through what you might do were the world we knew to be swept away as surely as the 19th century certainties were swept away by the events of the early 20th century." #strategy #scenarioplanning #technologytrends

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: When I started LinkedIn’s edit team nearly 9 years ago, I had no idea that we'd grow to 75+ editors across 15 countries, serving 690m+ members. Editors play a central role in LinkedIn’s professional community, from original reporting to cultivating/curating conversations from members, Influencers and publishers. Our mission is to give professionals the news and views they need now to stay informed and to build their voices.To help members connect with this content, today we're launching a distinct editorial identity — LinkedIn News — that reinforces our work as a trusted professional news brand, while communicating the value we bring to you and the community. If you aren’t already, be sure to follow the right page for you to stay up to date on today’s important business, career and economic news:🇺🇸 lnkd.in/linkedinnews🇦🇺 lnkd.in/linkedinnewsaus🇧🇷 lnkd.in/linkedinnoticias🇫🇷 lnkd.in/linkedinactualites🇩🇪 lnkd.in/linkedinnewsdach🇮🇳 lnkd.in/linkedinnewsindia🇮🇹 lnkd.in/linkedinnotizie🇯🇵 lnkd.in/linkedinnewsjapan🇲🇽 https://lnkd.in/emVVR5r🇳🇱 lnkd.in/linkedinnieuws🇪🇸 https://lnkd.in/eCGcFh4🇬🇧 lnkd.in/linkedinnewsuk🌏 https://lnkd.in/exFF2Q5🇪🇺 https://lnkd.in/e8W_QcW🇦🇪+ lnkd.in/linkedinnewsgulf

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: If you're one of the thousands of government workers struggling with unruly technologies as you step up to unprecedented new demands brought on by the #COVID pandemic and resulting economic dislocations, US Digital Response is a volunteer organization matching you with trained technologists who can help.  Tomorrow morning at 9 am Pacific, I'll be talking with USDR co-founder Jennifer Pahlka about their work in a 1 hour, Q&A heavy Meet the Expert webcast on the O'Reilly online learning platform. If you're a government and worker you've already taken O'Reilly Media up on our free offer for government, just sign in to your account. If you haven't done so already, you can sign up for a 3-month free account as part of the registration process. (If you're not a government worker but are interested in becoming a volunteer, you can attend the webcast by signing up for a shorter free trial if you aren't already a member.) #govtech #government #pandemic #volunteers

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Tomorrow at 10 am PT, Jennifer Pahlka and I will be talking with Pia Malaney and the Institute for New Economic Thinking community about how response to COVID is reshaping government and the economy. We'll talk about Jen's work on US Digital Response, an all-volunteer effort to match up tech talent with governments needing help, and some of the projects they've kicked off, but we'll also talk about the long term implications for our economic system of the Pandemic bailout and other ad-hoc response. Can we turn this into a transformational moment for the economy and our institutions, for the better? Free webcast, register here. #COVID #economics

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Tomorrow at 11 am Pacific time, I'll be hosting a presentation and Q&A with Kip Harkness, Deputy City Manager of the City of San Jose in charge of disaster planning and resilience. Kip will explain how San Jose used #agile methodologies to realign its priorities in response to the  #COVID crisis. Kip has useful insights not just for other governments, but any organization mobilizing to meet an uncertain future. (That's all of us!) #agilemindset #agileleadership #government #meet

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: "If you can stand up a new [government] service in a day when there's a crisis, why does it take years when you're not in a crisis?" On the Masters of Scale podcast, Jennifer Pahlka talks about what she's learned from the work of Code for America and United States Digital Response on how the #COVID crisis may just be a tipping point for the adoption of 21st century technology by government, and what this means for the rest of the economy. #inthistogether #theeconomy #unemploymentbenefits

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Idea to provide financial relief to local service providers whose businesses are shut down while we’re sheltering in place but whose services we will inevitably use again in the foreseeable future: Temporary subscriptions or pay in advance capabilities. For example, just about every one is going to need a haircut when this is all over with. For those that can afford to do it, pay for your next haircut (or two or three) in advance. Could do the same with dinners at your favorite restaurant, dentist visits, dog groomers, etc. Perhaps folks from companies like Amazon, Shopify, Patreon, Yelp, Apple, Paypal/Venmo, Square/Cash, Stripe, Brex, Intuit, Gofundme, etc., could pitch in to create the functionality and share it and/or open source to enable the largest number of local service providers and their customers to use it. Thoughts?

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: 5 weeks ago, 2 things happened: I broke my leg in 2 places, and Strata, one of the events I chaired, shut down. So I did what any immobile, self-isolated geek would do, and spent 30 days learning everything I could about virtual and hybrid conferences.This picture is one of the diagrams I've put together to understand the tech, but the *culture* and *business model* changes are far more important. The result is a big research report into over 160 companies, running dozens of demos and talking with many of the event organizers and speakers I trust most.I'll be sharing what I've learned in a live webinar on Friday, May 8 at noon ET (I mistakenly put 1PM in the picture below, but I can't edit it. :()You can go register here: https://bit.ly/FOfEvents#conferences #events #eventprofessionals #virtualevents #virtualconference

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I don't want life to return to normal. We need a massive shift toward compassion, kindness and deep care for our planet and all living creatures. We need a culture which values contribution to society above status, power and money.  It's up to us. #NewHeroes

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: "We had a plan, and all of a sudden the entire plan was not relevant anymore. The world changed." That's Brian Chesky talking about how Airbnb took bold and decisive actions in the face of coronavirus to establish a relief fund for hosts, expand the parameters of guest cancellations, open up a new business line of virtual experiences, and quickly raise new capital — all with the goal of both weathering the storm and laying the groundwork for the new era of travel that Chesky firmly believes will follow. On the new Rapid Response feed of Masters of Scale, Chesky takes our co-host Bob Safian through the last few weeks, shares what gives him hope and explains why he’s bringing Airbnb back to its roots as a scrappy, resilient startup that can adapt and evolve.Listen to it on @ApplePodcasts:https://lnkd.in/gqs3sUm#airbnb #COVID

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I cowrote this book a while ago, but today I received my first O'Reilly animal, as a framed print.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: "The fix starts with courageous policy choices supported by sound technology choices," says Jennifer Pahlka about the work of United States Digital Response to help states build Pandemic Unemployment Assistance sites that can stand up to the load (as well as mobilizing tech volunteers who are doing lot of other things to help state and local governments respond to the crisis.) This article explains a key design pattern for marrying high-performance cloud-based front ends with user friendly design to antiquated legacy government back-end systems. #COVID #pandemic #unemploymentbenefits #govtech #volunteers

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: With stay-at-home in place, I can't help overhearing bits of the conversations my wife Jennifer Pahlka is having in her role as one of the co-founders of United States Digital Response, an ad-hoc group matching volunteer tech talent with governments around the country that are struggling to model the impact of the COVID epidemic on their ability to deliver services, standing up new services or shoring up existing ones, automating tasks that have outrun the capability of their traditional workflows, all the while dealing with new remote-work environments and more. And it became obvious that the information O'Reilly provides is an important tool that can help keep overburdened services up and running. So as Laura Baldwin explains, we have decided that for the next three months we are making the entirety of our online learning library (books, video, live online training and technology sandboxes, and more) available for free to anyone with a federal, state, or local email address.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Examples of people and companies “helping where they can” are everywhere as we wrestle with the effects of this deadly virus. Today, O'Reilly Media is applying our mission to spread the knowledge of innovators to help government at a time when our citizens need them most. We’ve opened all of our technology resources free to all federal, state and local agencies as they work tirelessly to support us during these trying times. https://oreil.ly/0xOUX

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: We are beginning to see many great examples emerge, but many challenges still need to be tackled...Virus Shutdown: Time for Digital Government to Prove Itself https://bit.ly/2wco50F #govtech #COVID

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Ray isn't always right (who is?) but everyone can learn a huge amount from the process that he uses (and shares) for coming to an understanding of the current moment by distilling principles from history and other sources.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Moving your conference or meetings online?  Need help thinking through how to re-frame and re-organize the experience you were planning?   When I was at Maker Faire we leveraged #videoconferencing regularly to build community and expertise across the international network of events, and used the full capabilities of Zoom for annual online summits.  It's possible to guide folks seamlessly through plenaries (live or pre-recorded) to breakouts and even "hallway" experiences. People meet their peers and their mentors.  Exchange and engagement are real.  We also streamed entertaining coverage of the flagship events to thousands of viewers via Facebook, YouTube, and Twitch—live switching from keynotes and stage demos to roving camera coverage and man-on-the-street interviews.I have a network of experienced streaming media pros ready to help you make the most of #virtualevents. Large or small, we can help you design the program, choose the right platform, and provide #productionservices to ensure time well spent for your audience and community. Reach out if you have gathering problems to solve!

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Specific Critical COVID NeedI’m helping scale the COVID test and we have a specific current Bay Area local need in COVID testing.Stanford and UCSF have a rapid same day test and are doing really well. But in order to maximize the number of tests they can do daily, they don’t have enough labtechs to test and to scale to get to maximum number of testing every day.Needed: 2-5 local Bay Area CLIA certified lab techs, ideally with experience in nucleic-acid based diagnostics but not mandatory.In addition, UCSF will need up to 10 local Bay Area CLIA certified labtechs to do the same. Experience with the Bravo liquid handling robot or the Bio Rad CFX384 real-time PCR system would be great for here but again, not mandatory.These labtechs would be trained for the specific work flow and assist in testing currently to scale the tests.  Later, we will want to scale to other Clia certified labs but for now this is our most critical need. DM me or eve.blossom@gmail.com

Text: O'Reilly Media has decided, out of an abundance of caution, not to hold our Strata Data & AI San Jose event in March due to the COVID outbreak. We’ll be merging it with our larger Strata Data & AI New York event taking place September 14–17, 2020 to take advantage of the amazing speakers, sponsors, trainers, and attendees who make up the data and AI communities on both coasts. All the details are in today’s post. https://oreil.ly/YSyq5

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I couldn't agree more (except I believe #economy #decline we're even further down the slope of decline than the author suggests.) This is a must-read: "In the modern era, there are few if any examples of a country with a healthy, thriving economy and a broken political system. What distinguishes a successful economy from a failing one — what distinguishes Denmark from Italy and South Korea from North — is not how much capital it has or technology it produces but the quality of its institutions — the laws, rules, norms and policies that create the framework in which any economy operates. And there should be no doubt that as a result of broken politics, the quality of the United States’ institutions is already on the decline."

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: I couldn't be more excited about the acquisition of Katacoda by O'Reilly Media. We've been thinking a lot about the future of learning, and "learning by doing" with performance support tools is a big part of it. Katacoda brings this vision to the O'Reilly online learning platform. Scenarios and sandboxes allow you to actually do the work that you need to learn. We have just begun the process of integrating Katacoda into the platform, so there's a lot more to come. Give it a try! #technology #learning #technologyforteachingandlearning

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: O'Reilly acquires Katacoda and we could not be more proud to celebrate the future of learning.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Our politics and policy are "like a car where the steering wheel is only loosely connected to the wheels: We might fight over who is in the driver’s seat, but regardless of who is driving, you’re not going to get where you meant to go”, says Jennifer Pahlka. Her work on "delivery-driven policy" may seem like a wonky thing that matters only to the civic tech movement, but it also goes to the heart of much of what is wrong with our politics. Most of the policies we argue over are so flawed by poor implementation that it's as if they'd never been tried. And that failure leads to the profound distrust of government intervention that is a big part of our political divide. #democracy #policy #government

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: The approach that Code for America, USDS, and many others have brought to government technology has its highest applications in policy. This is how we really make government work for people in a digital age.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: The internet has lowered the barriers for anyone to be a critic, and it has raised the expectations for uninterrupted, instant access to services we depend on. Laura Baldwin's post about the Kincaid Fire and its impact on O'Reilly's business  #does a great job unpacking the gap between these two poles: the reality of choices and tradeoffs, but also the unexpected tangles of layered technology that catch even the most experiences companies (like Google and Amazon and Netflix) as well as O'Reilly, and most importantly, the human stories of loss and heroic effort that are not always obvious to those at a distance. Like you, I'm incredibly proud of the resilience displayed by our people and our services. Each experience - and over the years, we've had both flood and fire to contend with - makes us stronger, not just through building more resilient services, but also by building the muscle to deal with the inevitable surprises. Bravo. #fire #resilience

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Great quote from Kate Raworth's book Doughnut Economics very relevant to government's role in the economic shitshow of the shareholder value revolution that the Business Roundtable finally began to question this week: "Governments have historically opted to tax what they could, rather than what they should, and it shows. Tax windows and you'll get dark houses, as Britain discovered in the 18th and 19th centuries; tax employees and you head for a jobless economy, as many countries are discovering today. It is happening in part thanks to the 20th century's legacy of perverse tax policies, which charge firms for hiring humans (through payroll taxes), subsidize them for buying robots (through tax deductible capital investments), and levy next to nothing on the use of land and non-renewable resources. In 2012, over 50% of tax revenue in the UEU came from taxing labor; in the United States, the percentage was even higher. It is no surprise that the industry's response has been to focus on increasing labor productivity - output per worker - by replacing as many workers as possible with automatons." Government is a platform, and just like Facebook, it expresses itself through algorithms - in this case, tax policy - that control those who use it.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: What a great story! I learned so much about Elizabeth Warren. And teaching is such a fascinating context through which to understand how she operates. Must-read.

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: Great quote from Peter Norvig:  “We know how to build real intelligence—my wife and I did it twice, although she did a lot more of the work,” Norvig said in an interview with Forbes. “We don’t need to duplicate humans. That’s why I focus on having tools to help us rather than duplicate what we already know how to do. We want humans and machines to partner and do something that they cannot do on their own.” This article gives a good roundup of just how many benefits have already come from the pursuit of general AI as well as specialized work on domains like self-driving cars. #artificialintelligence

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: In my latest piece in Quartz, I take aim at what I call "the illusion of free markets," in which platforms like Amazon and Google first increase our economic freedom, and then restrict it in pursuit of increased profits. I write,  "These giants don’t just compete on the basis of product quality and price—they control the market through the algorithms and design features that decide which products users will see and be able to choose from. And these choices are not always in consumers’ best interests."  It includes an eye-opening account of how Google search results have changed over the past decade, from featuring the best of the web to putting ads and Google's own information products front and center. And now Amazon is following the same path, highlighting sponsored results over those that are best for their customers. If antitrust regulators want to get things right, they have to be solving the right problem. And that means having a theory about how the web and ecommerce work as ecosystems. They need to start measuring whether the top platforms are eating their ecosystem, and what tools they are using to do it. #web #google #amazon #antitrust

Name: Tim O'Reilly
Text: The Providence Mini Maker Faire returns to #pvdfest in one week! As any returning maker knows, we’ve been doing 3D-printed and CNC’d exhibitor credentials for a few years. This year, the design is inspired by the Corliss Centennial #steamengine (created in Providence, Rhode Island). It powered much of the World’s Fair of 1876, then known as the Philadelphia Centennial Exposition. Every exhibiting maker will get a badge to wear during the Faire and to take home as a #souvenir. If you’re not exhibiting, you can get get one by backing our #kickstarter, which ends Wednesday, June 5, 2019 at 4:00 PM EDT (http://kck.st/2ZSnew6)

Name: Alexis Ohanian Sr.
Text: Saw the ex CEO of a fitness brand allegedly disparaged a male colleague who was contemplating taking paternity leave... So I wrote this on Olympia Ohanian's 3rd bday bc we need to end this absurd stigma against men taking paternity leave.After multiple surgeries that my wife barely survived, what kind of man WOULDN'T absolutely want to take paternity leave (if he's lucky enough to have access) to be there for his fam? Besides, it it should be available for EVERY American. Not just wealthy CEOs + founders like me.And while we're on the subject.. there's a black maternal health crisis in the US and COVID has only exacerbated it. Shoutout to members of Congress like Congresswoman Blunt Rochester who are doing the work to fight + fix this, but there's A LOT to be done.

Name: Alexis Ohanian Sr.
Text: As the U.S. Open starts, I’m thinking about a tennis match from 47 years ago. I still remember sitting in front of the TV as a kid and watching Billie Jean King take on Bobby Riggs in “The Battle of the Sexes.”  I recently got to speak to Billie Jean about that experience and how it helped spur her to decades of activism for gender equality. “For me, playing Bobby had little to do with tennis,” she told me. “It may have been a tennis match, but it was all about social change.”

Name: Alexis Ohanian Sr.
Text: Today, I’m proud to announce that Tony West is joining Ro’s Board of Directors. Tony has spent his entire life fighting for the right side of history — from civil and constitutional rights to healthcare fraud prevention to immigration reform to marriage equality to diversity, equality, and inclusion. What started as a phone call turned into a 7 hour, socially distant, in-person chat. Tony’s rare expertise, unwavering integrity, and desire to help people is what makes him the perfect person to join the Ro Family. We are beyond excited to learn from Tony and to work with him to make Ro every patient’s first call.

Name: Alexis Ohanian Sr.
Text: So excited to welcome Tony West to the Ro board. This is a big league addition and supercharges our quest to be the patient's first call.

Name: Alexis Ohanian Sr.
Text: Today, I’m proud to announce that Tony West is joining Ro’s Board of Directors. Tony has spent his entire life fighting for the right side of history — from civil and constitutional rights to healthcare fraud prevention to immigration reform to marriage equality to diversity, equality, and inclusion. What started as a phone call turned into a 7 hour, socially distant, in-person chat. Tony’s rare expertise, unwavering integrity, and desire to help people is what makes him the perfect person to join the Ro Family. We are beyond excited to learn from Tony and to work with him to make Ro every patient’s first call.

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: At the core of Justice Ruth Bader Ginsburg’s extraordinary life was a simple conviction: “Women belong,” she said, “in all places where decisions are being made.” She was a brilliant jurist, an inimitable Supreme Court justice, a force for equality and integrity—and she was one of my heroes. There will never be another RBG, but we are a much better, fairer country for all that she gave us.

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: My esteemed colleague Johannes (Johs) Worsoe (CFO for the Americas at MUFG) will be contributing to the compassion handbook being developed by White & Case LLP and Thunderbird School of Global Management.﻿Excerpt from Johs’s article: “Your so-called “compassionate self” can have a profound impact on a single colleague, on an entire team, and even – if you get a chance at the big prize – on the overall culture of your company.  But that means finding your compassionate self, first of all.  Then it takes confidence to put it to good use every waking moment, which is key because consistency matters.…Any senior leader in a multi-trillion-dollar global bank obviously will face far-reaching decisions and moments that matter throughout every day – that’s a big part of my job. ... Regardless of the nature of these decisions, we must know this: For the people sitting across the table, these are moments that can matter hugely to them.  And therefore they should matter to you. Be present in these moments”Much gratitude to Dean Sanjeev Khagram  and Todd Wolynski for mobilizing Thunderbird School of Global Management and White & Case LLP resources on this book project to help bring compassion in the heart of financial service industry culture.  #leadership #gratitude #compassion

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: The replay of our virtual fireside chat with Jeffrey Walker is now available!Memorable quote on mindful partnerships from Jeff: "I analogize it to a jazz ensemble… that experience I have, that feeling of playing with others when I was young is still what I try to look for today. It’s listening to the others around you playing their own instruments, it’s knowing that they’re doing something different than you, but when you come together, you’re producing something you couldn’t have done by yourself… That if you remember, there’s an audience, there’s an intention, there’s a reason for you to be with these people to connect to each other to produce something that you couldn’t have done by yourself into an impact and to have a result... These ensembles for change that I’ve supported over the years and been a part of, and continue to find even new ones to work on.” #mindfulness #mindfulleadership #compassion #mindfulonwallstreet

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: In tumultuous times such as these, shedding light on mindful and compassionate practices and leadership in our corner of the global community remains our mission at Mindful on Wall Street. Mindfulness practices have been shown to shed light on cognitive biases and foster curiosity and openness to different perspectives. Compassion breeds empathy, and empathy asks us to imagine walking in another’s shoes. Empathy then asks us to ask ourselves what our role is or can be. Join us for for our first Mindful Leadership Fireside Chat on June 25th, where former Vice Chairman of JPMorgan Chase & Co. and current Chairman of New Profit Jeffrey Walker will discuss how mindfulness and compassion can help us navigate these volatile, complex and uncertain times. He'll also share how mindfulness plays a key role in leadership, decision-making, and will lead us in an exploration of how the tools of self-inquiry can help both companies and individuals begin to address the issues of inequality in our country. Register today: https://lnkd.in/dQAZ6rR#mindfulness #mindful #mindfulleadership #mindfulnessatwork #compassion #leadership #meditation

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: Lesson from one of my father’s favorite philosopher - Shantideva (8th Century):—-“Enemies such as hatred and attachment are without arms, legs and so on. They are neither courageous nor wise.  How is it that they have enslaved me?...For as long as space endures and for as long as the world lasts, may I live to dispel the suffering of the world.”——I recall Richard Gere visiting us at the Tibetan Childrens Village (TCV) in Dharamsala, India.  TCV is a school for Tibetan refugees which I attended. Richard met with a number of us with much love and respect. He told us how important it is to preserve our culture and the relevance of it in our world. As an economically poor and politically marginalized refugee his words were encouraging but I did not fully appreciate it. Fast forward I now serve on the board of The Tibet Fund based here in New York City. I work with Richard and others to raise funds and resources to preserve Tibetan culture.  While greatly appreciating modern political and economic system there is no doubt in my mind the value and relevance of our culture to contribute to a more kinder, equitable, sustainable and flourishing world.   #compassion #stewardship #inclusiveness #interdependenceMollie Rodriguez
