Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: Lesson from one of my father’s favorite philosopher- Shantideva (8th Century):—-“The mind does not find peace, nor does it enjoy pleasure and joy, nor does it find sleep or fortitude when the thorn of hatred dwells in the heart.”——The antidote to hatred is compassion.Today Alice Kim Douglas Martin, PMP and I had a call with Jeffrey Walker (former Vice Chairman of J.P. Morgan and co-founder of $12 billion CCMP Capital) to prep for a virtual fireside chat Jeff will give on Mindful Leadership organized by Mindful on Wall Street (MoW).During our conversation, Jeff mentioned of the $20 mm donation by Jennifer and Matt Harris (Founding Partner of Global Infrastructure Partners) to support research and application of kindness. As a project finance banker it was encouraging to see the growing number of colleagues both on the debt and equity side recognizing the value of compassion both in business and well being. So proud at MUFG that mindfulness and compassion training was recommended by colleagues including Beth Waters to help achieve our sustainable finance objectives.  #compassion #kindness #stewardship

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: for serious behavior modification by people in power, you cannot rely solely on outrage or moral suasion. You remove them from their posts or scare them enough at the prospect of removal that they change. Barack Obama wrote about this in a recent post imploring those wanting real change to become more, not less, involved in our political system, and above all to vote. It's fighting with one arm and both legs behind your back to protest, say, stop-and-frisk policing and then not vote in an election that would determine your local sheriff or mayor. I'm honestly increasingly impatient with nonvoters.

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: At the time of death what will best allow us to face it is not the size of the deal we worked on or even how much positive impact we had, but how best we tried to serve others. This is the conclusion I have drawn from my father. His body continues to deteriorate due to his age. When I ask how he is doing, he tells me he is very happy. When I prod him further he tells me that he has no regrets because he tried his best. This is great news because it means we ALL have the same opportunity no matter how powerful or rich we are. Let me give you a glimpse of his journey. In March 1959, my father was a staff person work closely with His Holiness the Dalai Lama. He stayed behind, along with a number of others, to create a sense of normalcy so that the Dalai Lama could escape to India. Later, he sought refuge in India and dedicated his life to preserve a culture that promoted mental qualities of love and compassion. Today top neuroscientists, multi billionaires, renowned educators and a growing number of public are seeing the wisdom of the power of an altruistic motivation. The culture my father and his generation put their life on the line to preserve is now viewed by many as a global treasure and source of hope for a better world.  #stewardship #inclusiveness

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: As we navigate the stress and uncertainty of this historic moment, I’ve been thinking a lot about how self-inquiry & mindfulness are life-lines, not luxuries.  When I was interviewed for this article in 2019, I could have never imagined how urgent the message would feel by 2020.   Social change is a marathon, not a sprint -- and our collective impact depends on each of us finding courage to grapple with every aspect of our humanness, including the things we typically push away vs. pause to investigate.  What is this moment teaching me about fear? Envy? Ego? Anxiety?  I’m convinced that confronting these questions head-on will give us the strength and stamina we’ll need for the long haul. With  gratitude to Jeffrey Walker and Katherine Milligan, Stanford Social Innovation Review, the #wellbeingproject and the amazing leaders whose examples light the way for me and countless others:  Peggy Dulany Ellen Agler Sasha Chanoff Renee KaplanPremal Shah Don Gips Diana Wells Nancy Lublin Erin Keown Ganju Bryan Stevenson Ai-jen Poo Jacqueline Novogratz Wendy Kopp Darren Walker Raj Panjabi Bill George#socialchange #thisisleadership #compassionateleadership #socialimpact

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: As the cascading effects of the COVID health and economic crisis multiply and the demands and stresses on social sector leaders grow to unprecedented levels, I wish to issue an urgent plea: embrace mindfulness and self-inquiry. They are not a luxury. They are essential to navigate this period of intense anxiety and uncertainty and enable us to “act out of our best selves in the work we do in the world.” I am pleased to share my article “Self-Inquiry for Social Change Leaders,” the result of a terrific collaboration with Jeffrey Walker and Aaron Pereira and Sandrine Woitrin at The Wellbeing Project. I know you will find the incredible leaders we interviewed as inspiring as I do, and I hope their courage in telling their stories encourages others to begin their own journey. #wellbeingwelldoing Peggy Dulany Ellen Agler Sasha Chanoff bedriye hulya Abby Falik Renee Kaplan David Germano Michael Sani Jose Mari Luzarraga Jasmeen Patheja Premal Shah Mark Bertolinicc Don Gips Diana Wells François Bonnici Kyle Zimmer Kristine Pearson Nancy Lublin Ashifi Gogo Olivia Leland Martín Burt, PhD Johanna Mair Patrick Awuah Frank Beadle de Palomo Jeroo Billimoria Jane Chen Erin Keown Ganju Jordan Kassalow Gonzalo Muñoz Abogabir Christie Peacock CBE Chris Underhill MBE Daniela Papi-Thornton

They are not a luxury. They are essential to navigate this period of intense anxiety and uncertainty and enable us to “act out of our best selves in the work we do in the world.” I am pleased to share my article “Self-Inquiry for Social Change Leaders,” the result of a terrific collaboration with Jeffrey Walker and Aaron Pereira and Sandrine Woitrin at The Wellbeing Project. I know you will find the incredible leaders we interviewed as inspiring as I do, and I hope their courage in telling their stories encourages others to begin their own journey. #wellbeingwelldoing Peggy Dulany Ellen Agler Sasha Chanoff bedriye hulya Abby Falik Renee Kaplan David Germano Michael Sani Jose Mari Luzarraga Jasmeen Patheja Premal Shah Mark Bertolinicc Don Gips Diana Wells François Bonnici Kyle Zimmer Kristine Pearson Nancy Lublin Ashifi Gogo Olivia Leland Martín Burt, PhD Johanna Mair Patrick Awuah Frank Beadle de Palomo Jeroo Billimoria Jane Chen Erin Keown Ganju Jordan Kassalow Gonzalo Muñoz Abogabir Christie Peacock CBE Chris Underhill MBE Daniela Papi-Thornton

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: Jeffrey Walker, New Profit's Board Chair, recently co-authored a piece with Katherine Milligan of Bamboo Capital Partners for Stanford Social Innovation Review's "Centered Self: The Connection Between Inner Well-Being and Social Change" series.The piece takes a deep look at the pressures associated with social entrepreneurship that often lead to burnout, anxiety, and fatigue and the importance of self-inquiry for these leaders. "We found that continuous self-inquiry helped leaders manage their energy and resilience, become more effective team leaders, and develop more meaningful collaborations with other organizations to drive sustained, positive change in the way the current individuals, organizations, and governments address problems."https://hubs.ly/H0plDXZ0

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: Our colleagues at America Forward, which is New Profit's nonpartisan social innovation policy initiative and coalition in DC, have published an important and timely piece about how nonprofits can understand and navigate the huge relief and recovery bill that was just signed into law. I'm encouraging all nonprofit leaders and others who care about equity and opportunity to read this piece and share it in their own networks. There are actionable pieces of information throughout, as well as some framing that feels important at this moment of unprecedented challenges:The more we share insights, collaborate, and provide support to each other, the better we'll be able to navigate the hard times ahead. Let's commit to standing with each other in the social sector, today and always. Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: A public health physician who used to work at Centers for Disease Control and Prevention for 20 years shared with me the importance of a culture shift in the financial industry:“Highlighting the importance of compassion in the banking and finance sector could significantly influence health system executives, who view health care as a business rather than a vocation or a compassionate mission.  Appeals by health workers for more compassionate health systems seem to carry little weight, but a strong voice and case studies of mindfulness and compassion from banking and finance could be very persuasive.  And health is just one of the many sectors that could be influenced in this way. “While we reflect with gratitude the compassion of our health care professionals, let us expedite our efforts to bring the culture shift in the financial industry so that we have the maximum positive impact on our society.I would like to express my deep appreciation to Dean Sanjeev Khagram from my alma mater Thunderbird School of Global Management  and a number of others who are work hard to envision a world post coronavirus which is driven by a compassionate approach based on inclusivity.  #compassion #stewardship #interdependence #mindfulness #leadership

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: While we look to immediate solutions during this global crises let us use this heightened awareness of interdependence to plan for the long term.Teaching our future leaders to approach challenges through a compassionate approach driven by inclusiveness is critical for our planet’s sustainability. The biggest problem stemming from the lack of such an approach is that it increases the chance of us being blindsided. Compassion and competition are not mutually exclusive. A spiritual looking person is not necessarily compassionate and a military person is not violent. Compassion is a state of mind where you wish to alleviate the suffering of others. To illustrate my point, one of my close friends Barbara Barrett is the Secretary of the world’s most powerful Air Force and a successful business person. She is driven by compassion. Earlier Barbara introduced me to Arizona State University President Michael Crow to explore areas of mutual interest. His inclusive approach to education driven to have a positive impact on the world is awe inspiring. ASU was named No. 1 in innovation (5 times) by U.S. News and World Report. I would encourage you to share his approach to your own alma mater as we plan for the future.  #stewardship #compassion #interdependence #inclusiveness

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: It is exciting to see the growing interest in mindfulness and sustainability among the younger generation.Two colleagues- Lahna Rae Harper and Magdalena Nadar  - requested me to share my thoughts on this subject.   It was mutually inspiring exchanging different stories, perspectives and experiences over lunch. At the end of our lunch, I shared probably the most important lesson I learned from my parents and teachers. —More important than the mindfulness techniques, is the wish to develop yourself to have the maximum positive benefit to others before your practice. An altruistic motivation allows you to see yourself as another sentient being and the preciousness of life.  Secondary factors like our gender, job, ethnicity, wealth etc. are a reality but will not define you once you set your motivation right. With this altruistic wish the anchor of your mind will be lifted and you will sail in a positive direction. How far you sail will depend on your technique and effort. This wish can play a critical role in connecting sustainability and mindfulness so that they can build of each other.  #stewardship #mindfulness #compassion #inclusivity

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: Mindfulness — What experiences should you expect when you practice?Experience 1 During the first stage, as you pay attention to the object of meditation it appears that your mind is full of thoughts. Normally we are most aware of the aspect of our mind that is engaged with external sensory items.Keep bringing your attention back to the object of concentration for short periods of time.  The number of your thoughts appears to be more than normal. The reality is that this abundance is always there, but now you are noticing them. The analogy used during this phase is that your mind is like a waterfall.    Just notice your thoughts without pausing and move on. Engagement with your thoughts will fuel your distraction.  Feel encouraged by this observation because it means you are now using the aspect of your mind that is inward focused.  #mindfulness #contemplation #compassion

Name: Jeffrey Walker
Text: The synergy resulting from merging ancient mind training techniques to generate compassion and modern economic system will have a transformative positive impact on the world. The two are a natural fit as they complement each other. One releases our mental potential while the other our material potential. The purpose of both systems is to benefit the greater good and they have individually proven to be extremely powerful.At our bank I had the opportunity to share mindfulness and compassion techniques to thousands of colleagues while learning about the intricate world of finance. I am excited to have our next Mindfulness Group luncheon on February 11 to informally share our experiences on banking with compassion. Attendees will include Ric Kay Saad Iqbal John Lilly David S. Miller David Interdonato Jordan Wishnew and Beth Prohow The overall support of our senior leadership and colleagues throughout our organization and outside has been very inspiring.  A special shoutout to our CFO for the Americas Johannes (Johs) Worsoe and former Vice chairman of JPMorgan Chase & Co. Jeffrey Walker for their support.  #leadership #compassion #stewardship #inclusivity

Text: Getting to know Jack Welch early on in my career and watching him in action reinforced my growing belief that the most important asset in business is information. I vividly remember that he never stopped asking questions—torrential, relentless questions—and he instantly grasped the links between one idea and another, even if they were entirely new to him.

Name: Jack Welch
Text: The Patriots are off to a 2-0 start, and if you’re wondering how happy that makes me, take a look at this photo Suzy snapped for our Instagram (@jack_and_suzy) of me watching the first game of the season. I’m in my glory! And look, I’m not going to get too lofty here. But the facts are, I love football for the same reason I love business. They’re both GAMES, and winning happens the same four ways. Play with all your heart and soul. No reservations – be all in. Relentlessly delight your “fans,” – that is, customers. Know and fear your opponents. And finally, have fun. Lots and lots of fun. Celebrate! And if you lose, which happens even to great teams, shake it off, and get ready (and better) for the next go.

Name: Jack Welch
Text: “The summer of mistakes.” That’s what my wife and daughter labeled the past few months, as they endeavored to get familiar with a newly installed home pottery studio. At first, I’ll admit I kind of bristled at their good humor around what did indeed prove to be a litany of blown-up pots and glaze meltdowns. But then I remembered how often in business I urged my teams to experiment rapidly and boldly, assess and evaluate out loud, and move on quickly – all in the name of learning. We can’t be afraid to fail, because the truth is, failure is often the best teacher – in life and at work. If only we could all be as cheerful about it as Suzy and Eve! (For more photos of our ceramics “journey,” you can visit our family Instagram at @jack_and_suzy.)

Name: Jack Welch
Text: As board members, it’s rare to get involved with summer interns, except when the company happens to be a start-up run by your kids, and the interns happen to be extraordinarily talented. Such was the case at Quadio this summer, where Suzy and I were blown away by the passion, intensity, and sheer creativity of the 22 college students from across the country who literally turned down internships in finance and at major record labels to join an upstart music tech company with a huge dream. These interns laid waste to virtually every claim we’ve ever heard lobbed against Millennials. They were sincere, engaged, and tireless, and we’re more optimistic about the future of business than ever. (To learn more about Quadio -- or to follow them, please! — check out  @QuadioMedia on Instagram.) #business #careers #internships

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we’re celebrating WNBA player Layshia Clarendon (all pronouns), point guard for New York Liberty, VP of the WNBPA, and founding member of the WNBA Social Justice Council. Layshia exists at the intersection of many identities: They navigate the world as someone who is multiracial, gay, and non-binary. "The labels that we give ourselves matter. That’s why I claim them so boldly and loudly. Because they are political statements, and there’s power in them." At the beginning of the season, Layshia and their fellow WNBA players launched the Social Justice Council with a mission of raising awareness on issues concerning race, voting rights, and LGBTQ+ advocacy. "Our league is 80% Black women, and we’re dedicating our season to Say Her Name in remembrance of the Black women who’ve been forgotten. Coming back to this season, we knew all eyes were looking at us. It was an opportunity for us to lead … Someone recently said to me that at one time the WNBA was once unimaginable. The most radical ideas aren’t that far-fetched. Can we dare to imagine a world where racism doesn’t pervade everything? I have to, in order to have hope. Because if not, what else am I fighting for? It’s time to think bigger." Thank you, Layshia, for fighting for that world.

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we’re celebrating Dr. Mabel Ping-Hua Lee, leader in securing the right to vote for women in America. She was born in 1897 in Guangzhou, China, and moved to New York’s Chinatown at age nine. In 1912, at age 16, Dr. Lee helped lead a suffrage parade (on horseback!) attended by almost 10,000 people. The New York Times called her “a symbol of the new era, when all women will be free and unhampered.” The same year, she started studying at Barnard College, and wrote feminist essays arguing that voting rights for women were necessary to a successful democracy. Dr. Lee and other Chinese suffragists fought for this right, even though they didn’t benefit from the 19th Amendment: White women won the right to vote in 1920, but Chinese women weren’t able to vote until 1943 due to the Chinese Exclusion Act, which prevented Chinese immigrants from becoming citizens. After graduating from Barnard, Dr. Lee earned her PhD in economics — the first Chinese woman to do so. She took over for her father as director of the First Chinese Baptist Church of NYC until her death in 1966. It’s unknown whether she was ever able to gain citizenship and exercise her right to vote. Thank you, Dr. Lee, for your instrumental and often unacknowledged activism for ALL women in America.

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we’re celebrating L. L. McKinney, the author who started #PublishingPaidMe, a hashtag for white authors to share the amount of their book advances publicly so Black authors and authors of color can compare. Publishing’s systemic biases against Black authors run deep. "What they’re paid. What the marketing is. How their books are treated. How one Black book not reaching its parameters casts a shadow on all Black books and all Black authors, and that’s not the same for our white counterparts." #PublishingPaidMe showed just how dramatic the difference can be, and that well-established Black authors earn comparatively smaller advances than unknown white authors with no track record. For example, Roxanne Gay received only $150,000 for her book following the beloved "Bad Feminist," while Mandy Lyn Catron – a white woman with one viral article under her belt – got a $400,000 advance on her debut. The hashtag led to an anonymous spreadsheet where authors can document their advances, and the trend is clear: When publishers decide to give six-figure advances to debut novels, they’re only giving them to white authors. Thank you, L.L. McKinney, for putting this disparity in the spotlight and advocating for transparency within publishing and beyond.

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we’re celebrating Erica Chidi: doula, lesbian, and CEO of Loom, a platform for sexual and reproductive health education. Erica started out in the fashion industry, but when she was exploring new career paths and learned about doulas, something clicked. "Doulas are like educators and advocates. One of my natural gifts is speaking and helping people understand things … I felt like sexual and reproductive health was this great equalizer. Everyone is operating from a knowledge deficit in this space." Since its launch in 2016, Loom has hosted events and educated on a variety of reproductive health issues, from periods and pregnancy to fertility and abortion. It also offers classes tailored to LGBTQ+ couples who are looking to become parents. "Sexual and reproductive health experiences are interconnected. They’re on a continuum. We should not be siloing postpartum from menopause, sex from fertility, or birth control from miscarriage." Loom raised $3 million in seed funding last week, making Erica one of 35 Black women founders who've raised more than $1 million in venture capital. Hell yeah. Thank you, Erica, for making sexual and reproductive health education inclusive and accessible to all.Photo by Justin Chung

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we’re celebrating Zadie Smith — novelist, essayist, and short-story writer. One of the most essential writers of our time, she’s authored five acclaimed novels — White Teeth, The Autograph Man, On Beauty (which was shortlisted for the Booker Prize and won the Women’s Prize for Fiction), NW, and Swing Time — and two essay collections. Zadie recently released a new collection of ultra-timely essays called Intimations, written entirely during lockdown. “Essay is, for me, an attempt at a kind of clarity. I have a very messy and chaotic mind, but when I’m writing an essay I find I can exert a bit more control over it.” Zadie says this book was her “way of doing something … I was stuck with the only thing I can do, which is write. And I suddenly thought of it as a way of participating, of raising money, of being active.” The royalties from Intimations will go to the Equal Justice Initiative and the COVID Emergency Relief Fund for New York. “I wanted to try and give readers the thing I try to fight for myself, which is a space to think your own thoughts, whatever they might be.” Thank you for writing (and sharing) your words with the world, Zadie.Photo: Dominique Nabokov

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we’re celebrating Rhiana Gunn-Wright, national climate policy expert and co-author of the Green New Deal. For Ms. Gunn-Wright, environmental justice work has always been personal, tied to health problems in her community: She was raised by her mother, grandmother, and extended family on the South Side of Chicago where a disproportionate amount of people — including herself — had asthma. Later in life, she realized it was linked to air pollution in the area. She went on to become a Rhodes Scholar, graduate magna cum laude from Yale, intern for former First Lady Michelle Obama (NBD), and lend her expertise to various campaigns and organizations. In 2018, Ms. Gunn-Wright was recruited by New Consensus to co-author the Green New Deal, a 10-year plan to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions while creating new jobs — which was introduced in Congress by Senator Edward Markey and Rep. Alexandria Ocasio-Cortez. “The last time I went home, I visited with my grandmother, Bertha Gunn. She told me: ‘You’re doing the work I always wanted to do. No one would listen to me, but they’re listening to you.’ That makes me happy.” Thank you, Ms. Gunn-Wright, for your work toward (literally) saving the world.For more like this, check out ellevest.com/magazine

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we’re celebrating Indya Moore (they/them) — non-binary actor, model, and trans rights activist. Indya stars as Angel Evangelista on "Pose," the barrier-breaking FX series that puts NYC’s Black and Latinx queer communities of the late 80s front and center. It also features more transgender actors than any scripted show in history. "I can’t fathom the magnitude of inspiration and hope that these stories give trans people and queer people." Indya was raised a Jehovah's Witness, and their parents weren’t accepting when Indya started showing their feminine self — so at age 14, they left home and entered the foster care system in the Bronx. Indya built up a following on Instagram and started modeling, which eventually led to their audition for "Pose" — and when they got the role, they knew their life was going to change. They’ve since reconciled with their mother (who has finally accepted Indya for who they are), become passionate about being a healing voice for marginalized communities, and landed a spot on 2019’s Time 100 Most Influential People list. "I don’t know who I am outside of someone who’s just trying to be free and find safety for myself and for others." Thank you, Indya. #NonbinaryAwarenessWeekPhoto: GettyFor more: ellevest.com/magazine

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: #Elated to share that Rethink Impact, LP Impact has closed on a record $182M Fund II (total AUM is nearly $300M) making it the largest, US VC investing in female-led tech companies tackling global challenges…and in case you’ve been living under a rock recently, we have plenty of challenges to solve these days! Our backers are diverse: 65% female, from nearly 40 states, and includes Pivotal Ventures, the investment company founded by Melinda Gates, the Ford Foundation, the W.K. Kellogg Foundation, university endowments, and significant financial institutions such as UBS. This money is timely as an unfortunate side effect of the COVID pandemic has been a 40% YOY decrease in the percentage of female-led, VC funded deals (PitchBook). There is so much to be done, and we are missing out by not incorporating broader points of view into which ideas get funded, which problems get solved, and which communities benefit (or don’t).  WANT TO HELP?! Entrepreneurs deserve to hear that this capital exists, so please feel free to reach out to your networks to amplify this work in any way you see fit. We are grateful!https://nyti.ms/3fqHFI9Heidi Krauel Patel #startups #femalefounders #tech

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: We founded Ellevest to fight gender wealth inequality and get more money in the hands of women+. Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This week’s #FinancialFeministFriday spotlight, Ianne Fields Stewart (she/they), is a Black, queer, transfeminine storyteller and performer work at the intersection of theatre and activism. Ianne has appeared on "Pose!" and "The Bold Type," and is a theatrical consultant, playwright, director, teaching artist, choreographer, and community organizer — wow. They are also founder of The Okra Project, a grassroots organization that combats food insecurity by bringing free home-cooked meals to Black trans people in New York and Philadelphia. "The Okra Project really has become something in the community that people can lean on when they need to. It has been really humbling and an honor to do this — creating and curating this space for Black trans people specifically." Ianne, we applaud you for the incredible work you’re doing as both an artist and an activist, and thank you for creating spaces where Black trans people are nourished, affirmed, and valued. Support her and The Okra Project here: theokraproject.com

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we're celebrating Danielle Geathers, sophomore mechanical engineering major at Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT). Danielle was recently voted student body president — the first time a Black woman has been elected to the position in MIT's history. Her platform with running mate Yu Jing Chen focused on unity, equity, and authenticity. "A Black woman in that role will squash every perception that MIT is still mostly white and male. The immediate image of that will make MIT a more welcoming and inclusive place." Before running for office, Danielle established a program called "The Talented Ten," to increase Black women applicants at MIT by pairing high school juniors with current students. "I understand the value that Black women bring to campus while also understanding the tremendous loss the MIT community experiences when a qualified, underrepresented minority student chooses to not enroll." Absolutely. Congratulations, Danielle!

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: If you’ve developed a TikTok habit since stay-at-home orders went into effect, you're probably familiar with this week’s #FinancialFeministFriday — Tabitha Brown. She’s an actress by trade, but recently became a viral sensation: Tabitha’s daughter convinced her to join TikTok in March to be "like a mom" to the platform's primarily teen audience. Since then, her vegan food tutorials and daily affirmation videos have earned her over two million followers. "So many people are dealing with anxiety and hopelessness during this time. That's why I started." Unfortunately, she’s all too familiar with this experience. Tabitha went vegan after a long period of illness in 2016, when she woke up with a headache that never went away — causing anxiety, chronic fatigue, and depression. She views cooking as a form of sustenance, but also self-care, and advocates for trusting yourself and making your own decisions in everything you do. "Food always gets people first, because we need it to survive. But more than food, we need love." Thank you, Tabitha, for providing a source of comfort in a time where it’s desperately needed — and for teaching us how to make the best avocado toast ... with garlic powder, of course, "'cause that’s your business."For more like this: ellevest.com/magazine

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: This #FinancialFeministFriday, we’re celebrating Maria Antoineta Alva — aka “Toni,” the 35-year-old finance minister of Peru who’s achieved near rockstar-status as a result of her pandemic response. Toni is the daughter of Jorge Alva, rector of the Universidad Nacional de Ingeniería, and was exposed to extreme poverty in Peru when she accompanied him on his travels as a child. She became determined to change things, and went on to graduate with a masters in public administration from Harvard in 2014. Now, she’s the only woman in President Martin Vizcarra’s cabinet. Some questioned Toni’s abilities when she was appointed, claiming she only made it there because of her father — not because of her years of experience. “It’s impossible not to think that was just machismo. If I were a man, that wouldn’t necessarily have been called into question.” She’s currently at the helm of an ambitious coronavirus recovery package that’s winning praise for its aid to small businesses and ordinary citizens. She accomplished this by negotiating with her colleagues for solutions like cash handouts, payroll subsidies, and government-backed business loans, none of which had ever been previously attempted in Peru. Thank you, Toni, for putting your citizens first. We can’t wait to see what you do next.

Name: Sallie Krawcheck
Text: Hard and yet easy to believe it’s been two years since I started at Ellevest. Every job has its ups and downs but this one has had SO many more ups! Still loving the work I (really, we) do and that I get to help people and change lives every day, all while on a grand adventure with spectacular colleagues- seriously y’all, these are some of my favorite people on earth and I am lucky enough to get to work with them every day. Special shout out to Sallie Krawcheck for getting such a special company off the ground and maintaining an amazing culture through all those ups and downs👸🏼🦸🏼‍♀️ 🍻🍷🍷Cheers to many more fun, life changing, getting sh*t done years ahead of us!

Text: Seven months in, what does science tell us about the Great Fomite Freakout? You can get Covid from surfaces, yes, but it's much harder than most of us think. Wash your hands and clean door handles in hospitals. But don't Lysol your mail.

Text: Twitter should never let people share hacked materials! Right?Wait, what then about the police docs this past June? Or the Panama Papers? The company's confusing backpedaling is not a help. But there is a tough line to define here.

Name: Nicholas Thompson
Text: My guess:30% of the outrage at Twitter over the NYP blocking is genuine and based on principle.30% is just trying to work the refs. 40% is faux outrage because it indirectly drives people to the original story

Name: Nicholas Thompson
Text: The Ajit Pai FCC until today: we need a light regulatory touch to keep innovation going.The Ajit Pai FCC today: the president is mad at Twitter and now we’re going to dress up some bogus arguments and rewrite section 230￼

Name: Nicholas Thompson
Text: The most interesting thing in tech: Twitter and Facebook both took action when a news story that seemed potentially like a misinformation campaign started to go viral. This got them both in a lot of trouble! And it probably drove more people to the original story. But honestly, though Twitter’s response was a mess, I felt like Facebook handled it all pretty well. #mostinterestingthingintech

Name: Nicholas Thompson
Text: Chaos and collapse are not a predestined future. After some delays and reconsideration, I'm pleased to be launching this endeavor today with more than 70 members including Anne-Marie Slaughter, Dr. Parag Khanna, Ian Bremmer, Tyler Cowen, R.P. Eddy, Steve Clemons, Ashton Applewhite, Bina Venkataraman, Peniel Joseph, Ted Johnson, LP.D., James Fallows, Kishore Mahbubani, Adam Grant, Roy Bahat, Nicholas Thompson many more. The Progress Network is a non-profit platform dedicated to highlighting, amplifying and connecting voices that point to a more constructive future in our dystopian era. Please follow here, on Twitter, Facebook, the web, promote and react, but above all, please engage.

Styling be damned...for now! #photographer #interiordesign #artist #photography #covid #realinteriors

Name: Nicholas Thompson
Text: The most interesting thing in tech: Facebook is going to ban political ads after the election. Why? The reasons are more complicated and interesting than you might think. It’s not about money, at least not in a direct way since political ads are a miniscule portion of FB’s business. Ultimately, I think it’s a good decision, but a small one. Because political ads are such a tiny part of Facebook. #mostinterestingthingintech

What books or authors you would recommend?

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: The climate is changing much faster than anticipated, and without swift action, the harm that we are doing will be irreversible. Despite the scale of the challenge ahead, I have cause to hope that businesses can play a key role in leading global change and finding solutions to the climate crisis.

Name: Indra Nooyi

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Happy International #DayOfTheGirl. Girls are magical, and should be celebrated everywhere! Deeming girls “less than” or inferior for the last several thousand years, has only held back half the global innovation and disrupted the balance of earth. Girls are amazing. They’re resilient, brilliant, spunky and fearless. And… they are a big part of our future. 💪 After three amazing boys, we had a baby girl. When Tepper arrived – she was not to be messed with from the very start. We always say Tepper is half warrior, half princess because she’s fearlessly herself. When I look at her, I see my mother, my grandmothers and all the other women who came before her who made it possible for her to have a future filled with possibilities. When I think about empowering my daughter to fulfill her great potential, it means she feels supported to believe in herself, to cultivate confidence, and that she has the courage to pursue her passions and dreams regardless of her gender. I hope this for ALL little girls around the world. Throw a 👍💪👊or 💥 if you agree!! #DayOfTheGirl

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: As Mary Barra poignantly states in her recent article, “listening is the singular first step on the path to any positive change in the world.” Now more than ever, it’s imperative that we heed Mary’s advice and examine how we can be more thoughtful and attentive in our daily interactions. What stands out to me about this piece is that Mary goes beyond lip service—she offers concrete ways business leaders can foster more meaningful conversations across their organizations. From General Motors’s “diagonal” conversations between leaders and employees to the company’s “Blue Table Talks” around diversity, inclusion, and unconscious bias, Mary paints a compelling blueprint for how we can all cultivate change and understanding through dialogue.

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Last week, many of you so openly shared your struggles, and the small joys, of being a work parent during the COVID pandemic. As our lives have changed so drastically over the past few months, it’s essential that we remain focused on understanding the challenges and impacts that have resulted for people all over the world and then get to work on solving them. By sharing some of the most common themes from your comments and experiences, I hope that we can learn from one another and continue this critical discussion.

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Friends & colleagues,I’m excited to share the news that as of today, October 5th, 2020, I am joining The Clorox Company as Executive Vice President, Chief Growth Officer, reporting to CEO Linda Rendle. In this role, I’ll have executive oversight of the company’s International business, as well as global responsibility for Marketing, R&D, Sales, the New Business & Partnership Office and the Sustainability Center. As many of you know, I recently served as president of Nestlé Coffee Partners (NCP). NCP is a division of Nestlé U.S. with revenues of nearly $3 billion, representing great brands like Starbucks, Nescafé, Chameleon, and Teavana Tea. I feel privileged to have been a part of the journey at NCP, and I'm proud of what we achieved together, including record sales and share growth in 2018 and 2019. After more than 20 years of work on building brands and businesses at some of the world’s most admired companies, I'm looking forward to this next chapter, and to joining the amazing team of leaders at Clorox! The Clorox Company is at one of those pivotal points that come once in a generation. We have a unique opportunity to accelerate growth while being a stronger force for good – for our teams, consumers, shareholders and society! Onward! #growth #innovation #leadership

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: This month we reached and passed the milestone of 1,000 Awards received by PepsiCo since the creation of its #Design & #Innovation function about 8 years ago. To receive this kind of recognition with products and brands designed for the mass market is not an easy challenge. Often these #awards focus on niche and high end brands and on specific industries and product categories. To create something that is inspiring and breakthrough, that is cool and unique, but that is also able to be understood and appreciated every day by billions of people worldwide, generating every year dozens of billions of $ in sales, is insanely difficult. Everyday we work hard to strike that perfect balance between useful and engaging, functional and beautiful, aspirational and commercially viable. For this achievement I want to thank:- The organizations and the juries behind these awards, for recognizing projects that do not belong to the more traditional categories of design, freeing up design from an old and suffocating definition and enabling our community of designers to touch so many more industries, with a long term positive impact on our society and the planet. Because our world needs design more than ever, in every category, in every product, in every solution... (continued in comments)

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Yesterday we outlined our newest sustainability goals. And while they are ambitious, they are also necessary to combat climate change and preserve and regenerate our natural resources. The challenge we face as a society is significant, so we must respond together with significant action. This is an opportunity for us to make an even greater difference. We’re targeting zero emissions across our global operations by 2040 and, with the Walmart Foundation, helping protect, manage or restore 50 million acres of land and one million square miles of ocean. Each of us has a role to play. In this effort your actions matter. What will you do? https://lnkd.in/eazifJD

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Surreal!I’m struggling to find words again today.   The only one that feels apt is surreal. That’s a punt though, isn’t it? It’s a word used when words simply can’t explain. 2020 has been surreal. Coronavirus is surreal. Partisan politics is surreal.  Food insecurity here (of all places) is surreal. The deaths of so many giants and so many little ones is surreal.  And yet, so is the generosity that I see every day in countless ways. So too is the selfless service of my many, many partners, inextricable from any good achieved.  And, so is the fact that the grand daughter of sharecroppers with extraordinary PARENTS (emphasis earned) from a very small town who had very big dreams of service is somehow on the Times 100 List HERE and NOW is, in a word, SURREAL.  #humbled#grateful#bethechange#

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Today is National Voter Registration day – a day designed to encourage U.S. voters who are not currently registered, to get registered to be ready for November 3. There are far too many citizens who fail to vote. When we think about the great sacrifices made by so many to earn the right to vote – people died for that right – it’s clear that more of us should be voting and doing it with passion.

It was inspiring to hear him speak at #HPReinvent last week. Voices like Paul's are needed now more than ever. #sustainability #climateweek

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Don Kendall was an extraordinary man who lived an extraordinary life. I had the honor of getting to know him even before I became CEO of PepsiCo. When I joined the company in 1994, Don still had the office next to mine, and we became fast friends. I was regularly in awe of his sharp instincts and worldly wisdom, and although he was internationally famous, he carried himself with the unpretentious air of his roots. Even after I stepped down, I would still see Don often, and if anything, our friendship only deepened as we bonded over the experience of being former CEOs. Even though he officially retired more than 30 years ago, Don never stopped bleeding PepsiCo blue, and his passion for the company and its people never waned.  To me, Don was more than our first CEO, more than a dear friend and a cherished mentor—he was truly one of a kind. Raj and I send our deepest condolences to his wife, Bim, his children and grandchildren, and the entire Kendall family on this monumental loss.

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Women don’t belong just on pedestals. They don’t belong on the sidelines or behind the accomplishments of others. They belong in the ring—fighting. Ruth Bader Ginsburg dedicated her life’s work to this belief, and generations of women past, present, and future are stronger for it. We lost a genuine heroine yesterday, and it hurts. But as we mourn, we must also make sure that our gloves are ready, so that we can put them back on and fight to keep her legacy alive.

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Saw the ex CEO of a fitness brand allegedly disparaged a male colleague who was contemplating taking paternity leave... So I wrote this on Olympia Ohanian's 3rd bday bc we need to end this absurd stigma against men taking paternity leave.After multiple surgeries that my wife barely survived, what kind of man WOULDN'T absolutely want to take paternity leave (if he's lucky enough to have access) to be there for his fam? Besides, it it should be available for EVERY American. Not just wealthy CEOs + founders like me.And while we're on the subject.. there's a black maternal health crisis in the US and COVID has only exacerbated it. Shoutout to members of Congress like Congresswoman Blunt Rochester who are doing the work to fight + fix this, but there's A LOT to be done.

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: Having the opportunity to become a curious and voracious reader should be universal – but it’s something that so many, especially children, never have the resources to do. On #InternationalLiteracyDay, it’s important to recognize how inequalities of all kinds can impact our communities - a theme that Matthew Desmond explores remarkably in his book, Evicted. This is a painful but essential study of how and why poverty and human suffering are the too-often ignored results of inequality and economic exploitation in American cities. This book is a must-read: https://lnkd.in/dM9uynC

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: After two meaningful years, I have decided to step down as Chief Marketing Officer of Facebook .  This has been a challenging year for all and an especially reflective year for me, following my mother’s passing before the lockdown. Given the historical inflection point we are in regarding racial justice, I have decided to dedicate 100% of my time to diversity, inclusion and equity. Though these issues have been core to my personal purpose and my work for many years, I want to make them my sole focus. I will devote the next chapter of my professional life to helping companies and agencies in the marketing and advertising industries accelerate their transformation and to drive holistic and profound change. It is a time for reckoning for our nation and industry, and it is time for me to play a more active part in accelerating change. In leaving Facebook, I am nothing but grateful. I believe in Facebook’s mission, and COVID has demonstrated the platforms at their best. As the company evolves, striking the right balance between preserving freedom of speech and eliminating hateful speech on the platforms is a generation-defining question that must continue to be addressed. I know the company and its leadership agree on the centrality of this important task. GRACIAS!

Name: Indra Nooyi

As the President of PepsiCo Global Beverage Group and Founder & Managing Partner of Rethink Food NYC, Brad has built a reputation for building business models that drive transformation and unlock growth. He knows first-hand how CMOs can strategically navigate the complexity of today’s marketing tech stack and how they can thrive through the dramatically different world COVID has presented. We look forward to bringing his passion to our clients.

Name: Indra Nooyi
Text: 5 years today with ULTA. That’s 1,825 days, 57 brand partner events, 10 21 Days of Beauty, 10 Liter Sales, 6 promotions/DORs, 5 BCRF Campaigns, 5 Holiday seasons, 4 different stores, 4 districts, 2 different states, 3 ULTA baby showers, 2 ULTA weddings, 2 Save the Children campaigns, and 1 General Manager’s Conference. In that time I have met countless amazing people who I feel honored to have been a part of their ULTA journey. I’ve laughed until my stomach hurt, I’ve held people while they cried, I’ve forced myself to look outside of my comfort zone and push to turn good into great. I’ve seen first hand how ULTA cares about their employees and empower women, POC, plus size, and prove that men can wear makeup and look AMAZING wearing it. They’ve tackled issues like racism and homophobia with education and inclusion. They’ve given grants to associates in tough times and donate to organizations that need us the most. To find a company that truly VALUES you and celebrates your worth is exactly why I work here. Thank you ULTA. Truly and deeply. #ulta #thepossibilitiesarebeautiful Mary Dillon Kecia Steelman (she/her/hers) Vanessa Ortiz Christa Crowe Diana Passaro-Betancourt Shana Alvarez Rasinia Pecunia CHRISTIAN COLLAZO Aliyah Shakoor Shana Alvarez Andrea Barger Lynsei Paladino

Looking Forward: The podcast that focuses on marketplace and societal trends, how they affect YOU, and how you might benefit from knowing about them.#podcast #business #investingtips #jobseekers #trends2020 #education

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Graduating with student loan #debt is never really ideal, but two things can help. One, it's not a terrible amount, and two, you have a good head on your shoulders. #studentloans

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The bad news is that you've been laid off. The good news is that you've done an amazing job of saving for #retirement. So now the question becomes which account should you be tapping first to get you through this period?

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Uncertainty on Wall Street after President #Trump tested positive for #COVID. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss the possible impact of his diagnosis on the economy.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The financial services industry can be very hard to understand, especially when it's full of jargon, so if you ever need help making sense of what's what, I'm more than happy to help! #fiduciary #personalfinance

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Okay, this may go down as the worst advice given in 2020! An emailer was told by his "advisor" that they should be "hiding" their assets inside an #annuity so they'll be able to qualify for financial aid. Folks, sometimes you can't make it up. #annuities

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: How near-historic low mortgage rates, fewer homes for sale and bidding wars are driving the housing market during the pandemic. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss how homebuyers can navigate the process.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: One of the things that really gets my blood boiling is when so called financial advisors are pitching products that are in no way appropriate. One such product is the Indexed Universal Life Insurance policy.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Having some extra cash flow is a good thing, and assuming you've got all your other bases covered, it means you've got some extra money to invest. Now the question becomes, how should you invest it?

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Having some extra cash flow is a good thing, and assuming you've got all your other bases covered, it means you've got some extra money to invest. Now the question becomes, how should you invest it?

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Having some extra cash flow is a good thing, and assuming you've got all your other bases covered, it means you've got some extra money to invest. Now the question becomes, how should you invest it?

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: When the you know what was hitting the fan back in March, a lot of people were frozen with fear. Six months later, and even though there's been quite a rebound on Wall Street, many are still unsure how to proceed.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Having some extra cash flow is a good thing, and assuming you've got all your other bases covered, it means you've got some extra money to invest. Now the question becomes, how should you invest it?

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The coronavirus is leaving its mark on colleges and universities, perhaps permanently. With schools work hard to keep COVID off-campus, 13% percent of colleges will offer online-only classes, while 35% will offer a mix of virtual and socially-distanced in-person classes. Here's my piece for CBS Sunday Morning on how educators and students are adjusting to an on-campus experience that will be, as one university professor describes it, “some combination of a monastery and a minimum security prison.”

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: A July jobs report that saw 1.8 million new jobs created and a lowering of the national unemployment rate comes amid negotiations in Washington over a second stimulus package. However, the pace of hiring appears to be slowing as more states slow down or roll back their re-openings. I joined CBS This Morning: Saturday to discuss what this all means, and what the numbers say about the future of the U.S. economy.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The economy added 1.8 million jobs in July, dropping the unemployment rate to 10.2%. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss the numbers and whether a second wave of layoffs is expected at small businesses.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: More than 50 million people have applied for unemployment since the pandemic began, and nearly half of U.S. workers get their health insurance through work. One study found that an estimated 5.4 million American workers lost their health insurance in just three months. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss coverage alternatives and what Americans who lost their coverage can do.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Check out my chat with Eskalera Inc. CEO Dane E. Holmes as we dive into the ongoing conversation around workplace diversity and how to make it better.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Two key reports show the impact of the pandemic. I joined CBS This Morning to explain what the historic drop in GDP and rise in weekly unemployment claims mean for the country's economy.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The pandemic is putting estate planning into focus. I joined CBS This Morning to explain why having a will, health care proxy and power of attorney documents are so important right now.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The economy added another 4.8 million jobs in June, dropping the new unemployment rate to 11.1%. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss whether the data indicates the beginning of economic recovery.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The nation's pending home sales jumped a record 44.3% in May, according to the National Association of Realtors. It's the highest one-month gain in the history of the index, which began in January 2001. I joined CBS This Morning to explain how the pandemic is impacting the housing market and why home prices remain high despite record low mortgage rates.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: More than 1.5 million Americans filed for unemployment last week. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss what the latest numbers mean and what soaring retail sales could indicate for an economic recovery.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: More than 1.5 million Americans filed for unemployment last week, bringing the total jobless claims to over 44 million in the last 12 weeks. I joined CBS This Morning to explain why weekly job losses continue despite a big gain in May and why the Labor Department's own data is confusing.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: We’ve all made some financial mistakes, but hopefully through reading, listening to podcasts, and learning from our previous mistakes, we can move forward and make smarter moves with our money. That was the gist of my conversation with the How to Money guys. Check it out here:

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The U.S. economy added 2.5 million jobs in May, stunning experts who anticipated losses on the scale of the Great Depression. I joined CBS This Morning: Saturday to discuss the new 13.3% unemployment rate and the outlook for Americans and the country as it recovers from the coronavirus pandemic.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: In a surprising turn, the economy added 2.5 million jobs in May, dropping the new unemployment rate to 13.3%. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss the reasons behind the unexpected positive data.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The coronavirus pandemic has us worrying not only about our health, but also about money. I joined Sam Sanders on NPR to discuss the current economic crisis and how it's affecting different generations.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: More than 2.1 million Americans filed for unemployment last week, bringing the number of jobless claims to more than 40 million over the last 10 weeks. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss which industries are scrambling to hire some of those workers.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: More than 38 million Americans filed for unemployment over the last nine weeks. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss what this means for overall unemployment and new projections about how long the financial fallout could last.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Nearly 3 million Americans filed new unemployment benefit claims last week, according to the Department of Labor on Thursday. That means more than 36 million workers have filed for unemployment benefits in the past eight weeks. I joined CBS This Morning to explain the significance of the numbers.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Check out my chat with Daniel Roth, editor in chief at LinkedIn, as we talk about how remote work could be here to stay for some as well as advice for college graduates entering an uncertain job market.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: A record 20.5 million Americans lost jobs in April, according to an unemployment report released by the Labor Department Friday. The U.S. unemployment rate jumped to 14.7%, the worst since the Great Depression. I joined CBS This Morning to unpack the staggering figure and discuss what it means for the future of the country.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The U.S. economy lost 20.5 million jobs in April amid the coronavirus pandemic. The national unemployment rate soared to 14.7% last month, the highest since the Great Depression. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: For the seventh straight week, unemployment claims are in the millions. More than 33 million Americans have now filed claims for unemployment benefits since mid-March. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss what this means to the economy and which Americans are being hit hardest.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: 8 Money Experts on How to Survive This Volatile Economy, via AARP.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: As Americans shelter at home, everyday shopping habits have changed, perhaps permanently, with online grocery sales way up, and department stores struggling to survive. For CBS Sunday Morning, I spoke with Brookfield Properties executive Stephanie Brager; Jan Whitaker, who has written about the history of department stores; and Scott Galloway, a professor of marketing at New York University, about the future of retail.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The Labor Department's latest report says roughly 3.8 million Americans filed for unemployment last week. The figure, comparatively lower than the last five weeks, brings the six-week total to 30 million U.S. workers filing jobless claims. The devastating total reflects the coronavirus pandemic's effect on the economy, despite trillions of dollars in stimulus spending. I joined CBS This Morning to break down the staggering figures.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Many companies are being forced to adapt to the financial impact from the coronavirus pandemic. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss the future of business.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: This week saw another significant spike in unemployment claims. Just over 4 million Americans filed for unemployment, bringing the pandemic's five-week total to roughly 26 million people without jobs. President Trump recently signed off on nearly $500 billion extra in addition to the initial coronavirus stimulus package, designed to help mitigate the pandemic's blow to the economy. I joined CBS This Morning to discuss what all of this means for the U.S. and American workers.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The Labor Department says 4.4 million Americans filed for unemployment, bringing the total number to roughly 26 million jobless claims in the last five weeks since the pandemic began. I break down the number and the pandemic's impact on the economy on CBS This Morning.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Charities are struggling to find new ways to help record numbers of Americans who are out of work during the pandemic, adding to the millions who already experience food insecurity. I talked with food pantries in New York, Maine and California, whose work in their communities is being strained, by increased demand, costlier supplies, and a reduced workforce, and yet has never been more valuable.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: More than 5 million people filed for unemployment in the last week as coronavirus lockdowns continue through the country. Although the number is lower than the previous two weeks, the figure rounds out a grim four-week span in which over 20 million Americans filed jobless claims. I joined CBS This Morning to talk about what that figure means for the U.S.'s road to economic recovery.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Yours truly and Brian Cooley from CNET on how to survive your pandemic unemployment.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Just over half of all American workers are employed by small businesses (companies with 500 or fewer employees), and according to the U.S. Chamber of Commerce, nearly a quarter of those small businesses could close permanently within two months without a financial lifeline. I chatted with some small business owners who are trying to maintain their (and their employees') livelihoods in a time of tremendous uncertainty.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Over 15 million Americans applied for unemployment benefits over the last three weeks, a devastating reflection of the coronavirus pandemic's impact on the economy. Many people, even those who do not know if they will still be employed, are looking for information to help navigate the uncertainty. I joined CBS This Morning to respond to some critical personal finance questions.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Have your finances been impacted by the coronavirus? Do you own a small business? Are you filing for unemployment? Tomorrow morning I’ll be answering *your* questions on CBS This Morning. Email your question to coronavirus@cbsnews.com.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The Labor Department's newest weekly jobless claims report shows 6.6 million Americans applying for unemployment over the last week. The previous two weeks saw around 10 million U.S. workers filing, a grim record that reflects the coronavirus pandemic's massive weight on the economy. I joined CBS This Morning to break down what the latest numbers mean for workers today and the future of the U.S. economy.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: I joined Face the Nation to explain why the U.S. economy will not look the same after COVID.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Over 9 million Americans applied for unemployment in the last two weeks, a grim record that reflects the coronavirus pandemic’s toll on the U.S. economy. I joined CBS This Morning to break down the virus’ impact on the economy and what the current numbers could mean for American workers’ futures.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The Labor Department has announced that it received over 6 million jobless claims in one week, significantly higher than the previous week's record-setting 3.3 million. I joined CBS This Morning to weigh in on what the latest report means for the U.S. economy and what out-of-work Americans can do to help themselves and their families.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Retail giants Macy's, Kohl's and Gap have announced widespread furloughs amid soaring reports of coronavirus cases in the U.S. The pandemic has sent the economy into free fall, with massive layoffs and small business closures happening across the country as a result of precautions to slow the disease's spread. I joined CBS This Morning to talk about this latest hit to workers and what it means for the future of the economy as the pandemic continues.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: New unemployment claims for the most recent measured week totaled 3.28 million. Facing an unprecedented event, the government is taking unprecedented measures as America's economy hits the crisis stage. But there are also firms that are hiring in response to the pandemic. Here’s my piece for CBS Sunday Morning.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The CARES Act, signed into law on Friday, is the largest economic stimulus package in history. The bill allocates $2.2 trillion to people and businesses negatively impacted by the coronavirus’ effects on the economy. I joined CBS This Morning to explain if and how the stimulus will affect you.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: New details surrounding the coronavirus pandemic and its impact on the economy come every day. CBS This Morning assembled a panel of experts, including yours truly, to answer viewers' most pressing questions to make sure you have the information you need to navigate the new normal.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: More than 3 million U.S. workers filed for unemployment last week, making it the worst week for unemployment claims in over 50 years. Over half of all U.S. states have ordered nonessential businesses to close, putting millions more at risk of being laid off or not work enough hours to survive. I joined CBS This Morning to put the numbers into context.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: The Senate's $2 trillion coronavirus relief package is expected to pass sometime Wednesday before being sent to the House. The historic bill is designed to help workers and businesses affected by the damage the coronavirus pandemic is causing the economy, including people who have already lost their jobs as a result. I joined CBS This Morning to talk about what that means for you.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: As the global economy enters an unprecedented shutdown during the coronavirus outbreak, I talked with Nobel Prize-winning economics expert Joseph Stiglitz; Michael Goodman, president of the investment management firm Wealthstream Advisors Inc.; and Jake Dell, owner of New York City's venerable Katz's Delicatessen, about weathering the economic storm. I also spoke with improv actor Ed Herbstman, whose Magnet Theater, shuttered by the pandemic, is now being forced to improvise.

Name: Jill Schlesinger
Text: Nationally, unemployment claims are skyrocketing. The federal government is trying to put a band-aid on the financial bleeding, work to send out stimulus checks of $1,000 per adult and $500 per child.

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: Proud to accept the Pledge to America’s Workers Presidential Award today at the White House on behalf of Lockheed Martin for our commitment to invest in workforce development programs. In 2018, Lockheed Martin pledged to deliver 8,000 new workforce development opportunities over the course of five years, and we have already reached over 50% of our commitment.  Listen to two of our former interns tell the story of how their internship experiences with our team helped them kickstart their careers at Lockheed Martin.https://lmt.co/3hVYaw0

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: A year ago, Lockheed Martin and the Derco team hosted President Trump at our Milwaukee, Wisconsin facility. It was pleasure work alongside Derco Aerospace General Manager Peter Winkler to bring this event together, and you can read his behind-the-scenes perspective here.

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: Lockheed Martin is committed to the continued growth of our nation’s pipeline of advanced manufacturing workers. Through various workforce and apprenticeship initiatives, our team is creating multiple pathways to a successful career in aerospace and defense.

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: I am honored to be recognized today by the Executives’ Club of Chicago as the 2020 International Executive of the Year. It is a privilege to accept this prestigious award on behalf of the 110,000 men and women of Lockheed Martin. It’s their ingenuity, energy, and teamwork that make such an award possible and make our company truly special. Watch my interview here: https://bit.ly/2VyUdFd

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: For the past seven years, it has been an absolute privilege to serve as Lockheed Martin's CEO, work alongside such innovative, focused, and dedicated men and women. In my time as the company’s leader, I’ve been continually inspired by my colleagues, as we delivered on our customers’ priorities, helped solve some of the world’s most complex challenges, and made a difference in the communities where we live and work. I transition to my role as Lockheed Martin’s executive chairman with optimism and confidence, knowing the company is in good hands with James Taiclet. Throughout his storied career in the military and in industry, he has displayed a commitment to people and demonstrated a strong sense of vision and purpose. I look forward to continued collaboration with him, as we work together to usher in a new chapter for our team. To the 110,000 men and women of Lockheed Martin around the globe – thank you for the opportunity to serve as your leader and partner in achieving our critical missions.

In my time as the company’s leader, I’ve been continually inspired by my colleagues, as we delivered on our customers’ priorities, helped solve some of the world’s most complex challenges, and made a difference in the communities where we live and work. I transition to my role as Lockheed Martin’s executive chairman with optimism and confidence, knowing the company is in good hands with James Taiclet. Throughout his storied career in the military and in industry, he has displayed a commitment to people and demonstrated a strong sense of vision and purpose. I look forward to continued collaboration with him, as we work together to usher in a new chapter for our team. To the 110,000 men and women of Lockheed Martin around the globe – thank you for the opportunity to serve as your leader and partner in achieving our critical missions.

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: The best part of starting a new job is building relationships with new colleagues. On my second day as Lockheed Martin’s CEO, I had the opportunity to spend the day with the executive leadership team at our headquarters in Bethesda. I also welcomed our new Business Transformation SVP Yvonne Hodge with an elbow bump. We had a great day talking about the future.

In my time as the company’s leader, I’ve been continually inspired by my colleagues, as we delivered on our customers’ priorities, helped solve some of the world’s most complex challenges, and made a difference in the communities where we live and work. I transition to my role as Lockheed Martin’s executive chairman with optimism and confidence, knowing the company is in good hands with James Taiclet. Throughout his storied career in the military and in industry, he has displayed a commitment to people and demonstrated a strong sense of vision and purpose. I look forward to continued collaboration with him, as we work together to usher in a new chapter for our team. To the 110,000 men and women of Lockheed Martin around the globe – thank you for the opportunity to serve as your leader and partner in achieving our critical missions.

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: Yesterday, I had the pleasure of showcasing the Lockheed Martin-built Orion spacecraft, which will carry astronauts to lunar orbit, to President Trump and Vice President Pence. Both NASA Administrator Jim Bridenstine and I were also proud to discuss the progress our teams are making and how Orion will be a cornerstone of the #Artemis missions taking the first woman and the next man to the surface of the Moon. We wish the NASA-SpaceX team good luck on Saturday’s scheduled launch. We look forward to watching. #LaunchAmerica

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: Across our team, we’ve emphasized to leaders the need to remain engaged with employees, learn about their needs, offer words of encouragement, and look for ways to provide accommodations where appropriate, as the fight against #COVID continues. It is critical we remain mindful of the mental and emotional toll stemming from the widespread disruptions and uncertainty the pandemic has caused.In partnership with our communities and customers, we’re striving to stay connected, give back, and support those in need. For more, read my blog on how we’re supporting well-being and building community during COVID.

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: Today I had the opportunity to speak with Maria Bartiromo from Fox Business Network about Lockheed Martin’s continued efforts to support our workforce, customers, and supply chain partners during #COVID. We remain dedicated to protecting our employees and their families, adding jobs to the economy, helping the medical community, and supporting our suppliers to deliver on our commitments to the United States Department of Defense and our nation’s allies around the world.  You can watch the discussion here: https://fxn.ws/3ayGF0Z

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: Our friends at Lockheed Martin continue to demonstrate a dedication to serving communities. They announced they will provide support efforts for healthcare workers and its employees in the supply chain segment. Thank you for serving those around you!

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: I’m grateful for the work our employees and so many others in California have continued to do throughout this crisis. We welcome the opportunity to participate in the important conversation to get California reopened safely and effectively.

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: As the nation continues its fight against #COVID, the Lockheed Martin team has worked closely with the United States Department of Defense to provide financial support to defense industry suppliers. Thanks to the DoD’s leadership and foresight to enhance progress payments, we estimate that we will be able to flow down $450 million of these payments to reinforce the American aerospace and defense workforce. In addition, we are expanding accelerated payments to small- and medium-sized businesses in our supply chain by another $50 million – for a total of $156 million. As we take steps to help bolster the economy, we continue to support the medical professionals on the front lines of this pandemic. Below is more information regarding how we are doing that.   -$2 million in donations to Project HOPE to help deliver PPE in coordination with Healthcare Ready and in partnership with FEMA-$2 million to the American Red Cross to support COVID pandemic emergency relief-$2 million to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention Foundation All of Us: Combat Coronavirus emergency response fund To read my full statement, click below.

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: The Lockheed Martin team continues to take concrete steps to aid the national and global #COVID relief effort. Below, we’ve outlined our additional measures to support our employees, vulnerable companies, and the medical community during this time of need. -1,000 new hires in the last two weeks & advertising more than 5,000 open jobs-Committing $50 million for a total of $100 million to support small businesses and our supply chain to sustain jobs-Donating personal protective equipment (PPE) for urgent need at local hospitals-Committing $2 million to FEMA for PPE supplies and medical devices

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: At Lockheed Martin, we recognize that the rapid spread of #COVID and its wide-ranging impacts have caused severe disruption across society and tragic loss of life around the world. We also recognize that the global pandemic has created a need for urgent action by government, business, communities and citizens. That’s why we’re taking the following steps as an initial contribution to the national COVID relief and recovery effort. We’re also offering Lockheed Martin’s engineering and technical capabilities to help solve the most pressing challenges faced by federal, state, and local officials. Read my blog post for more on the Lockheed Martin team’s response to the COVID pandemic: https://bit.ly/3amXqgp

Name: Marillyn Hewson
Text: Last week, I outlined how Lockheed Martin is supporting our workforce, reinforcing the national economy, and assisting the brave men and women of our armed forces. Our initial steps include the allocation of $65.5 million to: bolster small businesses in our supply chain, donate funds to non-profits involved in #COVID relief efforts, and support Lockheed Martin employees impacted by the pandemic. We will keep you updated on these first actions and will have more steps in the days to come.I’d like to personally thank the 110,000 men and women of Lockheed Martin who continue to support our nation, while also stepping up to help meet the critical needs of the nation’s healthcare system. As a global community, we are in uncharted territory. At Lockheed Martin, we continue to be guided by our core principles: Do what’s right. Respect others. Perform with excellence. To the Lockheed Martin team – thank you again for your dedication and the important work you do. And to the courageous and selfless global medical community – thank you for your sacrifice. Your work on the front lines ensures the country’s critical infrastructure can continue serving the nation.
