Join #Back2Better webinar with Executive Networks on Wednesday 21st to hear from Sanyin live! #leadership #hr #coaching #mentoring #webinar

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: Today we are celebrating Kathryn Kai-ling FrederickCMO @ Live Nation Entertainmenthttps://lnkd.in/dr4pCXJAs the newly appointed CMO of Live Nation Entertainment, Kathryn is one of the rare breed of modern business leaders who possesses equal parts of pragmatic business acumen and creative leadership. She brings diversely talented individuals together and creates a collaboratively innovative environment that centers on quantifiable results. Prior to Live Nation, Kathryn was the CMO at Ticketmaster (a subsidiary of Live Nation) where she has made her team the market leader in customer acquisition.Before Ticketmaster, she was the VP of Product Strategy & Marketing for PriceGrabber. She also served as CMO of Distillery No. 209 and helped launch omg! (which later rebranded as Yahoo! Celebrity).Kathryn is not the only shining star of her family. Her father Dr. David Ho is nothing short of legendary. As a recipient of the Presidential Citizens Medal by President Clinton in 2001 & Time magazine’s Man of the Year in 1996, Dr. Ho is currently work on treatments for COVID and other Coronaviruses.~Business Leader Spotlight Series~Who happen to be of #Asian origin.

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: Extremely proud of Best Buy's Corie Barry for being named to Fortune's Most Powerful Women in Business list! Her leadership amid the #COVIDpandemic has been second to none. Bravo, Corie!

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: To say that I am humbled and honored would be a major understatement. I still can't quite believe that I'm being counted among this amazing group of women! 🙇🏻‍♀️ Every single one of the leaders on this list has inspired and continues to inspire so many.🌟 Thank you Fortune for this tremendous honor. 🙏 #44 will forever hold a special place in my ❤️. To my colleagues at AT&T Business AT&T, I'm grateful for the opportunity to work with you every day, in every way. And to all who helped open doors for me, challenged me, and supported me throughout the decades to earn a seat at the table, thank you x ♾. I know it's impossible to pay all of you back - so, my commitment has been and will always be to #PayItForward. "If your actions create a legacy that inspires others to dream more, learn more, do more and become more, then, you are an excellent leader." ~D. Parton #leadership #connectedtogether #BetheChange🌎

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: Fuqua's Alumni Relations team is excited to launch Fuqua Forums.  Fuqua Forums is a series of virtual events created just for alumni on the topics of finance, marketing, entrepreneurship, health care, technology, and strategy. These two-hour sessions will include research presentations and conversations with faculty, practitioner panels featuring interesting Fuqua alumni, and time for network and discussion amongst participants. Sessions take place from 11:30AM - 1:30PM EDT.Learn more at https://lnkd.in/dVbd5dw.Our first event Fuqua Forums: Finance will be Friday, November 13.

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: From Word of Mouth to Word of Machine  --  Are you being smart about AI? As we begin the AceUp conference on "How coaching and technology shape the future of work,"  I started paying more attention to HOW AI impacts how we think. It comes down to who/what you believe for what and we are way more open to considering AI suggestions when it’s labeled Augmented rather than Artificial Intelligence…See more on the AceUp Conference here: https://lnkd.in/enR3Z8eFor more HBR articles and various other goodies go to: https://lnkd.in/ewDksYWhttps://lnkd.in/eXF6ytBSanyin Siang Marshall Goldsmith Terence Jackson, Ph.D. Liz Wiseman Carla Harris David B. Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: Congratulations to my colleague and friend Herman Bulls  on receiving the 2020 Executive Leadership Council (ELC) Achievement Award!  Herman is truly an inspiration! From his humble beginnings learning his hard work ethic from his mother, to graduating from West Point and serving our great nation in the Army until he retired as a Colonel in the US Army reserve... to the exceptional leader, mentor, colleague and friend that I know him as at JLL - his drive, determination, leadership and thoughtfulness are attributes that we can all learn from. Everyone that knows Herman, knows that he has always paved the way for others. Especially African Americans, minorities and women. I can attest to how he truly believes in making connections, creating avenues and helping others achieve professional and personal successes. If there is a way for Herman to help others, without a doubt he will be there asking what he can do. Cheers to you Herman! This is so well deserved. Thank you for always being an example and an inspiration to all of us that are blessed to know you.

Name: Sanyin Siang

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: Thank you to everyone who joined my Medley Conversation with Josh Silverman, CEO of Etsy. This Tuesday (October 20th), I will be continuing the dialogue with Darren Walker, President of the Ford Foundation.Under his leadership, the Ford Foundation became the first non-profit in US history to issue a $1 billion designated social bond in US capital markets for proceeds to strengthen and stabilize non-profit organizations in the wake of COVID. Before joining Ford, Darren was vice president at Rockefeller Foundation, overseeing global and domestic programs. In the 1990s, he was COO of the Abyssinian Development Corporation, Harlem’s largest community development organization.I will be leading the conversation on “Moral Leadership”, a topic Darren wrote about it earlier this month.  A few things we will discuss include his pivot from corporate finance into the nonprofit sector, facing adversity and challenges in tough conversations (including the many he’s had around social inequality and justice), and why surrounding yourself in different, diverse circles is important when taking action and wanting change.  Please join us Tuesday, October 20th at 1:00 PM EST on LinkedIn Live. RSVP here: https://lnkd.in/dZrz4A8 to be notified when are live.

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: What is leadership?If you look that up or ask a group of people you will get a lot of different answers but several common themes.We had Retired US Army MG Tony Cucolo on to give a talk about leadership and wanted to share one of his great takes.In his words, leadership is a process of influencing people by providing them purpose, direction, and motivation to do two things:Accomplish the mission and improve the organization.What is your definition of leadership?#leadership #management

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: “Without trust, we don't truly collaborate; we merely coordinate or, at best, cooperate. It is trust that transforms a group of people into a team.” – Stephen M.R. CoveyLess than half of employees place a great deal of trust in their employer. That leaves a lot of room for improvement.With trust as the foundation for building strong teams, fostering a positive culture, and producing results, how can you build trust as a leader?Sanyin Siang suggests that you can build trust as a team member and leader by sharing your operating principles. When you are explicit about what you care about, you give others a way of interpreting you. You provide them with a guide to how you operate - leaving less room for different interpretations of your actions. "Do people know what you actually care about?If I asked 3 random members of your team what your top values are, would I get the same answer? Would those answers match your answer?"#leadership #coaching #trust #100leaderslive #wbecs #teamcoaching #psychologicalsafety

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: What I did today.  Now you may wonder why this is a LinkedIn post?  It’s simply this - as we lead, live and work in service of our teams, organizations, community, society - doing right by others and ourselves  require an active participation in the aspects that can make that society better.  Active listening, active questioning, active generosity, all bolster that.  For a democracy, participating in voting is key part of making that democracy better .  Friends in the US, please vote.

Name: Sanyin Siang
Text: Friends, this is probably the most exciting thing I will share this year! My next book, "To Be Honest; Lead with the Power of Truth, Justice, and Purpose" is on final approach into the world. And to usher it into life, I will be hosting an online series in the coming months to talk about the findings from the 15-year longitudinal study with more than 3200 interviews on which the book is based. The most important discovery is that honesty isn't just a character trait, it's a muscle that we have to build to get good at. Our world is crying out for greater #honesty.Will you join me on the #journey ? Let's make the #world a safer and more #trustworthy place. Together, let's understand what it really takes To Be Honest.  And you'll get to meet some of the extraordinary people whose insights and experiences grace the book, like Bernard Banks, Ph.D. Tiffany A. Archer, JD, CGSS Dr. Tiffany Jana (they/them) Jonathan Haidt Dan Ariely Amy C. Edmondson Ed Townley Hubert Joly Kathleen Hogan Sanyin Siang Robert Bilott Vincent Stanley Ryan Honeyman (He Him, Coast Miwok Land) Riaz Patel Kim Malone Scott Chris Campbell Jim Detert John Rosling  and many others! Please watch, share, & be inspired.#ethics #mg100 #ToBeHonest #justice #truth #purpose #ethicsmatter #complianceofficer #integrity

Name: Lucy P. Marcus
Text: I am stunned and profoundly honored to have been selected as one of seven finalists from among 2,165 leaders nominated from 135 countries for the Tällberg Eliasson Global Leadership Prize. Named in honor of Jan Eliasson, one of the most accomplished global diplomats of our era, the Prize is given annually to outstanding leaders from any country and any discipline whose work is innovative, courageous, rooted in universal values and global in implication. The three winners will be announced in November 2020. Candidly, given the extraordinary achievements of my fellow finalists, I would be shocked if I win, but it is simply just a tremendous honor to be a finalist for such a prestigious award. I also need to give enormous credit to my colleagues Brian Tronic, Skylar Gleason, and Michael Russo at my public interest law firm, without who I'd get nothing done.

Name: Lucy P. Marcus
Text: After five truly wonderful years with Condé Nast on 'all inhabited continents', as we used to say, we have announced yesterday that I will soon leave the company. As my next chapter, I want to explore/understand/study what more journalism and 'the media' can do about the global climate crisis. My initial assumption is that there is no longer a scarcity of content on the topic but that we need to re-think the framing of climate change journalism so that readers and viewers want to engage with it a lot more. I am so thankful to Condé Nast, to all my wonderful teams and colleagues in Asia, Latin America, the Middle East, Europe and in the US whom I will miss dearly and to Roger Lynch, our CEO, for their continued friendship and for their understanding that I have to do this now. I also can't thank the Reuters Institute enough for granting me a 'visiting fellowship' in Oxford so that we can work on this question together soon. Here some more details on that:

Name: Lucy P. Marcus
Text: I am very proud and excited to share that tomorrow (September 15th 2020) I start my new role with Marks and Spencer as the Group Head of Diversity & Inclusion. It is a real honour to be joining such an iconic British company at such a pivotal moment in their long history and I look forward to being a key part of the M&S transformation. I have already been made very welcome by so many new colleagues post the internal announcement, and I look forward to meeting many of you in the coming weeks; this week I will be in stores in London and Bristol as part of my induction. I also look forward to celebrating National Inclusion Week and Black History Month with you, as we join together to lead the charge towards the change that we all want to see.#diversity #inclusion #diversityandinclusion #nationalinclusionweek #blackhistorymonth

Name: Lucy P. Marcus
Text: In honor of #HispanicHeritageMonth, I’m sharing this photo of me as a kid on my grandparents' ranch in Mexico. My father was welcomed by Mexico after surviving the Holocaust, arriving with nothing but the clothes on his back and the hunger to bring meaning to his life. Mexico has given me so much, my Jewish heritage has given me so much, and the United States has given me so much. I have the opportunity to contribute to my country because I get to combine the best of all of these worlds. Feliz mes de la herencia hispana. Happy Hispanic Heritage Month!

Name: Lucy P. Marcus
Text: EXCITING TIMES!! Still in development, it is expected to be a story about a far more dashing and far more handsome fictional version of me - an international human rights lawyer to travels the world freeing political prisoners. Stay tuned!

Name: Lucy P. Marcus
Text: After 15 years presenting business news at the BBC, I've made a big career move this week and joined Hargreaves Lansdown as a Senior Investment and Markets Analyst. It's been such a privilege to work at the world's leading broadcaster. Not only have I worked with wonderful colleagues but I have also met so many great contributors and guests along the way, some of whom have become very good friends.I am though very excited to take up this new challenge and bring my expertise in covering global financial and economic news to this widely respected savings and investment platform. So, expect lots of commentary from me on TV, radio, online and print in the months to come. The added bonus is that it's based in Bristol, in South West England, so it's very much a welcome home for me, as well as a much shorter commute. However, I am looking forward to hosting more business, economic and environmental conferences around the world, once they resume.A final thank you to all the many friends, mentors, guests and colleagues I have worked with since I rocked up to read the news on BBC Three TV, all those years ago. I’ll look forward to seeing you from the other side of the desk.

Name: Mark Cuban
Text: #opentowork #takeachanceonme #pleasereadAs a hospitality event planner, my position was eliminated at the end of June due to COVID, but was furloughed starting at the end of March. I have applied to 50+ positions in the last few months both within and outside of my industry. I have revised my resume with the help of extremely generous resources 3 times. I have had very few responses, taken assessments, have had phone conversations, and I’ve yet to receive any offers. I’ve successfully been in various positions from a writer, to an executive assistant to a luxury event planner within a variety of industries. I’m resilient. I’m intelligent. I’m willing to learn. Willing to be flexible. I have a work ethic that is honest and full of integrity. I’m  #opentowork - I’m open to finding a role that I can grow into, even if it means learning something new and needing to work a little harder. If I have ever worked with you, for you, or if you’ve ever seen my work (event planning or administrative) - would you mind commenting below of something you’ve seen me do well/successfully/appreciated/etc.? How were our interactions? I’m hoping someone in my network might read something that will remind them of an open position that they can recommend or share my Info!

Text: The Dallas Mavericks are no strangers to success, and they have the records to prove it! Name: Mark Cuban
Text: Don’t drown in opportunity.No matter your business, there will always be people who say “you should also ______”. No product can accomplish everything; succeeding at the 10% now means saying no to the 90%. People who say no (based on vision, goals, and a strong understanding of the market) are more likely to excel. #advice #focus #mentorship

Name: Mark Cuban
Text: This one is for my parents! They immigrated to Canada when I was young to provide me (and my siblings) some of the best opportunities for unlocking our potential. They selflessly sacrificed day and night for us to become our best selves. In middle school, when I was bullied for being a Muslim, they encouraged me to push onwards, and to be proud of who I am.Mum (Fatma Taha, MD, MScP, MHSc), dad (Dr. Abdel Megied Ginena): I'm delighted to hold between my hands my doctorate diploma from the University of Virginia Darden School of Business, to be the winner of the 2019 Academy of Management Best Dissertation-Based Paper Award (Organizational Behavior Division), and to be one of three finalists for the 2020 Society of Business Ethics Best Dissertation Award. I will never be able to repay you, and owe you everything! I also owe a huge debt of thanks to my chair (Lynn Isabella), my dissertation committee members (Andy Wicks, Jim Detert, and Randall S. Peterson), and a ton of colleagues who generously supported me along the way. Finally, I couldn't have done this without the loving support of my wife  – also a #Wahoo! – and kids, they are my joy!My dissertation can be found here: https://lnkd.in/euBWhgGStay tuned for what's next!#UVA #Darden #PhD

Name: Mark Cuban
Text: I’ve been as political as possible for the past few months, when it comes to the GLOBAL CRISIS that is COVID. I’ve prayed for it to go away, and I’ve held out hope that the morons that continue to pretend like this isn’t an issue will come around. It hasn’t happened. I hope you take a moment to watch this video, and I pray that we can come together as ONE, so we can all beat this, well before it beats anyone that YOU love. Stay home. Stay safe. Avoid places you don’t have to go to. Listen to logic. Love your neighbors. The only thing cooler than a picture of you pretending like you don’t care is actually caring. My name is Rogers Healy, and I pray that our world finally figures out that we can love each other, we can support our local businesses, and we can show respect, as long as we do it in a safe manner. Stay safe. #Covid19

Name: Mark Cuban
Text: Ran thru Wendy's drive thru just now, the girl at the window was crying. Her boss was standing there explaining she had to leave work because her mask broke and they had no extras. She was sobbing, "but I don't have a ride and I NEED the money!" Her boss was sympathetic and looked sorry for her. I hopped out, grabbed the bag of extra masks in my trunk that my husband gave me, and handed them a few thru the window. They both looked so shocked and it made the poor girl cry harder when she was thanking me. I got a free Frosty and a damn good feeling inside! #payitforward #kindnesscounts #goodvibes #wendysfrostysthough #yum

Name: Mark Cuban
Text: Our nation is facing three different crises at the same time: COVID, an economic recession, and nationwide protests following the brutal killing of George Floyd. As we work to recover and address the persistent inequities that have only been exacerbated by COVID, I believe expanding our locally driven network of national service programs can be part of the solution. Today, I am proud to introduce the #CORPSAct with Senator Roger Wicker and a broad bipartisan group of colleagues to double the number of AmeriCorps positions available this year to 150,000, eventually providing 600,000 service opportunities over three years to Americans of every background who want to serve their communities while earning a college tuition scholarship, a decent wage, health care, and valuable skills for the future. These positions could support a variety of response and recovery efforts based on community needs, including expanding food pantry capacity, mentoring and tutoring at-risk students, supporting public health needs, and more. This bill has such strong bipartisan support because we’ve seen the power of national service to strengthen our communities and bring about positive change. I'm work hard with my colleagues to include it in the next relief package considered by the Senate.

Name: Mark Cuban
Text: Dallas Mavericks owner Mark Cuban began the conversation with a straightforward question: When did black women gain the right to vote? He then shared the answer: the year after President Donald Trump was old enough to vote for the first time—1965. “When we talk about systemic racism and talk about challenges and hope, and the past, we talk about an African American community who couldn’t vote to change the country, the states, the cities they lived in, until 1965,” Cuban told a group of 100 people who gathered at the American Airline Center’s Victory Plaza on June 6—the day George Floyd was laid to rest. #community #communityimpact #GeorgeFloyd #CourageousConversations #DallasMavs #systemicracism

Name: Mark Cuban
Text: Sharing here first! Here's the advance galley cover of my new book "T-Minus AI: Humanity's Countdown to Artificial Intelligence and the New Pursuit of Global Power" Preorder link! https://bit.ly/TminusAI Despite everything at risk, for most of us #AI remains shrouded by a cloud of mystery and misunderstanding. Hidden behind complex technical terms and confused even further by extravagant depictions in science fiction, the realities of AI and its profound implications are hard to decipher, but no less crucial to understand.In the book, I explain AI from a human-oriented perspective that's easy to comprehend in order to illuminate the cultural and national vulnerabilities already exposed & the pressing issues now squarely on the table. Your preorder support would truly mean the world and I can't wait to share more along this journey over the next 90 days!! #artificialintelligence #technology #bookcoverdesign

Name: Mark Cuban
Text: Mark Cuban Companies is seeking Dallas-based candidates for an open role as a Junior Accountant on our growing portfolio support team. MCC supports a portfolio of more than 150 early stage companies and projects.Applicants must have at least an undergraduate degree in accounting, superb organizational skills, and experience developing monthly financial statements.Message me directly for more information!cc: Mark Cuban

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: Actions Matter. Today, JPMorgan Chase & Co. is making a $30 billion commitment over the next five years to address drivers of the racial wealth divide. We have a collective responsibility to take action to address systemic racism, starting within our own workforce by building a more inclusive environment, and helping Black and Latinx people build small businesses, become homeowners, find an affordable place to live, and improve their financial health.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: When New York companies do well, New Yorkers should share in that success. Our city has a vast pool of talent from across the boroughs, deserving of sustainable and stable career paths. Today I’m proud to announce that JPMorgan Chase & Co. is joining the New York Jobs CEO Council, a joint initiative among 30 of the city's major employers and educational institutions to transform job training, recruiting and hiring in the city. Through collaboration with the City University of New York, the New York City Department of Education, effective nonprofits and local community leaders, we can prepare underserved New Yorkers for in-demand jobs. These are well-paying jobs that will help New Yorkers gain access to economic opportunity and a path to the middle class. Our collective goal is to hire 100,000 New Yorkers by 2030, including 25,000 CUNY students. Thriving societies are built on jobs, and a stable job is often the first step in the ladder of a sustainable career. https://lnkd.in/dzDrrE6

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: It is my hope that we use this crisis as a catalyst to rebuild an economy that creates and sustains opportunity for dramatically more people, especially those who have been left behind for too long.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We manage JPMorgan Chase & Co. consistently with principles that have stood the test of time. Throughout our history, the firm has built its reputation on being there for clients, customers and communities in the most critical times. This unprecedented environment is no different.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: Four essential ways to ensure young people of all backgrounds can be put on a path to career success.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: Capitalism must be modified to do a better job of creating a healthier society, one that is more inclusive and creates more opportunity for more people.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: As we prepare for the new decade ahead, I shared my thoughts with Fortune Magazine on how the future of work is about skills, not just degrees.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We teamed up with Cam Newton for the 6th annual Santa Cam’s Surprise Sleigh in Charlotte, North Carolina! Our team of Chase elves helped Cam and his family deliver gifts and donations to more than 1,000 children and adults at local shelters, after-school programs, administrative systems and schools. These donations will help build new school gyms, improve academic programs, feed the hungry and provide warm clothing for the winter.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We teamed up with Cam Newton for the 6th annual Santa Cam’s Surprise Sleigh in Charlotte, North Carolina! Our team of Chase elves helped Cam and his family deliver gifts and donations to more than 1,000 children and adults at local shelters, after-school programs, administrative systems and schools. These donations will help build new school gyms, improve academic programs, feed the hungry and provide warm clothing for the winter.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We will use this moment as an opportunity to do better — as leaders, as employees and as human beings.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: When someone cannot get their foot in the door to compete for a job, it is bad for business and bad for communities that need access to economic opportunity. Giving more people a second chance allows businesses to step-up and do their part to reduce recidivism, hire talented workers, and strengthen the economy. JPMorgan Chase & Co. is committed to removing barriers to employment for those with criminal backgrounds and advocating for inclusive economic growth.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: It’s an honor that today, for the third consecutive year, JPMorgan Chase & Co. has been named to Fortune Magazine's “Change the World” list. It is critical that business uses its unique capabilities and expertise to play a bigger role in creating economic opportunity for more people. FORTUNE also recognized Business Roundtable, which just released a new Statement on the Purpose of a Corporation, underscoring the commitment of large employers to serve all of their stakeholders, including their employees and communities. I’m proud to serve as Chairman of this group, and especially proud of the employees at JPMorgan Chase whose efforts supporting communities are making a positive impact.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We are all in on Detroit’s future.  Our new investment will help the system work for more people, giving more Detroiters access to the tools they need to succeed, stay and benefit from the city’s continued recovery.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We have always recognized that long-term business success depends on community success. When everyone has a fair shot at participating in and sharing in the rewards of growth, the economy will be stronger and our society will be better.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: Better education and better job training is needed to prepare American workers for the jobs of tomorrow; that’s why JPMorgan Chase & Co. is investing even more in training people to develop the skills needed to succeed.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: As the government shutdown drags on, we’re work hard to help our communities and our customers, just as we do whenever they are struggling.  We’re here to help our customers, whether they’re a government worker, a government contractor or simply an employee at the diner across from a shuttered federal office. Today, JPMorgan Chase & Co. is committing $1 million to Feeding America and United Way Worldwide to provide meals, financial services, counseling, and other assistance to federal workers and their families who are in need. We want a reasonable solution to the shutdown and want to see it end immediately. In the meantime, we continue to serve those who need help.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: The world lost a critical force behind what is now JPMorgan Chase & Co. and, more importantly, an individual universally regarded with praise for his character, generosity and business acumen. Walter Shipley was the former Chairman and CEO of both Chase Manhattan Bank and Chemical Bank. He fostered an open, entrepreneurial meritocracy — one that carries through to this day at JPMorgan Chase. Widely respected for being a straight shooter, Walter believed there was no substitute for talent, drive and hard work. While we mourn the loss of a great leader and strategic thinker, we also remember Walter with a smile for his ability to motivate people while earning their respect through periods of tremendous challenge. We extend our deepest sympathies to his family.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We join the United States in mourning the loss of George H.W. Bush, the nation’s 41st President. As President, he will be remembered for his skillful expertise in foreign affairs. He will also be remembered for signing into law the Americans with Disabilities Act of 1990, one of the nation’s most comprehensive pieces of civil rights legislation. We would not be the diverse, inclusive company we are today without his signing of this historic legislation. We are grateful for President Bush’s devotion to our country and his many achievements that helped to move America forward. His compassion, strength of character and commitment to our country’s role in the world will not be forgotten and will ensure his place in history.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We - business, government and community leaders - have a responsibility to expand economic opportunity for all. J.P. Morgan is taking lessons learned in Detroit, Chicago and Washington D.C. to help create more economic opportunity where it is needed most in Greater Paris.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: It’s important for business and government to work together to find solutions for societal challenges. That’s one reason JPMorgan Chase & Co. launched the #AdvancingCities program. I sat down with Marketplace to discuss how this initiative, and other efforts, can help grow the economy.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: My hat’s off to Lloyd.  He has led his extraordinary firm for over 12 years – seeing it through the darkest days of the financial crisis and helping it emerge stronger than ever before.  Lloyd is a friend of mine -- I congratulated him early yesterday morning, and I’m hoping he’ll have more time to spend with me now!

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We’re making an investment in the Greater Washington region. With new branches comes new jobs and new lending for affordable housing, home mortgages and small businesses.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: We’re excited to be opening branches in the Greater Washington region. Running a healthy company allows us to make investments like this that support the economic future of our communities and employees.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: I’d like to thank our 250,000 employees around the world for their outstanding efforts as our company posted strong results across all of our businesses.  We believe that healthy, vibrant companies like ours can be an engine that helps drive inclusive economic growth for all Americans.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: Our company has been steadfast in our dedication to the clients, communities and countries we serve.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: U.S. businesses can help expand growth for American workers. Read how in my op-ed in the Wall Street Journal.

Name: Jamie Dimon
Text: It's a leader's role, in business or government, to bring people together, not tear them apart.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Reopening won't fix the economy. Beating the virus will.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: President Trump is obsessed with a coronavirus drug. But does it work? Would I take it? After an investigation, here's what I learned...

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Going back to work next week won't save the economy. It will just kill more people and prolong the pain.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Two years in and still so grateful to be a part of building THE sports media company of this generation.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: "If you’re doing anything interesting in the world, you’re going to have critics. If you can't tolerate critics, don't do anything new or interesting.” - Jeff Bezos

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: A huge thank-you to our team, audience, clients, and investors. Insider Inc is now profitable enterprise supporting 500+ journalists and newsrooms in ~20 countries. Our mission is to inform and inspire the digital generation, and we’re just getting started. Thank you all. Better every day!

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: “Failure is essential for success.”  (YES!).  But “trying again and again only works if you learn from previous failures.”

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: I wrote this piece for Business Insider about how Yale's "happiness" class has already helped me learn new habits that are bringing more joy to my daily life. #happiness

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Pres Trump personally employs undocumented immigrants at his golf club. They are excellent employees, not violent criminals. Perhaps he can stop insulting them and instead help them become legal residents?

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Hope to see you all at Ignition!  (Our ninth annual IGNITION: Media, Technology & Transformation conference, New York City, December 3-4).

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Insider TV Executive Producer Tony Manfred explains why we're now focusing on 30+ second video "views" rather than the standard 3+ seconds. In short, better for audience and better for clients.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: “Blockchain is the most overhyped — and least useful — technology in history.”  — Professor Nouriel Roubini pulling no punches...

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: This is really bad news for Bitcoin bulls. It casts further doubt on the already-suspect logic that "Bitcoin is the Internet in 1995." Internet usage never stopped growing, much less shrank. Bitcoin usage is now shrinking.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: CEOs spend 24% of their time doing email, study finds. Study’s authors conclude this is horrible mis-use of time. Respectfully disagree. Email can be extremely fast, convenient, and clear. Need to use well, obviously, but often better for all than meetings.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: "The conclusions for conservatives of today emerge clearly: Do not break the rules that hold a republic together, because one day you will need order. And do not destroy the opponents who respect those rules, because one day you will miss them."

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Girlfriend deletes boyfriend's acceptance letter to dream school because she doesn't want him to leave town... and he doesn't find out for two years

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: San Francisco clash of The People vs The Tech Elite reaches new height of absurdity...  Brilliant protesters block tech buses with pile of VC-funded scooters that people hate.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: China's first high-speed train line was built in 2008. Now they have 15,000 miles of lines serving 3 billion passenger rides per year.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Theranos employees made a video game with the objective of shooting at the reporter who exposed the company's troubles. Here's a video of the game...

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Why does Switzerland have so few gun massacres even with so many guns? Common-sense gun regulations — strict licensing, training, and background checks.

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: Great essay by Steven Pinker. The world is getting better all the time. And it will continue to unless the partisan extremists take over...

Name: Henry Blodget
Text: I spent a portion of my weekend watching the World Economic Forum Annual Meeting sessions in Davos. Highly recommend. I've included a session below featuring Indra Nooyi, Carlos Ghosn, Theresa Whitmarsh, Mark Weinberger, Joseph Stiglitz, and Henry Blodget titled "Towards a Better Capitalism" #WEF18

Text: The decline of good-paying "masculine" jobs like manufacturing is making American men less marriageable. And they don't want to be nurses.

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: Massively important read from Andrew Ross Sorkin on how Milton Friedman affected business for years to come. It's the 50th anniversary of his essay in the @NYTimes Magazine, “The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits.”  Commentary included from Marc Benioff, Anand Giridharadas, Erika Karp and more. #CSR #socialimpact #socialgood #capitalism #sustainability

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: TY Andrew Ross Sorkin for your article today! On the 50th anniversary of #MiltonFriedman's The New York Times article, "The Social Responsibility of Business is to Increase Its Profits", we're re-sharing Anne Bahr Thompson's blog post for the 10th Annual Global Peter Drucker Forum. "Long-term success is dependent on meeting the needs of a wide range of stakeholders: a virtuous—or ethical—interdependent circle that includes customers, employees, suppliers, communities, society at large, and even the planet."

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: "A free market manifesto that changed the world, reconsidered" with excellent current perspective from experts like Darren Walker, Erika Karp, Larry Fink, Glenn Hubbard and many others.  The historical perspective on how Milton Friedman's views became mainstream from Kurt Andersen is critical context.  Thanks Andrew Ross Sorkin.  -- Principles for Responsible Investment

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: Yesterday I was honored to speak on a panel during CNBC's Inclusion in Action Forum, moderated by Andrew Ross Sorkin, along with co-panelists, Blavity Inc. 's Morgan DeBaun and Washington Football Team's President Jason Wright. I discussed the need to create new pathways of access in the financial services and technology industries. Delivering greater equality of opportunity won't be easy, but there are solutions. At Cadre, instead of bemoaning the lack of capital in under-served communities of color, we are using our platform and resources to support Minority Depository institutions by engaging in new business through the financing of real estate transactions and cash deposits. And instead of accepting a lack of diverse job candidates, we are intentionally building a broader, deeper pipeline. Even as our country and world face real hardships, there has also been the rise of real commitments to move from words to action and create needed systemic change. As the forum and panel demonstrated, these commitments are coming from all industries and leaders from ALL walks of life. This gives me more confidence that our collective efforts will achieve real, enduring change.

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: There is a better way to do business! Along with former Delaware Chief Justice Leo Strine, I co-authored a perspective in The New York Times on the change we need. https://lnkd.in/dQMSXcvAnd discussed with Andrew Ross Sorkin!https://lnkd.in/daAsevt

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: Fifty years ago today, Milton Friedman published an incredibly influential essay in The New York Times Magazine, "The Social Responsibility of Business Is to Increase Its Profits." DealBook and The Times magazine reconsider its legacy in a special issue out today. Here are the highlights:  "Greed Is Good. Except When It's Bad"-> A special edition of the DealBook newsletter: https://lnkd.in/dEKbMDz"A Free Market Manifesto That Changed the World, Reconsidered"-> CEOs, Nobel laureates and other top thinkers annotate passages of Friedman's original essay: https://lnkd.in/dkHQwZM"How Liberals Opened the Door to Libertarian Economics"-> Kurt Andersen writes about the historical context of the 1970 essay, namely how "Friedman’s free-market ideas found favor in a free-love era": https://lnkd.in/dv4_CdX"Has Business Left Milton Friedman Behind?"-> Andrew Ross Sorkin asks, “What would Mr. Friedman make of this current moment?”: https://lnkd.in/dBAWHSz#capitalism #shareholders

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: SPECIAL PROJECT: Today, to mark the 50th anniversary of the publication of Milton Friedman’s seminal essay in The New York Times Magazine on Sept 13, 1970 that changed the future of capitalism, DealBook and The Magazine have collaborated on a special section to reflect on that momentous piece...

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: Moving words from Robert F. Smith, the nation's wealthiest African American: "When I see the face of George Floyd, Ahmaud Arbery, or Christian Cooper, I see myself as a young man; I see the faces of my children; and I am reminded of the many times in my life when I have been judged not by my character, but by my skin color. I am not alone." MUST READ.

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: Thoroughly enjoyed Lawrence Ingrassia’s masterfully reported book, “Billion Dollar Brand Club,” on brand building in the age of direct-to-consumer. With a wealth of case studies across Glossier, Inc., Tuft & Needle, Away, and Warby Parker, among others, three verities emerge that make consumers frustrated and brands ripe for disruption:1) Poor price/value equation (real or perceived)2) Poor consumer experience (either at retail first moment of truth, customer service, or uncompetitive “last mile” speed of delivery)3) Little to no true, meaningful category innovation #marketing #brandmanagement

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: Thanks to Andrew Ross Sorkin and Becky Quick for having me on CNBC this morning. The coronavirus pandemic has brought us to a tipping point, where ecommerce and digital payments have become essential services. I don’t think there’s any turning back from that. People want to continue prioritizing safety with contactless payments going forward. PayPal is continuing to innovate with this in mind, particularly with advancing our in-store efforts.

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: The coronavirus seems to be grinding the world to a fearful, lonely halt. It's at times like these -- just as after 9/11 and in the terror of the financial crisis -- when it helps to reread the great C.S. Lewis essay called "Learning In War-Time." Delivered weeks after the start of World War II, it inspires us to keep going. I share with you here my favorite passage: #coronavirus #cslewis #inspiration

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: Some thoughts on Business Transformation Readiness for COVID. Please join in the ideation on how, as business leaders, we can work together to protect our people and their families, support our businesses, and make a difference.

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: The bailouts in 2008 undoubtedly worked despite the political blow-back. But it is less clear that the same kind of stimulus is right this time around. Let's have the bailout debate now so it can be done smartly if it is needed..

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: “I suspect that before it is over, there will once again be an urgent need in an election year for bipartisan support in Congress to work with the administration if we are to mitigate the economic burden on Americans.”Hank Paulson speaks to Andrew Ross Sorkin of The New York Times about the economic response to the coronavirus crisis, and how it compares to the 2008 crisis.“In some ways, this is more complex because it also involves important health issues. This will once again test our political system, but I believe our leaders will rise to the challenge as our nation has always done in a crisis.”https://lnkd.in/g5MUT4i#Coronavirus #COVID #Economics #Treasury

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: One of the things I'm most excited about as part of my next play as LinkedIn's Executive Chairman, will be helping to close the #networkgap. A few of you have asked about my specific areas of focus: 1. Advancing diversity, inclusion, and belonging at LinkedIn through continuing work on innovative recruiting practices, allyship and mentoring efforts, unconscious bias education, apprenticeship programs for people with non-traditional backgrounds, and ongoing ERG support. 2. Working with an incredibly talented LinkedIn product team to redefine the way under-connected youth and underserved communities make connections and gain social capital on LinkedIn and off.3. Sharing our "every member" efforts beyond LinkedIn, e.g., minimizing unconscious bias in algorithms, and learning from our customer’s best practices. 4. Continuing to partner with non-profits committed to serving underserved communities, e.g., Year Up, Management Leadership for Tomorrow, Boys & Girls Clubs of the Peninsula. 5. Working with our Social Impact team to turn the #plusonepledge into a movement. 6. Investing in start-ups with diverse founders, serving underserved communities, and/or dedicated to building diverse teams through Sean Mendy's new Concrete Rose Capital fund & foundation.

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: GA CEO Bill Ford was joined by David M. Solomon and Stacey Cunningham at the 2020 World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in Davos for the “Valuing Unicorns” panel, moderated by Andrew Ross Sorkin. Bill spoke about GA’s framework for valuing companies and creating long-term growth: “It’s about good governance, getting the right independent board in place, making sure there’s enough management depth to take on being a public company, making sure they can handle quarterly reporting… Making sure they have a real path to profitability if they’re going to go out before they’re profitable. And that’s our job, to discipline those companies, to have them ready, and so when they go, they can be successful and deliver value to investors in the public market.” #Davos2020 #WEF2020 #DrivingGlobalGrowth

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: I'm in San Francisco in early February to talk about my new book, Billion Dollar Brand Club. It chronicles a revolution in the way new brands are created, like Warby Parker, Dollar Shave Club, ThirdLove, Glossier, Inc., Hubble Contacts, Casper, quip., Allbirds, Tuft & Needle, Eargo, Away, eSalon, Stitch Fix, Harry's, Inc., Mohawk Group Holdings, Inc. (NASDAQ: MWK) and others, with the help of VC investors like Forerunner Ventures, digital marketing firm Ampush, and innovative logistics startups like Quiet Logistics, Locus Robotics and FLEXE. The book shows how technology has leveled the playing field, enabling entrepreneurs to take on corporate giants in ways unthinkable a decade ago.   Join me at 7 p.m. Wednesday Feb. 5 at Book Passage, Ferry Building Marketplace, San Francisco, https://lnkd.in/ghuVNrj.    And at 7 p.m. Thursday Feb. 6 at Books Inc., 317 Castro Street, Mountain View, https://lnkd.in/gPheESa    If you can't make it, you can order the book from various sites online at my web site: https://lnkd.in/gmVMGsX    Larry Ingrassia

Name: Andrew Ross Sorkin
Text: Even if a job title impresses other people, it's the wrong choice if the day-to-day work depresses you.In career decisions, beware of being seduced by status. Pursue a job where you can express your values in a culture where people share those values.

Name: David McCormick
Text: Great to see research by Bridgewater’s Sustainable Investing Team alongside many leading thinkers in the newly released book, “Sustainable Investing: A Path to a New Horizon.” In their chapter, Bridgewater’s Karen Karniol-Tambour, Carsten Stendevad, Daniel Hochman, Jacob Davidson, and Brian Kreiter discuss how investors may think about building a scalable portfolio that is designed to achieve financial returns as well as positive environmental and social impacts.

Text: I want to congratulate my friend and our COO Brian Kreiter, who last week received the 2020 Innovator Award from A Better Chance, recognizing his longstanding commitment to empowering individuals and communities. Name: David McCormick
Text: September 28 marked the end of my proverbial “First 90 Days” as The Wharton School dean – a Zoom-filled first 90 days like no other. I took time to reflect on what’s transpired since my appointment and the #leadership lessons I’ve learned thus far: 1. Embrace the concept of “swift trust”2. Ask questions to inform your priorities3. Find people who energize you & seek out time with them4. "Wag the tail" i.e. lead the leaders

Name: David McCormick
Text: It was a privilege to sit down with General Joseph Dunford (ret.), the former Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, and Julia Friedlander from the Atlantic Council, for a wide-ranging conversation about the future of American economic and national security. We discussed how innovation is critical to our nation’s future, the need to integrate the government’s approach to statecraft, and the themes of the paper I co-authored, "Economic Might, National Security and the Future of American Statecraft." It was a particular honor to be joined by General Dunford, an incredibly distinguished leader and one of the foremost strategic thinkers I know. I agree completely with him that we must come together as a country to address the array of security challenges we face, and I trust that will rise to the occasion. Thank you to Julia and her colleagues at the Atlantic Council’s new GeoEconomics Center for hosting this timely discussion.

Name: David McCormick
Text: It was my honor to host Stephen A. Schwarzman for Bridgewater’s Distinguished Speaker Series. Stephen is a true icon in the world of business and finance, a renowned philanthropist, and an all-around great guy. I enjoyed hearing him recount his early years, the story of founding Blackstone, and the values that underpin its culture. He said something that resonated with me and our own culture at Bridgewater: “The job of a leader isn’t to give an answer. The job of a leader is to establish a process and let everybody else’s talent come forward.” Thank you, Stephen, a pleasure to have you. Our full conversation is available here: https://lnkd.in/eZ59buk

Name: David McCormick
Text: Thrilled to see the creation of Hobson College at Princeton University, which was made possible by a gift from Mellody Hobson and the Hobson/Lucas Family Foundation. This is the first residential college at Princeton named for a Black woman, which is fitting for Mellody, who as a transformational corporate and philanthropic leader has broken down barriers throughout her career. She went from being the first in her family to graduate college to co-CEO of Ariel Investments and serving on the boards of Starbucks, JPMorgan Chase, and DreamWorks Animation. And Mellody’s words on her gift demonstrate her commitment to helping others like her succeed: “My hope is that my name will remind future generations of students — especially those who are Black and brown and the ‘firsts’ in their families — that they too belong.”

Name: David McCormick
Text: Even as we continue to fight the coronavirus pandemic, we can’t take our eyes off the long game of national renewal. In this piece for the Milken Institute, I propose five guiding principles for our government’s role in strengthening America’s scientific and technological leadership.

Text: Social conditions are increasingly important for how the economy will be managed. The Covid downturn has disproportionately hit the most vulnerable, and the new policy landscape created in its wake is one more able to pay attention to inequalities and reverse the tide of declining quality of life measures. New research with Melissa Saphier, Yusuf Jailani and Jeremy Fraenkel.

Name: David McCormick
Text: Great to speak with Tom Keene and Francine Lacqua at Bloomberg about some of the challenges facing investors today. While we don't know if the inflation pendulum will swing back after decades of monetarism and global disinflation, good risk management says we should think through what that scenario, and the Fed's latest policy changes, could mean for portfolios.

Text: Phil Dobrin came to Bridgewater straight out of college and I’ve been witness to his growth and development over the years. Today his brilliance shines through as both a savvy researcher and an invaluable partner to our clients. Congrats, Phil – this recognition is well deserved.

Name: David McCormick
Text: I’m looking forward to National Geographic's series on OceanXplorer, Ray Dalio’s cutting edge deep ocean research vessel. This project is yet another example of Ray’s insatiable curiosity and creativity, as he converted a used oil ship into a scientific instrument that could unlock the mysteries of the ocean. I'm excited to discover more about such a critical part of our planet. From climate change to evolution, this series could reframe what we know about the world, and equally important, how we share that newfound knowledge with others. To quote Ray: “It will be mind-blowing.”https://lnkd.in/ejj-vdx OceanX

Name: David McCormick
Text: Now that she has this month formally taken the helm of the the Hoover Institution, I wanted to take a moment to congratulate Condoleezza Rice, and also recognize the Hoover Institution, for this magnificent choice. Never has the work of the institution been needed more as a catalyst for new thinking and as a convener of ideas that promote greater economic and political freedom in our country and around the world. There is no one more capable than the former Secretary of State to lead this charge and my wife Dina and I are inspired to support her and the Hoover Institution in the years to come. https://lnkd.in/gwsveZQThe Hoover Institution, Stanford University

Name: David McCormick
Text: 2020 has been a year that necessitates reflection. A year that raises deep questions of values, of where we’re trying to head as individuals, as organizations and as a society. This brings me to continually reflect on what boat I am in, and who I am sharing it with. Any destination we reach will be the result of what we can accomplish together. More than anything, I am grateful for the people I am on this ride with.  David McCormick,  Ray Dalio, Greg Jensen, Bob Prince, Karen Karniol-Tambour, Kevin Brennan, Asaf Gilboa, Leigh Fisch, Kelly Timko, Tricia Lewis, Sean Macrae, Kerry During, Osman Nalbantoglu, Noah Yechiely, Jason Rotenberg, Porter Diehl Steven Kryger, Alex Schiller, Phil Salinger, Amit Srivastava, Avraam Sidiropoulos, Gardner Davis, Matt Karasz, Atul Narayan, Erin Miles, Jonathan Fernandez, Robyn Shepherd, Michal Bar haim, Gal Bar Dea, Giora Bar Dea, Larry Cofsky, Rebecca Patterson , Bridgewater Associates, The Wharton School , IDC Herzliya, Israel Defense Forces, Fortune

Name: David McCormick
Text: Today we mourn the passing of a towering figure in America’s judiciary: a first-rate legal mind, a pioneer in the pursuit of women’s rights, and among the finest judicial strategists our nation has produced with a passion for civil liberties. She was beloved by her colleagues on the Bench and was regarded not just for her extraordinary wisdom, but also for her warmth and love of the arts and music. It would be nice to think that somewhere in the hereafter, she and her friend, the late great conservative Justice Antonin Scalia, will enjoy an opera together again.

Name: David McCormick
Text: Hollywood producer Brian Grazer, known for great films such as Apollo 13 and A Beautiful Mind, is a legend in his industry and is one of the most creative, entertaining, wildly successful yet down-to-earth people I know. It was a treat to have him spend an hour with our Bridgewater community in a wide-ranging conversation. We discussed his reflections on race relations and representation in Hollywood, how determination and charm landed Brian his first break, how curiosity has fueled his career, his encounter with Fidel Castro, a humbling moment he had at the Oscars, how he handles critical feedback, his hopes for his legacy, and more. Thank you for joining us, Brian — great to see you. The full recording is available here:

Name: David McCormick
Text: I have often said that I am a steadfast believer in term-limits. With that in mind, I have given significant thought to when the time is right for me to hand over the reins and I have decided to retire in February of next year.37 years ago I joined Citi right out of college. In the years since, I have worked with wonderful people and had incredible experiences. We have shared great successes and we have been tested, during the financial crisis and, most recently, the COVID pandemic. Through every test, I have seen my colleagues rise to the occasion. I look back at eight years as CEO and couldn’t be prouder of what we accomplished. What I have seen gives me tremendous confidence in Citi’s future. I am thrilled that our Board of Directors has chosen Jane Fraser to succeed me. Jane will become our first female CEO, a point of pride for all of us and groundbreaking for our industry. I am grateful to have been a custodian of this institution and am excited to see what happens next.

Name: David McCormick
Text: I would like to extend my warmest congratulations to Jane Fraser, Mike Corbat, and the whole team at Citigroup on Jane’s historic selection as CEO. This is welcome news, and I am sure Jane will thrive and set an important tone for future leadership on Wall Street. I also applaud Mike for his steady leadership of Citi over the past eight years coming out of the financial crisis, and his thoughtful management of this transition.

Name: David McCormick
Text: I am fortunate to work alongside so many talented individuals, whose diverse backgrounds make Bridgewater such a vibrant place. Among them is my colleague Nir Bar Dea, who Fortune Magazine recently named to its "40 Under 40" list. Nir joined Bridgewater in 2015 after a decorated career in the Israeli Defense Forces, as an entrepreneur, and later with Israel's Permanent Mission to the United Nations. We quickly realized that we had found an incredible leader whose experiences fostered a deep appreciation for developing people and building strong teams. Today, Nir is Co-Head of our Investment Engine and I am grateful to be in the trenches with him. Congratulations for this recognition, Nir. I encourage all of you to read more about him here:

Name: David McCormick
Text: I recently read and would recommend “The Splendid and the Vile” by Erik Larson. It’s an incredible book chronicling the leadership of Winston Churchill during the two-year period of World War II when the United Kingdom fought Germany without the help of the United States. The book is a deep dive into Churchill’s thinking at the time, drawn from his own writing and that of his close associates. What jumps out is Churchill’s remarkable capacity to confront, with brutal candor, the reality his nation faced, the odds that were against Britain – and his ability to inspire, with genuine optimism, the capacity of British people to prevail. It’s the best example of a leader who was able to balance those two things so beautifully – the candor and the optimism. A fantastic read.

The book is a deep dive into Churchill’s thinking at the time, drawn from his own writing and that of his close associates. What jumps out is Churchill’s remarkable capacity to confront, with brutal candor, the reality his nation faced, the odds that were against Britain – and his ability to inspire, with genuine optimism, the capacity of British people to prevail. It’s the best example of a leader who was able to balance those two things so beautifully – the candor and the optimism. A fantastic read.

Name: David McCormick
Text: I recently read and would recommend “The Splendid and the Vile” by Erik Larson. It’s an incredible book chronicling the leadership of Winston Churchill during the two-year period of World War II when the United Kingdom fought Germany without the help of the United States. The book is a deep dive into Churchill’s thinking at the time, drawn from his own writing and that of his close associates. What jumps out is Churchill’s remarkable capacity to confront, with brutal candor, the reality his nation faced, the odds that were against Britain – and his ability to inspire, with genuine optimism, the capacity of British people to prevail. It’s the best example of a leader who was able to balance those two things so beautifully – the candor and the optimism. A fantastic read.
